Subject: [sfraves] Oh Yeah.. Cannabass Lastnight



---------------------------- Original Message ----------------------------
Subject: Oh Yeah.. Cannabass Lastnight
From:    "Osby Oi Oi Jamz" <osby@viberation.com>
Date:    Thu, March 31, 2005 5:32 pm
To:      sfraves@hyperreal.org
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

OK.. so like yeah... things kinda happened unexpectedly on my endof things
& I ended up not going 2 class lastnight... so LoL.. I went 2 the ol' BnB
early 4 ummm... the open decks throwdown 4 Cannabass.. it's also like
mondo Groovy 'cause well.. I picked up an old story I wrote like 2 years
ago that I ended as an open ending end.. & i read it again & thought,
Hello 2day, let's add more.. so I can honestly say that I did spend a huge
chunk of the night like writing in my notebook.. LoL

OK.. DJs... ummm.. there was like this tall Groovy "Berkeley Kid" lookin
Cat who busted a good set during open decks well.. it was more or less the
sound check set 'cause yeah... they had some probs.. but it worked out..
Dope!

OK... My Jungle Slut from Santa Cruz & her BF came up 2 spin... so Dymphna
hit the decks & ya know.. it was a really chill set from her lastnight...
she played alot tracks that, Ummm, like had more of the jazzy instrumental
breakdowns playing then the hard bass jungle, like i dunno.. reversed dnb
songs.. la la la.. but it was smooth.. she pretty much stayed jazzy the
set, so yeah!  So Dope!!  Oh yeah.. but she did get in some hard tunes
here & there, so that was Groovy!  But yeah.. the many many times I've
seen Dymphna spin... this may have been the 1st time ever I heardher go
mello & not hard boom boom boom... LoL

OK.. DJ Sik went on next... he took up a step & well.. he played OK ok
ok.. shoot me if I'm getting this wrong, Liquid Funk!?!?!! YUMMY none the
less!

OK.. now KODA went up & yeah.. he played his signature raga Jungle, but it
was a trip.. he busted out this track that wasn't Raga,, so that weird &
like when that track dropped, me & Lewt like looked @ each other & laughed
=)

O.. but I wasn't there 4 all of KODA's set 'cause, YAY, my Homie Crash
from LA came up 2 Oakland 2 spin & him, me, & his GF went 2 get like food
real quick...

We got bac & KODA finished his set.. OK.. then Crash went on..
Heeeeeeeeello 2Day,,, see,, Homeboy's been my Bro 4 like the past 2 years
& we ain't seen each other since 2004... but we do talk online like every
other day!!  He just picked up the tables last year or like year & 1/2 &
right away practiced on DNB 'cause that's his musical Love!  \O/  Yeah.. &
now he's fuckin Sick w/ his spinning!!  YAY!!  His set was fuckin
Awesome!!  I mean.. yeah.. he was just playing all this hard bassy jungle
& me & his GF totally like grabbed floor!

The vibe was chill.. I mean.. there wre people dancing, people drink,
alota laughing... it was a Good night there!!  I Loved it!!!  YAY!!





Jungle:::::YUM!

-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)






---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] SFRaves Planners Dinner - 040305 @ 8pm

**************************************************************
SFRaves Planners Dinner! - 040305 @ 8pm:METREON!
**************************************************************
When: Sunday, April 3, 2005
Where: Sony Metreon Food Court (1st Floor) - 101 Fourth Street, San 
Francisco, CA 94103
Time: 8pm
URL: http://www.metreon.com/dining/index.html
Cost: FREE (No Admission) - BYOF (Bring your own food or food to share - 
Potluck Style :)
**************************************************************
To kick off the event planning SFRaves is hosting an informal dinner with 
SFRaves Planners @ The Sony Metreon, Located @ 101 Fourth Street, San 
Francisco, CA 94103 @ 8pm on Sunday, April 4, 2005.

We are meeting in the food court located on the 1st floor, seated in the 
center of the Food Court. Karina (karina@hyperreal.org) will be wearing 
her SFRaves laminate for easy identification.
**************************************************************
Directions:
**************************************************************

Metreon is located at THE CORNER OF FOURTH AND MISSION STREETS in the 
heart of San Francisco. Located next to Yerba Buena Gardens, Moscone 
Center, Zeum, and just blocks from Union Square and the cable car lines. 
The street address is 101 Fourth Street, San Francisco, CA 94103.

Metreon is located just across the street from the Yerba Buena Garage, 
with over 2,500 parking spaces. Additional parking can be found around the 
neighborhood.

Taking public transportation to Metreon is easy! Metreon is just a few 
blocks from both Powell and Montgomery BART and Muni stations; close to 
over thirty transit stops; within walking distance of the Transbay 
Terminal and the Ferry Building; and a short ride from Caltrain. For 
transit information, call 817-1717 in any Bay Area area code. Visit 
http://www.transitinfo.org/ for maps and schedules of Bay Area public 
transit.

**************************************************************
Purpose: 
**************************************************************
We are meeting plan our first collaborative event taking place
on April 30, 2005 as well as to plan the SFRaves 13 Year A
Annniversary Party!
**************************************************************
**************************************************************
Agenda / We will be meeting to discuss: 
************************************************************** 
**************************************************************
SFRaves Collaborative Event on April 30, 2005: 
**************************************************************
*Venue 
*Sound and lighting
*DJ Lineup
*Equipment
*Decorations
*SFRP Community Reach Out
*SFR TSHIRTs :), et AL
*Flyers, Promotions
*Shifts
*Badges
*Structure 
*Themes, Art, Decor *Art Installations *Dancers & Artists

**************************************************************
SFRaves 13 Year Anniversary Planning: 
**************************************************************
*Venue 
*Sound and lighting
*DJ Lineup
*Decorations
*Equipment
*Permitting 
*Security
*Flyers, Promotions
*Shifts
*Badges

*Themes 
*Permitting
*Food
*Decor
*Art Installations
*Dancers & Artists

**************************************************************
* To subscribe to SFRaves Planners list, send an email message to:

sfraves-planners-subscribe@hyperreal.org
**************************************************************
What is SFRaves Planners?
**************************************************************

We are a collective of individuals who meet to coordinate, plan, and throw 
Quality events in colloboration with a number of resources serving the 
Collective Community...

Our goals & intent are threefold:

1) For sfraves-planners to act as a vehicle of communication, available as 
both a resource and a medium for those who wish to be part of and 
participate in the process of planning, organizing and throwing events 
with SFRaves & Hyperreal.

2) To create a resource for those who wish to colloborate in throwing 
events between SFRaves & other crews, promoters, djs, artists, venue 
owners, producers, production members, crews and collectives which make up 
our diverse and fantastic community.

3) To plan, organize, promote and host current, future and ongoing events 
for the SFRaves community and beyond into the reaches of the Nightlife and 
Dance community in the greater SF / SJ Bay Area. This includes 
collaborative events, one-offs, weekly events, outdoor and indoor events, 
small intimate affairs and large gatherings. This theme is growing and 
includes plans for outdoor campouts, bonfires and burns, as well as 
planning the SFRaves 13 Year Anniversary which is now in planning stages.

**************************************************************
What is the Collective Community? 
**************************************************************

The Collective Community *IS* the greater Electronic Music & Dance 
Community that SFRaves serves - Studios, Video Production and Visuals 
resources, Record labels, Websites and other online / offline resources 
(sfdance, sfjungle, groundscore, bayraves, bayarearavers, burningman, 
sfstation, ravelinks, etc) Contacts, Collectives and Crews (too many to 
list), Producers, DJS, Live Acts, SFRaves Calendar & SFRaves Discussion 
List members, Event planners, Production Crews, Sound and Lighting, Radio 
Stations, TV, Venue Owners, Promotions, Nightlife specialists, Event 
promoters, raver, clubber, party-participant, members of online 
communities pertaining to SFRaves (e.g. tribe.net, friendster.com, 
orkut.com, myspace.com, livejournal.com, multiply.com) as well as event 
participant / patron alike.

************************************************************** 
**************************************************************
SFRaves Planners WANTS YOU! 
**************************************************************

Who is available to donate time and energy for our first collaborative 
event? Details to be released shortly...

**************************************************************
Here are a few of the items that we need help with:

*DJ Lineup
*Decorations
*Information Table
*Flyers, Promotions
*Shifts
*Badges
*Structure
*Artwork and Decor
*Lighting/Visuals
**************************************************************
More information is available @
http://www.sfraves.org &  http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2

April 30, 2005 - SFDance / SFRaves BDAY BASH!

SFRaves in collaboration with SFDance is celebrating our birthdays
together in style!

HAPPY BIRTHDAY SFDANCE AND SFRAVES !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

SFRaves is 13 Years Old this Year - This event is the first of many
events SFRaves and SFDance are planning in collaboration with one another.

This is also the first of several preludes of celebrations of SFRaves
becoming a teenager - one of several collaborative events planned
throughout the year to climax our coming of age - an orgasmic BASH
is planned of epic proporation for the SFRave's 13 year Anniversary
later this summer. Keep your ears the ground and stay tuned for more
information.

SFRaves/SFDance are ready to celebrate with one SWANK affair.
We are planning an event to celebrate one another's blessing
GAIA and our TERRA FIRMA.

hidden between Market/Mission
in the heart of
San Francisco's
world famous
SOMA district

block to 6th St.

Subject: [sfraves] Stop Crying Over Spilt Milk

Ok i'm tired of hearing about this stupid Terri Schiavo crap.  Why's
everyone gotta have their panties crammed up their butts over this one
stupid girl.  There are probably a few hundred of people in very
similar situations, but you dont hear crap from them or their
families.  Why get so worked up over this one?  I dont get it.  It's
stupid and retard, just like she was.

Actually it's funny cause she may have been retarded confined to a
life of drooling on herself, but you know what?  It was her parents
who were the real retards.  I mean come on, who would want to see
their child live like that?  To carry this crap on for 15 years?  Well
actually the real legal bullshit didnt start until like what year 8? 
Which to me is still way too long to let her live like that.  But to
then drag it through the court system for another 7 years?  That's so
stupid.  Now it's all thrown up in our faces, and we cant escape it. 
I put a lot of effort into avoiding the news.  Cause to me it's like
listening to 94.9 or some other piece of shit top 40 radio station. 
Listen to some crap...take a 2 minute break, listen to the same crap
again...talk about something else for a minute and now that you think
you're done listening to the same piece of shit, here you go again,
only this time we're gonna play the super long extended club you over
the head mix and then just to make sure you dont forget it, we'll go
over it one more time, before we go over it again.

Stupid religious parents...just let her die and go be with your God. 
If he truely is all powerful and all fogiving and all that shit and
looks down on suicide/euthenasia and what not, i think he'll still
take little Terri into his arms at the pearly necklace...er i mean
pearly gate.  So why not end her suffering and live out the rest of
her afterlife in peace and happiness.  Lets film this chick for like 5
hours and edit it down to the 4 minutes we think she might have
actually be responsive and use that as our defense that she is
responsive and not a permanent kumquat.  How stupid is that?  Sounds
like they should go work for Fox News, so they can help them edit it
out all the truth and reality in news and force feed us what the
stupid right wing dumbasses have the think about stuff, then maybe one
day they can work their way up to the glorius position of being G. W's
personal ass wipers.

I cant belive they enjoyed seeing their child like that.  I mean sure
i bet they loved her more than anything and no parent wants their
child to die before them, but come on.  Is the pain of knowing your
daughter died with as little suffering as possible, greater then the
pain of seeing your child live a meaningless miserable life every day?
 I for one, would rather have the one single pain of knowing i had to
end my childs life for the better.  Knowing I let them die in peace
and not live a fabulous life of drooling on themselves, would help me
get over it, and i was relish in all the happy memories.  It'd be more
painful to have to go to a hospital everyday to see my child drool on
itself because i could no longer give it the care that it needed. 
Sounds like like taking a needle and slowly pushing it into your
eye...god damn this hurts, but for some reason i just cant stop
myself.  Fucking stupid plain and simple.

-- 
Chester Copperpot

"Goonies never say die!"
"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
"I feel like I'm taking crazy pills"

At 09:09 AM 4/1/2005, Chester Copperpot wrote:
>Ok i'm tired of hearing about this stupid Terri Schiavo crap.  Why's
>everyone gotta have their panties crammed up their butts over this one
>stupid girl.  There are probably a few hundred of people in very
>similar situations, but you dont hear crap from them or their
>families.  Why get so worked up over this one?  I dont get it.  It's
>stupid and retard, just like she was.



Whatever your personal beliefs are concerning Terry
Schiavo...

Were you aware that George W. Bush signed a law in
Texas that expressly gave hospitals the right to remove
life support if the patient could not pay and there was
no hope of revival, regardless of the patient's
family's wishes? It is called the Texas Futile Care
Law.

Under this law, a baby was removed from life support
against his mother's wishes in Texas just this week. A
68 year old man was given a temporary reprieve by the
Texas courts just yesterday.

Were you aware that Republicans have voted en masse to
pull the plug (no pun intended) on Medicaid funding
that pays for the kind of care that someone like Terry
Schiavo and many others who are not so severely brain
damaged need all across this country?

Were you aware that the tort reform that is being
contemplated by the Republican congress would preclude
malpractice claims like that which has paid for Terry
Schiavo's care thus far?

Were you aware that the bankruptcy bill will make it
even more difficult for families who suffer a
catastrophic illness like Terry Schiavo's because they
will not be able to declare chapter 7 bankruptcy and
get a fresh start when the gargantuan medical bills
become overwhelming?

Were you aware that this grandstanding by the congress
is a purely political move designed to appease the
religious right and that the legal maneuverings being
employed would be anathema to any true small government
conservative? (See the now infamous memo circulated to
GOP House & Senate members...)

We are now seeing a spectacle on television in which
the news anchors repeatedly say that the congress is
"stepping in to save Terry Schiavo" mimicking the
unctuous words of Tom Delay as they grovel and leer at
the family and nod sympathetically at the sanctimonious
opportunists who are using this issue for their
political gain.

This is why it's become so difficult to trust the
mainstream media. Most people get their news from
television. And television is presenting this issue as
a round the clock one dimensional soap opera pitting
the "family", the congress and the church against this
woman's husband and the judicial system that upheld
Terry Schiavo's right and explicit request that she be
allowed to die if extraordinary means were required to
keep her alive. The ghoulish infotainment industry is
making a killing by acceding once again to trumped up
right wing hypocrisy.

What Americans think:

ABC News (PDF). 3/20. MoE 4.5% (No trend lines.)
Removal of feeding tube

Support 63
Oppose28

Federal Intervention

Support 35
Oppose 60

Appropriate for Congress to get involved?

Appropriate 27
Not Appropriate 70

Reason political leaders are trying to keep Shiavo
alive

Concern about Shiavo 19
Political Advantage 67




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] (sort of rr) Reclaim the Streets!  Saturday!  SF!  ComMUNIty Mutiny!

sorry for the late notice on this...  anyway, it
should be fun!  if you haven't been to a Reclaim the
Streets before, come check it out.  they've got the
spirit of a great underground renegade - but set loose
on the streets of SF...

RTS-SF and the Coalition for Transit Justice in
standing up against muni fare hikes! Experience
thepower of community, delight in the thrill of an
impromptu street party, revel in creative
performances, art, dancing, and music, all while
taking a stand against the increasing commodification
of public space and public transportation.  

Bring your banners, noisemakers, puppets, urban
redecoration toolkits, friends and of course your very
sexy self to Dolores Park, Saturday April 2nd at noon
o'clock. This parade gets on the road at one pm,
marching to an undisclosed location for a street party
and masquerade ball. So don't forget to come in
costume! 

(I can't vouch for the music for the whole event, but
i do know there's going to be some hot
technofunk/electro including some original tunes from
12:30 to 1pm in Dolores Park before the march starts.)

THURSDAY, Mar. 31st to April 1st
Club 6 Presents
The Filming of
RENT THE MOVIE

Chris Columbus, the same film director who brought us Home Alone (1990), 
Mrs. Doubtfire (1993), Nine Months (1995), Stepmom (1998), Bicentennial Man 
(1999), Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001) and Harry Potter and 
the Chamber of Secrets (2002), plans to make his next movie in his own 
backyard -- between San Francisco and the East Bay.

6th St. was chosen because of it's unique resemblance of the Lower East 
Side in the 70's. During the filming of the movie, Club 6ix will be 
transformed into a transvestite bar frequented by the main characters.






Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

a trance/techno fan would yer ;)

what's up with this dude?  always get me kicking and acting foolishly
with pumping musics outloud?  i mean when i go to mainstream music
stores i often find myself wondering around the techno section looking
for his latest gigs.  called me hypnotized and brainwashed.  call me
anything your like... but i just like his stuff.  albeit some albums
shared same tracks but they go together in harmonously per album..

what do i say about CL'slatest album?  go buy it along with a seven
pack of mood altering stuff then chill forget anything that u wanna
forget.

have a wonderful weekend folks.

l&hugs.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject: [sfraves] ARGHHHHH!!!!!!!!!!!

    sorry, i need to vent bigtime. so the restaurant
that i have been mangaing for a little while opened a
new location. the one i work at has the "commisary
kitchen" which means that we make everything for all
the other locations. which means that my life is hell
right now. 

my boys in the back are mad because they don't have
the equipment they need. it's been ordered, after
bothering the bosses for a week, but who knows when it
will come? 

my foh staff is pissed because our location is running
out of things, which they hate. cause of course the
customers get pissy when that happens. 

my suppliers are mad cause i can't give them a clear
idea day to day what to expect. hiccups of opening a
new place. 

and i'm pretty sure next week my bosses will be a
little miffed because i intentionally over ordered
going into the weekend because we don't get another
delivery till monday. 

not to mention the fact that because a new location
opened i am now understaffed, specially since i have
to fire someone on monday for stealing money and the
gm (i'm the am) is out of town till april 12th.
horrible timing. 

needless to say, i am ecstatic that i have this
weekend off. between brass tax, get freaky, and god
knows where saturday will take me, then some good
outdoor earthy dirty fun, i will hopefully go into
next week, which will only be harder, a little calmer
and much happier. god i wish i was really off of work.
this is the longest day i've pulled in a while, only
cause i have to wait for this one customer to come in
so i can deal with his order. then i'm done. party
time!!!!! he better be on time!

At 11:22 AM 4/1/2005, Apollo wrote:

>At 09:09 AM 4/1/2005, Chester Copperpot wrote:
>>Ok i'm tired of hearing about this stupid Terri Schiavo crap.  Why's
>>everyone gotta have their panties crammed up their butts over this one
>>stupid girl.  There are probably a few hundred of people in very
>>similar situations, but you dont hear crap from them or their
>>families.  Why get so worked up over this one?  I dont get it.  It's
>>stupid and retard, just like she was.
>
>
>
>Whatever your personal beliefs are concerning Terry
>Schiavo...
>
>Were you aware that George W. Bush signed a law in
>Texas that expressly gave hospitals the right to remove
>life support if the patient could not pay and there was
>no hope of revival, regardless of the patient's
>family's wishes? It is called the Texas Futile Care
>Law.
>
>Under this law, a baby was removed from life support
>against his mother's wishes in Texas just this week. A
>68 year old man was given a temporary reprieve by the
>Texas courts just yesterday.
>
>Were you aware that Republicans have voted en masse to
>pull the plug (no pun intended) on Medicaid funding
>that pays for the kind of care that someone like Terry
>Schiavo and many others who are not so severely brain
>damaged need all across this country?
>
>Were you aware that the tort reform that is being
>contemplated by the Republican congress would preclude
>malpractice claims like that which has paid for Terry
>Schiavo's care thus far?
>
>Were you aware that the bankruptcy bill will make it
>even more difficult for families who suffer a
>catastrophic illness like Terry Schiavo's because they
>will not be able to declare chapter 7 bankruptcy and
>get a fresh start when the gargantuan medical bills
>become overwhelming?
>
>Were you aware that this grandstanding by the congress
>is a purely political move designed to appease the
>religious right and that the legal maneuverings being
>employed would be anathema to any true small government
>conservative? (See the now infamous memo circulated to
>GOP House & Senate members...)
>
>We are now seeing a spectacle on television in which
>the news anchors repeatedly say that the congress is
>"stepping in to save Terry Schiavo" mimicking the
>unctuous words of Tom Delay as they grovel and leer at
>the family and nod sympathetically at the sanctimonious
>opportunists who are using this issue for their
>political gain.
>
>This is why it's become so difficult to trust the
>mainstream media. Most people get their news from
>television. And television is presenting this issue as
>a round the clock one dimensional soap opera pitting
>the "family", the congress and the church against this
>woman's husband and the judicial system that upheld
>Terry Schiavo's right and explicit request that she be
>allowed to die if extraordinary means were required to
>keep her alive. The ghoulish infotainment industry is
>making a killing by acceding once again to trumped up
>right wing hypocrisy.
>
>What Americans think:
>
>ABC News (PDF). 3/20. MoE 4.5% (No trend lines.)
>Removal of feeding tube
>
>Support 63
>Oppose28
>
>Federal Intervention
>
>Support 35
>Oppose 60
>
>Appropriate for Congress to get involved?
>
>Appropriate 27
>Not Appropriate 70
>
>Reason political leaders are trying to keep Shiavo
>alive
>
>Concern about Shiavo 19
>Political Advantage 67
>

At 08:48 PM 3/31/2005, Karina wrote:
>Spirit of Raving Question: How do you define Community?

Community...or Come-Unity...seems to be becoming an ever more elusive 
experience lately in the nightlife business.  Recently I have been 
rereading Hunter S. Thompson's "Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas"  -- last 
read was when it was published.

This excerpt is an excellent description of "community" in my humble opinion:

"...it seems entirely reasonable to think that every now and then the 
energy of a whole generation comes to a head in a long fine flash, for 
reasons that nobody really understands at the time­and which never explain, 
in retrospect, what actually happened.

My central memory of that time (the mid-sixties in SF) seems to hang on one 
or five or maybe forty nights­or very early mornings­when I left the 
Fillmore half-crazy and, instead of going home, aimed the big 650 Lightning 
across the Bay Bridge at a hundred miles an hour wearing L. L. Bean shorts 
and a Butte sheepherder's jacket . . . booming through the Treasure Island 
tunnel at the lights of Oakland and Berkeley and Richmond, not quite sure 
which turn-off to take when I got to the other end (always stalling at the 
toll-gate, too twisted to find neutral while I fumbled for change) . . but 
being absolutely certain that no matter which way I went I would come to a 
place where people were just as high and wild as I was: No doubt at all 
about that. . . .

There was madness in any direction, at any hour. If not across the Bay, 
then up the Golden Gate or down 101 to Los Altos or La Honda. . . . You 
could strike sparks anywhere. There was a fantastic universal sense that 
whatever we were doing was right, that we were winning... .

And that, I think, was the handle­that sense of inevitable victory over the 
forces of Old and Evil. Not in any mean or military sense; we didn't need 
that. Our energy would simply prevail. There was no point in fighting­on 
our side or theirs. We had all the momentum; we were riding the crest of a 
high and beautiful wave... .

So now...you can go up on a steep hill...and look West, and with the right 
kind of eyes you can almost see the high-water mark­that place where the 
wave finally broke and rolled back."

Love,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_4705215==.ALT--

> At 11:22 AM 4/1/2005, Apollo wrote:
> 
> >At 09:09 AM 4/1/2005, Chester Copperpot wrote:
> >>Ok i'm tired of hearing about this stupid Terri Schiavo crap.  Why's
> >>everyone gotta have their panties crammed up their butts over this one
> >>stupid girl.  There are probably a few hundred of people in very
> >>similar situations, but you dont hear crap from them or their
> >>families.  Why get so worked up over this one?  I dont get it.  It's
> >>stupid and retard, just like she was.
> >
> >
> >
> >Whatever your personal beliefs are concerning Terry
> >Schiavo...
> >
> >Were you aware that George W. Bush signed a law in
> >Texas that expressly gave hospitals the right to remove
> >life support if the patient could not pay and there was
> >no hope of revival, regardless of the patient's
> >family's wishes? It is called the Texas Futile Care
> >Law.
> >
> >Under this law, a baby was removed from life support
> >against his mother's wishes in Texas just this week. A
> >68 year old man was given a temporary reprieve by the
> >Texas courts just yesterday.
> >
> >Were you aware that Republicans have voted en masse to
> >pull the plug (no pun intended) on Medicaid funding
> >that pays for the kind of care that someone like Terry
> >Schiavo and many others who are not so severely brain
> >damaged need all across this country?
> >
> >Were you aware that the tort reform that is being
> >contemplated by the Republican congress would preclude
> >malpractice claims like that which has paid for Terry
> >Schiavo's care thus far?
> >
> >Were you aware that the bankruptcy bill will make it
> >even more difficult for families who suffer a
> >catastrophic illness like Terry Schiavo's because they
> >will not be able to declare chapter 7 bankruptcy and
> >get a fresh start when the gargantuan medical bills
> >become overwhelming?
> >
> >Were you aware that this grandstanding by the congress
> >is a purely political move designed to appease the
> >religious right and that the legal maneuverings being
> >employed would be anathema to any true small government
> >conservative? (See the now infamous memo circulated to
> >GOP House & Senate members...)
> >
> >We are now seeing a spectacle on television in which
> >the news anchors repeatedly say that the congress is
> >"stepping in to save Terry Schiavo" mimicking the
> >unctuous words of Tom Delay as they grovel and leer at
> >the family and nod sympathetically at the sanctimonious
> >opportunists who are using this issue for their
> >political gain.
> >
> >This is why it's become so difficult to trust the
> >mainstream media. Most people get their news from
> >television. And television is presenting this issue as
> >a round the clock one dimensional soap opera pitting
> >the "family", the congress and the church against this
> >woman's husband and the judicial system that upheld
> >Terry Schiavo's right and explicit request that she be
> >allowed to die if extraordinary means were required to
> >keep her alive. The ghoulish infotainment industry is
> >making a killing by acceding once again to trumped up
> >right wing hypocrisy.
> >

> >
> >ABC News (PDF). 3/20. MoE 4.5% (No trend lines.)
> >Removal of feeding tube
> >
> >Support 63
> >Oppose28
> >
> >Federal Intervention
> >
> >Support 35
> >Oppose 60
> >
> >Appropriate for Congress to get involved?
> >
> >Appropriate 27
> >Not Appropriate 70

> >alive

Subject: [sfraves] [NRR] Papal Reform

Ok, so the Pope is dead, it's time to reform.  We need a new
direction, a new vision, a new kick in the pants to push us into the
21st century with a full head of steam.

I think the best way to do that would be to vote me for the Papal
seat.  Who better for that position than me?  A man of great wisdom
and charity.  I may not be a priest of Catholicism or any religion
other than my own for that matter.  Why do we need such a rule like
that.  I've been clean and celebate and true to myself my whole life,
I'm a perfect canidate.  According to some predictions, there's only 2
seats in the Papal office left.  Help make me one of them.  Put your
trust and faith into me and cast your ballot.  Rush to you local
priest or cardinal and submit my name for candidacy.  I shall not let
you down.

Vote for Pope Chester I "The Great Molester"
-- 
Chester Copperpot

"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
"I feel like I'm taking crazy pills"

Did i disrespect the dead?  where?  when?  I dont recall saying
anything about anyone dead, except for where i said

> "Ok, so the Pope is dead, it's time to reform."

How's that disrespecting the dead?  Did i walk over to his limp
lifeless body and teabag his chin?  or take a dump in his Papal Hat
next to his deathbed?  i don't recall any of that, i guess it could
have happened in a drunken stupor, but i doubt that cause i havent
been in any lately.

So if you could please point out the disrespect, I'd appreciate it. 
If it truely was disrespect, maybe you all will get lucky and hear an
apology out of me, but seeing as how i dont see any disrespect i guess
you all will just have to keep holding your breath.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [NRR] Papal Reform

It's not like the cardinals arent doing the same thing, they're going
about trying to figure out who's next.  They do that everytime they
confirm the pope is dead....start figuring out who's gonna be next,
cause the world will fall apart if there isnt a pope to lead the
sheep.

I fail to see the callousness of that sentence, and if people do take
it as disrepectful and callous, then they need to take their finger
and jam them far, far, far up their ass and pull those pretty pink
panties they have all bunched up in there out, maybe then they'll be
able to relax a little.

Most religions/governments all do the same thing, once the current
seat of power is opened, they worry about getting it filled back in. 
It helps restore "order" and bring peace to their pathetic little
lives, cause with out someone one to tell them what to do, what will
they do...it's maddening, the world will spin off it's axis and we'll
all die in the firey glow which we call our sun.  It's not callous and
anyone who thinks that, is retarded just like terri schiavo was.

Chester Copperpot

In our quest to play for everyone on the planet, the next two live skylab2000 shows are outside the US! 

This Friday, April 8th, skylab2000 will be in Juarez MEXICO, at Club Bardu. [http://www.elbardu.com] Right after that, (May 4th), we will be in Nagasaki, JAPAN to play at an outdoor festival. [http://www.i-feel-love.com]

There are still some summer dates open for skylab2000, so if you do a club or event, please contact us. Easy to have skylab2000 play at your event!

Thanks!

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Oral sex 'is best'  !!!

--=====================_7985632==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


Oral sex 'is best'  !!!


Washington - US teenagers apparently prefer oral sex as a safer and morally 
more acceptable alternative to intercourse, a possible explanation for 
their rare use of condoms, according to a small poll by the University of 
California.

Around 20% of the ethnically diverse 580 teenagers - 42% boys, 58% girls 
with a mean age of 14 - who answered a questionnaire in the study published 
on Monday, admitted having had oral sex, compared to 14% who had had 
intercourse.

In addition, one third of the survey group said they intended to experiment 
with oral sex in the following six months, said the medical researchers 
headed by University of California paediatrics professor Bonnie 
Halpern-Felsher.

The teenagers in the survey said they preferred oral sex because they 
believed it carried "significantly less risk" than intercourse in terms of 
its health, social and emotional consequences, according to the study.

This perception would explain why condom use among teenagers is so rare, 
the researchers said.

Although the risk of contracting sexually transmitted diseases, including 
Aids, is considerably lower with oral sex as opposed to regular sexual 
relations, young people too often underestimate it, said the study 
published in the latest issue of Paediatrics.

world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

--=====================_10875418==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed



* Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu *

Japanese American civil rights pioneer Fred Korematsu has died at the age of
86. He was jailed during World War II refusing orders to be sent to an
internment camp set up for U.S residents of Japanese ancestry. We air an
excerpt of the documentary, "Of Civil Rights and Wrongs: The Fred Korematsu
Story" and we speak with one of his attorneys.

Listen/Watch/Read
http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=05/04/05/1334210

From: Bam <invibe@gmail.com>

References: <6.2.1.2.2.20050405164055.029a7ea8@localhost>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu

i was a little dissappointed that the Korematsu's passing wasn't given
more attention considering the impact that his original case and the
retributions had on our nation.  the original 1942 Korematsu vs.
United States is widely referenced to in all legal textbooks.  the
1982 case overturned the original ruling, which ultimately led to the
US government apologizing and admitting they were wrong for
imprisoning 120,000+ persons of Japanese ancestry during WWII.

His story is a very interesting one, even more so for me since my
entire family was sent to internment camps.

though it happened over 60 years ago, the recent climate towards
people of middle eastern decent is really not that much different than
how Japanese and Japanese Americans were treated during WWII.  How
easily we forget history...

-B

On Apr 5, 2005 4:41 PM, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> 
> 
> * Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu *
> 
> Japanese American civil rights pioneer Fred Korematsu has died at the age of
> 86. He was jailed during World War II refusing orders to be sent to an
> internment camp set up for U.S residents of Japanese ancestry. We air an
> excerpt of the documentary, "Of Civil Rights and Wrongs: The Fred Korematsu
> Story" and we speak with one of his attorneys.
> 
> Listen/Watch/Read
> http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=05/04/05/1334210
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> 
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> 
> The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the
> money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the
> world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
> -Hunter S. Thompson
> 
> "Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience
> while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before
> death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think
> ghosts will do it after?"
> -Kabir
> 
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
> 
>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu

Not to discredit American's of Japanese decent and their struggles and
mistreatment in a dark day in American history, and also not to troll...

But really some one should make a movie about the rape of Nanking. I
find it sad that a lot of younger people today are more aware of the
imprisoning of Americans of Japanese decent then the atrocities
committed by the Japanese army during WW2.

Same with the Abu Gahrab(sp?) prison scandals, In the future are people
going to only remember the negative things done by a few stupid soldiers
or are they going to remember all the people that got their heads cut
off with butter knives by the terrorists while screaming "god is great"?

Seriously, this is not a troll post. Just trying to converse and hear
viewpoints.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu

you know what, fuck you for making a connection between what happend
to Japanese Americans and what the Japanese military did in China.

that's right, fuck you.  it's that same attitude that made it possible
for Americans to think it was okay to throw 120,000 people behind
barbed wire fences because of their ethnic background.  not because of
crimes they committed.

fuck you.

of the 120,000 people interned, do you realize that over 2/3 were
American citizens?  citizens that should have been protected by
constitutional rights and our judicial system.  these were not
Japanese nationals.  these were people born and raised on US soil who
had never even been to Japan.

these were not the people that bombed Pearl Harbor.  these were not
the people that invaded China.

you are making some sort of weak connection between Japanese American
Internament and the actions of the Japanese military.  which is the
same thing that the US military and government and the people did
during WWII.

let's point the finger at the other guy and say "hey what they did was
worse."  and hey, we imprisoned 120,000 people without due process and
robbed them of their land and property but you know what.....some
people across the ocean who have slanty eyes like them and eat with
chopsticks like them, they did something worse.

fuck you.

-B

> Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights
> Pioneer Fred Korematsu
> 
> You should see the documentary "Rabbit in the Moon". It was produced in
> Berkeley and discusses the families that were in the internment camps
> during WWII. Powerful and touching film...
> 
> -tim
> 
> Bam wrote:
> 
> >i was a little dissappointed that the Korematsu's passing wasn't given
> >more attention considering the impact that his original case and the
> >retributions had on our nation.  the original 1942 Korematsu vs.
> >United States is widely referenced to in all legal textbooks.  the
> >1982 case overturned the original ruling, which ultimately led to the
> >US government apologizing and admitting they were wrong for
> >imprisoning 120,000+ persons of Japanese ancestry during WWII.
> >
> >His story is a very interesting one, even more so for me since my
> >entire family was sent to internment camps.
> >
> >though it happened over 60 years ago, the recent climate towards
> >people of middle eastern decent is really not that much different than
> >how Japanese and Japanese Americans were treated during WWII.  How
> >easily we forget history...
> >
> >-B
> >
> >On Apr 5, 2005 4:41 PM, Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> >
> >
> >>* Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu *
> >>
> >>Japanese American civil rights pioneer Fred Korematsu has died at the
> age of
> >>86. He was jailed during World War II refusing orders to be sent to an
> >>internment camp set up for U.S residents of Japanese ancestry. We air
> an
> >>excerpt of the documentary, "Of Civil Rights and Wrongs: The Fred
> Korematsu
> >>Story" and we speak with one of his attorneys.
> >>
> >>Listen/Watch/Read
> >>http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=05/04/05/1334210
> >>
> >>Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> >>
> >>House Music 101:
> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> >>
> >>The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the
> >>money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in
> the
> >>world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
> >>-Hunter S. Thompson
> >>
> >>"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience
> >>while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time
> before
> >>death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you
> think
> >>ghosts will do it after?"
> >>-Kabir
> >>

Pioneer Fred Korematsu

you know what, fuck you for making a connection between what happend
to Japanese Americans and what the Japanese military did in China.

>I wasn't making a connection except for the fact that it has to do with
>WW2, I was just bringing up the point that it's insane that we
concentrate >so much on small mistakes (in comparison) we've made while
much bigger >mistakes have been made by others.

that's right, fuck you.  it's that same attitude that made it possible
for Americans to think it was okay to throw 120,000 people behind
barbed wire fences because of their ethnic background.  not because of
crimes they committed.

>No, I don't think so. The attitude that lead to the Americans of
Japanese >decent being put in prison was one of FEAR and the fact that
spying and >espionage was big in that time period.

fuck you.

>I will later when I'm at home.

of the 120,000 people interned, do you realize that over 2/3 were
American citizens? =20

>Duh, yeah and I'm also aware of the fact that the Americans of Japanese
decent immigrated a long time before WW2 into the United States. Most of
them even came before the Chinese.=20

citizens that should have been protected by
constitutional rights and our judicial system.  these were not
Japanese nationals.  these were people born and raised on US soil who
had never even been to Japan.

>um yep. Learned it in school in 5th grade and again in 9th grade.

these were not the people that bombed Pearl Harbor.  these were not
the people that invaded China.

>Duh.

you are making some sort of weak connection between Japanese American
Internament and the actions of the Japanese military.  which is the
same thing that the US military and government and the people did
during WWII.

>Nope.


let's point the finger at the other guy and say "hey what they did was
worse."  and hey, we imprisoned 120,000 people without due process and
robbed them of their land and property but you know what.....some
people across the ocean who have slanty eyes like them and eat with
chopsticks like them, they did something worse.

>not what I said. Come on, think a little more complex then that!

fuck you.

>Again, later today in private I will.

-B

>-SO

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korem

My major gripe with our country is the overwhelming amount of blind 
allegiance people give it. As if the USA could do no wrong. Nevermind that 
we robbed the Native American people's of the land they inhabited LONG 
before the white man ever showed up. Never mind all the slavery of African's 
and the resulting social caste system. Nevermind the internment of Japanese 
Americans, or the war in Iraq, or Vietnam, or the Iran-Contra scandal, or 
the fact that there are thousands of "alleged" terrorists hanging out in 
Guantanamo for supposedly having terrorist ties that no one can seem to 
prove. Fuck due process and the Constitution and the rights that come from 
it. We're the US of A! "god's" chosen people! right?

Sick and sad.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu

I think the point that's trying to come across here is that a sense of
rightousness fuels acts of indecency on fellow human beings.Wether in
the instance of the American, German, and Japanese govs during WW2,
the recent beheading-happy terrorists, or any of the other thousands
of sensless violent acts which have been commited on innocent people
during times of war, it just goes to show that people in power often
lose their sense of consciousness and humanitarian responsibility.
It's sad and upsetting, but nothing new. I mean, fuck. Look at the
crusades. Unjustified fear-based persecution all over. So sad....

To: Steve Osteen <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>

In-Reply-To: <340D5A031E64C2468AF37960805A37450229D96C@us1-mail16.pcle.com>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu

> >I wasn't making a connection except for the fact that it has to do with
> >WW2, I was just bringing up the point that it's insane that we
> concentrate >so much on small mistakes (in comparison) we've made while
> much bigger >mistakes have been made by others.

well, here's my point.  we can't control what the other guys do.  if
what other people do really pisses us off, we can just invade their
country.  however, we do have control over what we do in our own
country and what we do to our own citizens.  the issue of Japanese
Internment is an issue of civil rights.  was it okay for the US
government to deny American citizens of their civil rights based
solely on their ethnic background?

> >No, I don't think so. The attitude that lead to the Americans of
> Japanese >decent being put in prison was one of FEAR and the fact that
> spying and >espionage was big in that time period.

for the record, there was not ONE recorded case of spying nor
espionage by any Japanese Americans before or during the war.  people
of Japanese ancestry in American were viewed as disloyal foreigners
but there was absolutely no evidence of this.  no evidence, no cases
of espionage, but they looked like the enemy and therefore were
treated as such.

> these were not the people that bombed Pearl Harbor.  these were not
> the people that invaded China.
> 
> >Duh.
> 
> you are making some sort of weak connection between Japanese American
> Internament and the actions of the Japanese military.  which is the
> same thing that the US military and government and the people did
> during WWII.
> 
> >Nope.


but still, you hear the words "WWII" and "Japanese" in a conversation
about the civil rights issues surrounding Japanese American Internment
and it reminds you that the Japanese military invaded China and killed
alot of Chinese people?  what's the connection?  are we talking war
crimes?  what the Japanese military did in China is a war crime.  what
the US government did to Japanese Americans is a legal issue of civil
rights and due process.  of course, this was prompted by the events of
WWII, but the issues affect all Americans regardless of ethnicty.

Executive Order 9066, which was used to enforce internment, did not
specifically single out people according to ethnic background.  it
gave the US military the right to remove any and all persons from any
region for whatever reason.

had the Korematsu case not been overturned, the original Korematsu vs.
United States would have still been on the books.   this is the
importance of the case as it applies to ALL Americans and people
living in America.  that you could be taken from your home and
imprisoned without trial and without evidence because the military
views you as a threat.

so here's my point.  the Rape of Nanking was a terrible atrocity.  and
you're right, there isn't much out there regarding that time period in
that region.  Iris Chang's "The Rape of Nanking" is probably the most
influential text on the subject but it wasn't published until the late
90s.  but that was something that was committed by a government other
than our own and was committed on soil other than our own.

Japanese American internment was committed by OUR government on OUR
soil and to OUR people

--

Subject: [sfraves] RE: [SPAM] Re: [sfraves] NRR: Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu

My comments below...

-----Original Message-----
From: Bam [mailto:invibe@gmail.com]=20
Sent: Wednesday, April 06, 2005 12:12 PM
To: Steve Osteen
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [SPAM] Re: [sfraves] NRR: Remembering Japanese American Civil
Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu
Importance: Low

> >I wasn't making a connection except for the fact that it has to do
with
> >WW2, I was just bringing up the point that it's insane that we
> concentrate >so much on small mistakes (in comparison) we've made
while
> much bigger >mistakes have been made by others.

well, here's my point.  we can't control what the other guys do.  if
what other people do really pisses us off, we can just invade their
country.  however, we do have control over what we do in our own
country and what we do to our own citizens.  the issue of Japanese
Internment is an issue of civil rights.  was it okay for the US
government to deny American citizens of their civil rights based
solely on their ethnic background?

>>No and I agree with what you are saying.

> >No, I don't think so. The attitude that lead to the Americans of
> Japanese >decent being put in prison was one of FEAR and the fact that
> spying and >espionage was big in that time period.

for the record, there was not ONE recorded case of spying nor
espionage by any Japanese Americans before or during the war.  people
of Japanese ancestry in American were viewed as disloyal foreigners
but there was absolutely no evidence of this.  no evidence, no cases
of espionage, but they looked like the enemy and therefore were
treated as such.

>> Maybe not by Japanese American's, but by Japanese living in the US.
The fact is, Spying was a new concept in the times of WW2 and thus the
fear of it was huge, just like how we fear a dirty bomb here now.

> these were not the people that bombed Pearl Harbor.  these were not
> the people that invaded China.
>=20
> >Duh.
>=20
> you are making some sort of weak connection between Japanese American
> Internament and the actions of the Japanese military.  which is the
> same thing that the US military and government and the people did
> during WWII.
>=20
> >Nope.


but still, you hear the words "WWII" and "Japanese" in a conversation
about the civil rights issues surrounding Japanese American Internment
and it reminds you that the Japanese military invaded China and killed
alot of Chinese people?  what's the connection?  are we talking war
crimes?  what the Japanese military did in China is a war crime.  what
the US government did to Japanese Americans is a legal issue of civil
rights and due process.  of course, this was prompted by the events of
WWII, but the issues affect all Americans regardless of ethnicty.

>> Ok, true, but I was trying to make the point that we seem to
concentrate on the wrong things.

Executive Order 9066, which was used to enforce internment, did not
specifically single out people according to ethnic background.  it
gave the US military the right to remove any and all persons from any
region for whatever reason.

had the Korematsu case not been overturned, the original Korematsu vs.
United States would have still been on the books.   this is the
importance of the case as it applies to ALL Americans and people
living in America.  that you could be taken from your home and
imprisoned without trial and without evidence because the military
views you as a threat.

so here's my point.  the Rape of Nanking was a terrible atrocity.  and
you're right, there isn't much out there regarding that time period in
that region.  Iris Chang's "The Rape of Nanking" is probably the most
influential text on the subject but it wasn't published until the late
90s.  but that was something that was committed by a government other
than our own and was committed on soil other than our own.

Japanese American internment was committed by OUR government on OUR
soil and to OUR people

>> Very true, and thanks for giving me that viewpoint, I hope you can
consider mine.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: [SPAM] Re: [sfraves] NRR: Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu

> for the record, there was not ONE recorded case of spying nor
> espionage by any Japanese Americans before or during the war.  people
> of Japanese ancestry in American were viewed as disloyal foreigners
> but there was absolutely no evidence of this.  no evidence, no cases
> of espionage, but they looked like the enemy and therefore were
> treated as such.
> 
> >> Maybe not by Japanese American's, but by Japanese living in the US.
> The fact is, Spying was a new concept in the times of WW2 and thus the
> fear of it was huge, just like how we fear a dirty bomb here now.

actually, this is also untrue and has been widely referred to as an
arguement against the military neccesity of internment.

http://www.pbs.org/childofcamp/history/
"At the time, Executive Order 9066 was justified as a "military
necessity" to protect against domestic espionage and sabotage.
However, it was later documented that "our government had in its
possession proof that not one Japanese American, citizen or not, had
engaged in espionage, not one had committed any act of sabotage."
(Michi Weglyn, 1976)."


> >> Ok, true, but I was trying to make the point that we seem to
> concentrate on the wrong things.

i would still disagree that concentrating on acts by our own
government in which citizens are robbed of their civil rights is
wrong.  even in comparison with immoral or violent acts committed by
other nations in other countries.

in the case of internment, it wasn't just a handful of people.  not a
group of individuals.  it was EVERYONE in the western united states
who was of a certain ethnicity.  they were uprooted at a moments
notice.  could only take what they could carry.  they lost property
and their livelyhoods.  there were first forced to live in horse
stables while the camps were being built.  then forced into camps
behind barbed wire in some of the least hospitable regions of our
country.

> >> Very true, and thanks for giving me that viewpoint, I hope you can
> consider mine.

and i think i understand your  viewpoint.  but i still will stand by
my perspective that we, as a nation, should hold ourselves to the
highest standards of our own laws if we are to continue to say that we
are a free nation and try to enforce our own moral and ethic code to
other nations.

otherwise we are hypocrits and have no base for expecting other
sovereign nations to respect us.

--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu

Ok this isnt to be taken badly or derogatory or anything ok?  I just
thought i'd toss it out, my ex girlfriend always referred to Japanese
American's (Herself included) as Cracker Japs and  It's always kinda
stuck with me, cause it's kinda cleaver and witty with a lil fun
poking , but i wanted to see how the rest of you felt about that?  Do
you feel that's just a cute coin phrase or do you feel it's more of a
derogatory term?  I've always felt it was the prior rather then the
latter, but i can see how people can see it that way,  I never thought
it was that bad since she was Japanese/American and she called it
herself, but then again i guess a lot of black people call themselves
niggers (among themselves in conversation or like in Rap music where
it's out there for the masses), but if someone else were to say it
they would be looked down upon.

Feel free to give your insight, flame, poo throwing...whatever I can
take it.  Just wanted to see what others thought, since so far as i've
found i havent come across anyone else who had ever heard or used that
term before.


-- 
Chester Copperpot

"Goonies never say die!"
"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
"I feel like I'm taking crazy pills"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu

no, it's derogatory but not in the way i think most people would interpret it.

i would say that Japanese Americans that experienced internment and
the generations after them ahd some seriously complicted and fucked up
issues.  let's take a second generation JA born in the US but before
internment:

you grow up with your parents who speak Japanese and tell you good
stories of thier past in Japan.  you eat Japanese food at home and
practice some of the cultural customs.  but outside of your home
everything is American.  you grew up speaking English and go to school
with kids of all ethnic backgrounds.  you're just one of the
guys/girls.  you love America and recite the pledge of allegiance
everyday.  you learn about freedom and how great America is.

then war breaks out.  the country your parents were raised in has
attacked the country that you were raised in.  then the country you
were raised in tells you that you'rea a threat to national security
because of what was done by a country that you've never been to, and
yet have a cultural connection to.  people on the street call you a
"dirty Jap" and spit on you.  your friends and neighbors who used to
welcome you into their homes now look at your with spite and say
"you're not an american."

then you get taken from your home and get dropped at a race track
where you live in a horse stable.  the smell of shit surrounds you. 
your once proud parents don't talk anymore and don't smile.   you bath
and wash your clothes in a trough meant for animals.  then you get
trucked off into the desert.  you're surrounded by barbed wire.  some
people say it's for "your own protection" but the machine guns in the
towers point inward, not outward.

years go by and the war is over and you can go back home.  but you
don't want to go back home cause you've got nothing left there.  you
don't want to indentify with anything Japanese cause that's what got
you locked up in the first place.  but your parents still speak
japanese and eat japanese food at home.  so you disassociate yourself
from them.  you go off and try to be as american as possible, but you
can't deny the fact that you have some fond memories of the customs
that you were raised with.

you grow up and get married.  maybe to another JA, maybe not.  you
have kids.  what do you teach your kids?  about the fact that the
country you are trying to teach them is best in the world locked you
and grandpa and grandma up for being japanese?

doh, meeting time at work.  yeah, i'm supposed to be working.

more on this later.  or not.  isn't this a rave list?

On Apr 6, 2005 2:44 PM, Chester Copperpot
<chester.copperpot420@gmail.com> wrote:
> Ok this isnt to be taken badly or derogatory or anything ok?  I just
> thought i'd toss it out, my ex girlfriend always referred to Japanese
> American's (Herself included) as Cracker Japs and  It's always kinda
> stuck with me, cause it's kinda cleaver and witty with a lil fun
> poking , but i wanted to see how the rest of you felt about that?  Do
> you feel that's just a cute coin phrase or do you feel it's more of a
> derogatory term?  I've always felt it was the prior rather then the
> latter, but i can see how people can see it that way,  I never thought
> it was that bad since she was Japanese/American and she called it
> herself, but then again i guess a lot of black people call themselves
> niggers (among themselves in conversation or like in Rap music where
> it's out there for the masses), but if someone else were to say it
> they would be looked down upon.
> 
> Feel free to give your insight, flame, poo throwing...whatever I can
> take it.  Just wanted to see what others thought, since so far as i've
> found i havent come across anyone else who had ever heard or used that
> term before.
>

On Apr 6, 2005 3:00 PM, Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:
> no, it's derogatory but not in the way i think most people would interpret it.
> 
> i would say that Japanese Americans that experienced internment and
> the generations after them ahd some seriously complicted and fucked up
> issues.  let's take a second generation JA born in the US but before
> internment:
> 
> you grow up with your parents who speak Japanese and tell you good
> stories of thier past in Japan.  you eat Japanese food at home and
> practice some of the cultural customs.  but outside of your home
> everything is American.  you grew up speaking English and go to school
> with kids of all ethnic backgrounds.  you're just one of the
> guys/girls.  you love America and recite the pledge of allegiance
> everyday.  you learn about freedom and how great America is.
> 
> then war breaks out.  the country your parents were raised in has
> attacked the country that you were raised in.  then the country you
> were raised in tells you that you'rea a threat to national security
> because of what was done by a country that you've never been to, and
> yet have a cultural connection to.  people on the street call you a
> "dirty Jap" and spit on you.  your friends and neighbors who used to
> welcome you into their homes now look at your with spite and say
> "you're not an american."
> 
> then you get taken from your home and get dropped at a race track
> where you live in a horse stable.  the smell of shit surrounds you.
> your once proud parents don't talk anymore and don't smile.   you bath
> and wash your clothes in a trough meant for animals.  then you get
> trucked off into the desert.  you're surrounded by barbed wire.  some
> people say it's for "your own protection" but the machine guns in the
> towers point inward, not outward.
> 
> years go by and the war is over and you can go back home.  but you
> don't want to go back home cause you've got nothing left there.  you
> don't want to indentify with anything Japanese cause that's what got
> you locked up in the first place.  but your parents still speak
> japanese and eat japanese food at home.  so you disassociate yourself
> from them.  you go off and try to be as american as possible, but you
> can't deny the fact that you have some fond memories of the customs
> that you were raised with.
> 
> you grow up and get married.  maybe to another JA, maybe not.  you
> have kids.  what do you teach your kids?  about the fact that the
> country you are trying to teach them is best in the world locked you
> and grandpa and grandma up for being japanese?
> 
> doh, meeting time at work.  yeah, i'm supposed to be working.
> 
> more on this later.  or not.  isn't this a rave list?
>

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Satellite picture of where I live

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

As some of you may have heard, Google has a mapping service available in 
Beta.  One can view both a map and directions to a location as well as a 
satellite view (look on the upper right hand side of the map and click on 
"satellite."

I thought it might be cool if we exchanged satellite views of our homes.


Here's a link to the map and satellite picture of where I 
live:  http://maps.google.com/maps?q=1496+La+Playa+Street,San+Francisco

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

>there?   some homies from Hawaii?  do JAs just not like raving?  not
>into the music?

Yes, I sympathize Bam.  I'm a Polish American (PA) and when I moved to SF 
in the eighties I thought I was the only PA in the City, let alone the 
"nightlife" scene.  Then I  met Andy W :-)  But that was after living here 
over as a lonely Pole for over a decade.  Takes time.

I'm going to go eat some kiska...by myself.  Andy doesn't eat it anymore :-(

Love,

Apollo

in the eighties I thought I was the only PA in the City, let alone the=20
"nightlife" scene.  Then I  met Andy W :-)  But that was after living
here=20
over as a lonely Pole for over a decade.  Takes time.

I'm going to go eat some kiska...by myself.  Andy doesn't eat it anymore
:-(

Love,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the=20
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in
the=20
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience=20
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time
before=20
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think=20
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually
become=20
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Remembering Japanese American Civil Rights Pioneer Fred Korematsu

I ran into a good-sized cluster of Japanese ravers at Little SciFi.  I 
spotted a couple of them again at Bubblegum SciFi, but it was too damn 
crowded to make it over and say hi (WAY overcrowded...  First time I 
ever actually left a Skills party significantly early, it was so 
crowded.  Probably the last time I'm gonna set foot in the Blue Cube, 
for the same reason.).

So far as the rest of the thread goes, I'm with you 100%.  I'm gonna 
refrain from throwing in any further, as I'll just wind up launching 
into a long bitchy rant about how extra-double-super-loathsome certain 
people are, for trying to blame the present generation of Japanese for 
the tragedies brought about by some old, mostly dead now, Japanese 
soldiers during WWII.  And no one wants to read that, I'm sure.

I mean... for fucks sake...  I'm half Italian, on my father's side.  
And I have (non-living) relatives who fought in the Italian army during 
WWII.  Yes, on the same side as HITLER  (Oooooo...).  Does that make ME 
a fascist?  Does that make ME responsible for Auschwitz?  Not a chance. 
  So for anyone to bring up nanking with today's generation of Japanese 
is just totally and entirely despicable, and would seem, to me, to 
indicate a latent (or not-so-latent) racism.


cya,
john

From sfraves-return-120502-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Apr 07 16:16:08 2005

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 77642 invoked by uid 1103); 7 Apr 2005 16:16:08 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 77626 invoked from network); 7 Apr 2005 16:16:07 -0000
Message-ID: <1112890565.42555cc5d5db7@webmail.deepfog.com>
Date: Thu,  7 Apr 2005 12:16:05 -0400
From: Deepfog <sfgroove@deepfog.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
User-Agent: Internet Messaging Program (IMP) 3.2.3
X-Originating-IP: 205.56.129.102
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Thu)

i just got done reading philip k. dick's "lies, inc.".  this is an interesting
book, because it was originally written in the 1960's and published as "the
unteleported man".

dick wrote and wanted to publish an expansion of the book at the time, but the
publisher didn't like the expansion.  then in the late 70's, he found another
publisher to agree to publish the book with the expansion.  the only problem
was he couldn't find 4 pages of the original book so he rewrote the beginning
and ending to make it all fit together.  then he died in 1982, and the person
managing his writings found the 4 pages and published the book, with the
expansion, under the new name "lies, inc."  that dick intended.

the book without the expansion is very much like a twilight zone episode.  the
expansion is very abstract and psychedelic.  i can see why the publisher would
have thought it too weird but it does add to the story.

and finally, after about 6 different people told me i should, i'm reading snow
crash.  very funny and outlandish adventure book.  what are you reading?  let
me or us know!

--

After another moment's silence, she mumbled that I was peculiar, that that was
probably why she loved me but that one day I might disgust her for the very
same reason.

 Albert Camus, L'Etranger

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <1112890565.42555cc5d5db7@webmail.deepfog.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.5.6+20040907i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Thu)



Finished "Brass" recently.  If you like Irving Welsh (Trainspotting, ect..)
you should like Brass.  Total smut though... about 7 sex encounters as
graphic as anything you would read on the internet.  Not just sex.. but dirty
dirrrrty sex.  We yanks just can't get enough of those clubbing, drugging, 
shagging british youth.  Only thing, though... I could not quite get the
girl's modivation for her reckless sex cravings.  Almost like the sex
scenes were pasted in over the story to help sell books.  Worked for
a sucker like me, though.

I found "Plan of Attack" facinating becuase I was really following the
news with the buildup to the Iraq war.  This book takes you behind the
scenes to see what was really happening behind the headlines.  I really 
loved the description of the CIA infiltrating northern Iraq.  A team of 
8 CIA and special forces guys driving into Iraq on bumpy trails in just 2
trucks... with 18 million dollars in $100 bills for payoffs.  You can
see why both pro- and anti- war people like this book.. it actually 
softened my hatred of Bush.  The real person to blame for the Iraq mess?
Rumsfeld.  

Currently reading "Cloud Atlas".  Seven seperate stories linked together
in a mysterious way.  Great writing.. but you have to be able to re-enage
with those 7 different stories and sets of characters.  Very interesting.
I have a friend who is totally fanatical about this book, and he can't
wait for me to finish so he can have someone to discuss it with. 

Phillip K. Dick is always a fun read.  His whole worldview is that reality
is never solid.. but constanty shifting and flipping around and inversing.
My favorite is "Flow My Tears, The Policeman Said".  Not as far-out as
his stuff like Valis.  

-troy


On Thu, Apr 07, 2005 at 12:16:05PM -0400, Deepfog wrote:
> i just got done reading philip k. dick's "lies, inc.".  this is an interesting
> book, because it was originally written in the 1960's and published as "the
> unteleported man".
> 
> dick wrote and wanted to publish an expansion of the book at the time, but the
> publisher didn't like the expansion.  then in the late 70's, he found another
> publisher to agree to publish the book with the expansion.  the only problem
> was he couldn't find 4 pages of the original book so he rewrote the beginning
> and ending to make it all fit together.  then he died in 1982, and the person
> managing his writings found the 4 pages and published the book, with the
> expansion, under the new name "lies, inc."  that dick intended.
> 
> the book without the expansion is very much like a twilight zone episode.  the
> expansion is very abstract and psychedelic.  i can see why the publisher would
> have thought it too weird but it does add to the story.
> 
> and finally, after about 6 different people told me i should, i'm reading snow
> crash.  very funny and outlandish adventure book.  what are you reading?  let
> me or us know!
> 
> --
> 
> After another moment's silence, she mumbled that I was peculiar, that that was
> probably why she loved me but that one day I might disgust her for the very
> same reason.
> 
> ? Albert Camus, L'Etranger
> 
> 
> 
> ----------------------------------------------------------------
> This message was sent using IMP, the Internet Messaging Program.
> 
> 
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

--

tsheets@saturn5.com                                  <- You have found me   
http://www.ferrapsylix.com                           <- sub atomic breakbeat
"I just don't have the discipline to be a hippie"    <- Homer J. Simpson

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Thu)

Finally a thread i can floss my mind with.....thanks Deepfog!

i'm reading "love in the time of cholera" -gabriel gacia marquez
it starts off as a romantic piece and then goes into sexual liberation. 
this was written sometime ago so it's like a melrose place episode as far
as being risque.  unlike melrose place, it is brilliantly written.  i am
enjoying it immensely.

JOnas






> i just got done reading philip k. dick's "lies, inc.".  this is an
> interesting
> book, because it was originally written in the 1960's and published as
> "the
> unteleported man".
>
> dick wrote and wanted to publish an expansion of the book at the time, but
> the
> publisher didn't like the expansion.  then in the late 70's, he found
> another
> publisher to agree to publish the book with the expansion.  the only
> problem
> was he couldn't find 4 pages of the original book so he rewrote the
> beginning
> and ending to make it all fit together.  then he died in 1982, and the
> person
> managing his writings found the 4 pages and published the book, with the
> expansion, under the new name "lies, inc."  that dick intended.
>
> the book without the expansion is very much like a twilight zone episode.
> the
> expansion is very abstract and psychedelic.  i can see why the publisher
> would
> have thought it too weird but it does add to the story.
>

> snow
