Subject: [sfraves] [bsp] Amber on the field at SF Giants game (Saturday 4/9)

Open Turntables and DJ Performances at SF Giants game this Saturday
http://www.iamthedj.com/news/

I will be on the field (on the field!) at SBC Park before the game with
two young norcalDJMPA alumni who will be spinning a short set for the
crowd of 40,000 before the San Francisco Giants face the Colorado Rockies
this Saturday.

norcalDJMPA will be hosting open turntables in front of the park in Willie
Mays Plaza from 11am - 1pm, and up in the Coca-Cola Fan Lot during the
game, too. You would be nuts to miss this. DJs invade SBC park this
Saturday. Get tickets now!

http://www.sfgiants.com/

Here's another cool one that's been making the rounds:

Black Rock City (site of Burning Man)
http://maps.google.com/maps?q=gerlach,NV&ll=40.759277,-119.236679&spn=0.042229,0.070467&t=k&hl=en

http://redirx.com/?37rs

The satellite pic was taken days before it was about to begin 
(8-18-2003), so you can make out the layout, and camps starting to setup, 
and you can _almost_ make out a teeny tiny 'Man".

-terry

Subject: Re: [sfraves] I WANT TO PROMOTE!

>Who do I need to hook up with? I've got the raver heart, so let me
spread the love (and peace >and unity and respect).
 
Who do you need to hook up with?  You need to hook up with me, so I
can pimp you out and get you to know all the "right" people.  No need
for you to spread the love, we can find other things to spread that
will bring a lot more joy.  I like that idea you had with the
CD-Player, i'm sure we can have a lot of fun with that, probably bring
in some good cash flow too.

Why do people always gotta post, how do i promote?  I dont get it.  Is
it really that hard to figure out.  I mean shit when i first started
partying back in the early/mid 90's i figured it out.  It's not that
hard to go to the DJ, who more often then not will know whos' throwing
the party (unless it's keoki and he's too fucked up to remember his
own name) and ask...hey i wanna help promote, are you part of this
crew or know who it?  Or how about the person working door?  or one of
the people working *cough*security*cough*.  It's not that hard to
notice the people behind all the action, unless your an E'd out candy
kid, with enough chemicals in your blood to kill a horse, and still
i've been there and i can still tell who's behind the party.  Sure
asking a public forum like this could get your pointed in about 30
differant directions, but why not take the initiative yourself and ask
around at the party your at.  You are obviously at that party cause
you like some element of it, and therefor asking around there, will
get you better leads, rather then getting 30 leads here that could
point you in directions you dont really care for (like promoting
gabber parties or something *bleh*) you could ask around at that party
and get leads that would point you in a similar direction as that
party.

For me the easiest way was to stick it out till the end of the party,
after everyone's gone home.  The few people remaining are generally
going to be the people throwing that party and then you can have a
chance to talk to them one on one without loud pounding music going on
in the background or stupid raver kids asking you if your want a god
damn sucky ass light show.  Offer to help clean up and talk about what
other things you can do to help out.  It shows you get some motivation
to be part of a crew.

All in all take initiative, walk around, ask around, putting out a
broad post on a public forum isnt the way to go, it's like getting a
tutor and having them do your homework for you, you get it done and
you get good grades, but are you really learning anything?

-- 
Cletus the Slack Jawed Yokel

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] I WANT TO PROMOTE! 

On Thu, 07 Apr 2005 20:46:05 -0400, <heaven957@aol.com> wrote:

> So.... I'm really loving the rave scene right now.... kinda new, very  
> open minded and loving the music!!!!!!! I swear, I would have sex with  
> it if I could, but that hasnt worked yet. (Well, except for that one  
> time I turned my CD player up real loud and sat on it) lol....j/k.

Well that's your problem- you don't sit on the CD player, you sit on the  
speaker-
Get yourself a nice, suitable-shaped bandpass box (SAS Bazooka tubes work  
well here)- then just send a 33hz tone through it-
Put a little ampmod on it to make it pulse nicely, and there ya go...
Be careful you get the frequency right- 33hz vibrations will make most  
women have a spontaneous orgasm, but 13hz will make you instantly shit  
yourself.
Unless you're in to that of course :P

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

"Hypocritical Hip Hop"
By NerCity (3-16-05)

"I don't like these new rappers"
"They aint talking about shit"
"All they do is degrade women and talk about money"
"What happened to REAL MC'S!!!????!"
SHUT UP!!!!
Old School hip hop heads
Got all 'Booshy'
Forgot where they came from.
Acting like Ice Cube's alias wasn't "Bitch Killer"
Like Chuck D
And PE
Wasn't hanging out with gun totting criminals
Called the 9-8 posse
Holding gats
Are you really trying to tell me
That all old school hip hop
Was block parties and pro-black???
Man 'figa-figa-figa' fuck that..
The first rule about hip hop is "KEEPING IT REAL"
And real is
For every time Jay-Z rhymed about Maibach
EPMD talked about Benze with "Ground effect kits"
In days way back.
Hell EPMD stood for
two dudes "Making Dollars"
No different than a crew called "Cash Money"
Rap recycles itself
Like Daytons and Trues and Vogues
Now being replaced by Spinners dipped in chrome
Before I heard KRS-1 talk about self destruction
He told me that
"Roxanne Shawntee was only good for steady @#%$"
Basically calling a Queen from Queensbridge a Ho.
Hell "Bitch Better Have My Money"
And "Jeneane The Dick Fiend'
By AMG
Disrespected more women
Then any song from
50, Buck, or Tony Yayo. ...
You Hip Hop Hypocrites....!!!
Acting all high and mighty
judging these new school kids
And their music...
Women who got upset and wanted to boycott
Nelly when credit cards were slid down the ass of Groupies
were the same women that replied
In the early 90's when Treach asked them
If they were "Down with OPP?"
Come on man..stop fronting
It's just me.
Don't get booshy.
Acting like NWA
stands for "Nubians With Agendas"
You're laughing..
But if you're around my age..you're fronting
For every Poor Righteous Teachers
There was a Too Short
"BIIIOTCH" bumping in your speakers
There was
DJ Run
Keeping a bag of cheeba inside his locker.
Before Hey Young World
Or Children's Story score
Rick the Ruler said
"The Bitch Been Around Before My Mother's Born"
Face it..
Bitch and ho lyrics aren't new...
Hip Hop has always embraced it.
Talked about guns,
drugs, money and material things
Three fingered rings
To bling bling
 From Sugar Hill
Cypress Hill or Lauryn Hill
Digital Underground's Sex Packets
Were ecstasy pills
Way before Em talked about Purple Hills
Come on man.
You're breaking rule number 1 of Hip Hop
"Keep IT REAL!"
Or maybe we should just keep it right.
And make all MC's accountable for what they write.
Understand that our MC's
Opened the door for 1000's of MC's
And even though we feel a few of them
are some 'Sucka MC's" They're still MC's...
MC Brains or Chingy
The people who say they hate rappers who sing a lot
Know they bump "Friends" by Whodini
Or Biz Markie
Stop being hip hop hypocrites
If you don't like the way Rap music is now a days.
Shut up
Shut off the radio and video
Leave the mainstream garbage alone
dig up your roots
and dig out some Roots and stop being "Clones"
And PLEASE....stop complaining
Hip Hop is fine.
The same people who complain about it
Are the same people who only download it online
Don't support the art.
Don't go to Talib or Common concerts.
Hip Hop is fine.
Radio has always sucked!!!
So if you're tired of how Hip Hop sounds
go back to where you first heard it.....
come with me...
It's underground.
==========================================




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Fri)

thought i was going to forget, eh?  actually, the internet was down (or so
annoyingly slow it might as well have *been* down) so i had to wait.

i was going to make friday a star trek quote of the day.  yes, i still like star
trek.  i know i don't talk about it as much these days and i know that you wish
i would.  well everything needs a rest now and then.  back when i was at UCSC
there were these surfer dudes from dana point in my dorm.  well guess what they
liked to do?  yep, you guessed it.  i had to climb up on the upper bunk in order
to use this contraption they had.  anyway, one of them told me all i ever talked
about was star trek and raves.  now i just don't talk much unless there's
something really new and interesting.

and speaking of new and interesting, why not dig up an old quote of the day from
one of my favorite old time authors, robert anton wilson.  you know, the nice
thing about things we like is they never really get old.  sometimes you have to
take a break from them but just like a boomerang, they always come back to you.

happy friday!

-d

--

William James, father of American psychology, tells of meeting an old lady who
told him the Earth rested on the back of a huge turtle.

"But my dear lady," Professor James asked, as politely as possible, "what holds
up the turtle?"

"Ah," she said.  "that's easy.  He is standing on the back of another turtle."

"Oh, I see," said Professor James, still being polite.  "But would you be so
good as to tell me what holds up the second turtle?"

"It's no use, Professor," said the old lady, realizing he was trying to lead her
into a logical trap.  "It's turtles-turtles-turtles, all the way!"

- Robert Anton Wilson, excerpt from "Promethius Rising"

i must have missed this email ... i've been doing mass dumps to my

works, works, right?

right now i'm regurgitating all my webmail back down to my laptop.  i'm 
at an internet cafe in malta.  when i came to san francisco last month, 
i was pleased to see more coffee shops having wifi, but this cafe i'm 
at here blows them all away.  they serve alcohol and let you play pool 
and order food all in sort of a big multiplex internet cafe.  it also 
connects to a bed and breakfast.  and internet is $3 per hour.  not 
bad.

what else could you possibly want?

see you all monday ... quote of the day

>Holding gats

>Was block parties and pro-black???

>For every time Jay-Z rhymed about Maibach
>EPMD talked about Benze with "Ground effect kits"

>two dudes "Making Dollars"

>Rick the Ruler said

>Talked about guns,
>drugs, money and material things

>To bling bling

>Way before Em talked about Purple Hills

>"Keep IT REAL!"

>And even though we feel a few of them
>are some 'Sucka MC's" They're still MC's...
>MC Brains or Chingy
>The people who say they hate rappers who sing a lot
>Know they bump "Friends" by Whodini
>Or Biz Markie
>Stop being hip hop hypocrites
>If you don't like the way Rap music is now a days.
>Shut up
>Shut off the radio and video
>Leave the mainstream garbage alone
>dig up your roots
>and dig out some Roots and stop being "Clones"
>And PLEASE....stop complaining
>Hip Hop is fine.
>The same people who complain about it
>Are the same people who only download it online
>Don't support the art.
>Don't go to Talib or Common concerts.
>Hip Hop is fine.
>Radio has always sucked!!!

>It's underground.

KFJC Record Swap

The next KFJC Record Swap is happening Saturday, June 25 from 10:AM to
4:PM at Spangenberg Theater in Palo Alto. This is an open invitation
to anyone who wishes to sign up as a dealer. Feel free to pass this
information on to other record labels, distributors, stores, publishers,
publications, bands, collectors, dealers, DJs and friends who might be
interested.

<http://kfjc.org/swap/dealers.php>kfjc.org/swap/dealers.php

This year promises to be a truly amazing event at a new location with
bands playing (live broadcast!), KFJC DJs spinning and much more. If
you think we are passionate about music, so are our listeners!

Early reservation is suggested. To reserve space today, please print
out, complete and return the form with payment or simply make a
payment online. Reservations will be confirmed by telephone two weeks
before the swap. Deadline for reservations is Monday, June 6 2005.

Thanks!

--dk

Psychoacoustic Soundclash
with Nozmo King
Saturdays, 3-6 PM (PT)

KFJC 89.7 FM (<http://kfjc.org>kfjc.org)

On Apr 8, 2005 12:07 PM, Nathan Seven <scosol@scosol.org> wrote:
> On Thu, 07 Apr 2005 20:46:05 -0400, <heaven957@aol.com> wrote:

> > So.... I'm really loving the rave scene right now.... kinda new, very
> > open minded and loving the music!!!!!!! I swear, I would have sex with
> > it if I could, but that hasnt worked yet. (Well, except for that one
> > time I turned my CD player up real loud and sat on it) lol....j/k.
> 
> Well that's your problem- you don't sit on the CD player, you sit on the
> speaker-
> Get yourself a nice, suitable-shaped bandpass box (SAS Bazooka tubes work
> well here)- then just send a 33hz tone through it-
> Put a little ampmod on it to make it pulse nicely, and there ya go...
> Be careful you get the frequency right- 33hz vibrations will make most
> women have a spontaneous orgasm, but 13hz will make you instantly shit
> yourself.

if it were true then it would be technically possible to install in
your car a seat capable of automatically generating spontaneous
orgasms for female passengers.

think of the time you would save!

especially if you had a camper.

> On Apr 8, 2005 12:07 PM, Nathan Seven <scosol@scosol.org> wrote:
>> Get yourself a nice, suitable-shaped bandpass box (SAS Bazooka tubes  
>> work
>> well here)- then just send a 33hz tone through it-
>> Put a little ampmod on it to make it pulse nicely, and there ya go...
>> Be careful you get the frequency right- 33hz vibrations will make most
>> women have a spontaneous orgasm, but 13hz will make you instantly shit
>> yourself.

> if it were true then it would be technically possible to install in
> your car a seat capable of automatically generating spontaneous
> orgasms for female passengers.

No bullshit- I believe it was Tesla who fist discovered the "vibrating  
shit table"...
IIRC he would invite guests in to his house and tell them to sit on the  
"relaxation platform", then await their reaction.
My kinda guy...

As for the in-seat attention-getting action, there are several companies  
that make transducers that are made simply to vibrate, and not produce  
sound (though they operate just like loudspeakers)-
Yeah sure, I guess I could be fiddling with knobs on the dash while my  
female companion is enjoying the ride in her seat, but hahah those aren't  
the buttons I want to be pushing you know?

good times good times...
See you at  Sunet   party everyone!!!!

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Mon)

sitting in a euro internet cafe, sipping on some "fizzy" water (perrier=20=

to us paltry americans), chatting with osby on IM ... the life.  ahh.

and personally, i like the volkswagens they have over here, especially=20=

The President explains the virtues of his Social
Security plan,
Tampa, FL, Feb. 4, 2005

WOMAN IN AUDIENCE:  " I don't really understand. How is it the new=20
[Social Security] plan is going to fix the problems you have=20
mentioned?"

PRESIDENT BUSH: "Because the -- all which is on the table begins to=20
address the big cost drivers. For example, how benefits are calculated,=20=

for example, is on the table. Whether or not benefits rise based upon=20
wage increases or price increases. There's a series of parts of the=20
formula that are being considered. And when you couple that, those=20
different cost drivers, affecting those -- changing those with personal=20=

accounts, the idea is to get what has been promised more likely to be=20
-- or closer delivered to that has been promised. Does that make any=20
sense to you? It's kind of muddled. Look, there's a series of things=20
that cause the -- like, for example, benefits are calculated based upon=20=

the increase of wages, as opposed to the increase of prices. Some have=20=

suggested that we calculate -- the benefits will rise based upon=20
inflation, as opposed to wage increases. There is a reform that would=20
help solve the red if that were put into effect. In other words, how=20
fast benefits grow, how fast the promised benefits grow, if those -- if=20=

that growth is affected, it will help on the red. =A0

=A0
Okay, is that clear enough for you?" =A0

>From: Heidi <cosmicdancer@sbcglobal.net>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: [sfraves] Miss Kitten at Mezzanine 4.30.05___ FREE
>Date: Fri, 11 Mar 2005 09:24:17 -0800 (PST)
>
>I cannot believe this is going to be a free show! Just
>found it in my inbox and thought I'd share it with you
>guys. Hope to see you there!
>
>love, Heidi
>~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>
>Saturday April 30th
>blasthaus presenté
>Miss Kittin
>at Mezzanine
>10pm until 2am
>21+ / $FREE
>
>http://www.illstatic.com/venue_list.php?venue=Mezzanine#the%20415%20SESSIONS
>
>
>"DJ is my main activity, working every weekend in
>clubs or festivals since 1994. I started with hard
>techno-acid sounds: Drop Bass Network, Analog,
>Interr-Ferrence, Force Inc, SP23, to Detroit and
>experimental techno. I figured out it expressed my
>late teenage aggressivity. With experience, I got
>musically softer and more open-minded.
>
>Actually I play everything that entertains me:
>minimal, deep, to kicking techno, mixed with funny our
>leftfield tunes, classics, electro, no matter what it
>is. That's why I hardly can describe my style. A 2h
>monotone set really bores me. If I don't have fun
>myself, I'm not able to please people.
>DJing must be, in a way, something selfish. I shout it
>loud: I don't do it for the people. I never pretended
>to educate the audience, I just share a big part of
>me, taking it as serious as I love it. Michael Mayer
>(Kompakt records, Cologne) said: "Taking it serious
>about having fun." Because 1st it's a job, and we
>should never forget being paid to give pleasure to
>people is a great privilege. If the risks I take in my
>sets are my trademark, my priority is still to make
>dance the ones who make my living. Question of
>respect.
>
>I think I have a sharp technique, pitch-control born
>in my acid times, I consider my best weapon to focus
>on musical choices.
>
>I love playing records, it's probably the best thing I
>know to do in life. I do it because it's big fun and
>it makes me free, it even turns into a meditation kind
>of thing. With records, nothing is planned, every
>record is important. I often compares a DJ set to a
>tennis game where each ball counts. But people know me
>more for my voice even if I never took singing
>lessons."
>
>
>

>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] photos from sunset

Grrrr...the guest account has been suspended so I can't see the pics, 
but it was great to see so many faces yesterday that I hadn't seen in 
days. Had a fantastic time, the only shitty part being when the cops 
wouldn't let us spin fire. I know that I did a few burns there last 
year, so I was bummed that they were talking about lack of permits. 
Overall, it was amazing to see so many beautiful people dancing and 
being in community under the warm spring sun. Big ups to the the SF scene.

Happy

>http://www.illstatic.com/venue_list.php?venue=Mezzanine#the%20415%20SESSIONS

> >"DJ is my main activity, working every weekend in
> >clubs or festivals since 1994. I started with hard
> >techno-acid sounds: Drop Bass Network, Analog,
> >Interr-Ferrence, Force Inc, SP23, to Detroit and
> >experimental techno. I figured out it expressed my
> >late teenage aggressivity. With experience, I got
> >musically softer and more open-minded.
> >
> >Actually I play everything that entertains me:
> >minimal, deep, to kicking techno, mixed with funny
> our
> >leftfield tunes, classics, electro, no matter what
> it
> >is. That's why I hardly can describe my style. A 2h
> >monotone set really bores me. If I don't have fun
> >myself, I'm not able to please people.
> >DJing must be, in a way, something selfish. I shout
> it
> >loud: I don't do it for the people. I never
> pretended
> >to educate the audience, I just share a big part of
> >me, taking it as serious as I love it. Michael
> Mayer
> >(Kompakt records, Cologne) said: "Taking it serious
> >about having fun." Because 1st it's a job, and we
> >should never forget being paid to give pleasure to
> >people is a great privilege. If the risks I take in
> my
> >sets are my trademark, my priority is still to make
> >dance the ones who make my living. Question of
> >respect.
> >
> >I think I have a sharp technique, pitch-control
> born
> >in my acid times, I consider my best weapon to
> focus
> >on musical choices.
> >
> >I love playing records, it's probably the best
> thing I
> >know to do in life. I do it because it's big fun
> and
> >it makes me free, it even turns into a meditation
> kind
> >of thing. With records, nothing is planned, every
> >record is important. I often compares a DJ set to a
> >tennis game where each ball counts. But people know
> me
> >more for my voice even if I never took singing
> >lessons."
> >
> >

Subject: [sfraves] mary jane related: granny eats the canny-bis


> Subject: [D] Sounds like MY grandma (seriously)
>
> Pothead Grandmother Spared Jail
>
> Mon Apr 11, 8:09 AM ET
>  Oddly Enough - Reuters
> By Lydia Bell
> LONDON (Reuters) - A 66-year-old British grandmother
> with a taste for marijuana casserole was spared jail
> Friday despite admitting she had shared
> cannabis-laced cookies with fellow pensioners.
>
> Patricia Tabram from East Lea in the northern tip of
> England, who said she uses cannabis to alleviate
> pains in her neck and back, pleaded guilty to
> possession of the drug with intent to supply.
>
> But Judge David Hodson said he would not make a
> "martyr" of her when she returned to Newcastle Crown
> Court for sentencing. Instead, she received a
> six-month suspended prison sentence.
>
> The white-haired, bespectacled granny was
> unrepentant, and said she would keep cooking with
> pot.
>
> "I had it this morning in my scrambled eggs and I'll
> have it again for lunch. I'm not giving it up," she
> told Channel 4 news.
>
> Tabram has become a symbol for Britain's legalize
> marijuana campaign. On her Web Site,
> www.grandma-eats-cannabis.com, she promises soon to
> provide free recipes, as well as tea towels and mugs
> for sale.
>
> Last year, Britain downgraded cannabis from the same
> class as cocaine and ecstasy to a lower class of
> illegal drug, which means police are not expected to
> arrest people for possessing small amounts but can
> jail them for supplying it to others.
>
> Police said they raided Tabram's home after a
> tip-off in May last year and found 31 cannabis
> plants along with hydroponic cultivation equipment.
> In a later raid they found 47 bags of "skunk," a
> particularly strong form of the drug.
>
> The set-up at Tabram's home "bore all the hallmarks
> of any sophisticated drug dealer," police said in a
> statement.
>
>


--

Subject: RE: [sfraves] smartest dance floor on earth

When we did sound for Sound Asylum (5 i think) Denise brought in one
of those dance floors.  It was pretty cool.  You could setup little
games on it like dodge the bouncing ball and pong.  We had a lot of
fun on it at the beginning of the party before people started packing
in.  For a while people didnt seem to want to dance on it, but once we
got a few people going it was all over from there.  It had some cool
effects on it.  But it's freakin expensive as hell.  the guy who set
it up said he's done a few clubs where they had the entire dancefloor
made of that stuff, but for this party it was only like a 10'x10'
square.  i got video of it at home still i think.
-- 
Chester Copperpot

"Meth Monsters are my Anti-Drug"
"I feel like I'm taking crazy pills"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] I WANT TO PROMOTE!

> >> Get yourself a nice, suitable-shaped bandpass box (SAS Bazooka tubes
> >> work
> >> well here)- then just send a 33hz tone through it-
> >> Put a little ampmod on it to make it pulse nicely, and there ya go...
> >> Be careful you get the frequency right- 33hz vibrations will make most
> >> women have a spontaneous orgasm, but 13hz will make you instantly shit
> >> yourself.
> >
> > hold on a minute, is this bullshit or real?
> >
> > if it were true then it would be technically possible to install in
> > your car a seat capable of automatically generating spontaneous
> > orgasms for female passengers.
> >
> > think of the time you would save!
> >
> > especially if you had a camper.
> 
> No bullshit- I believe it was Tesla who fist discovered the "vibrating
> shit table"...
> IIRC he would invite guests in to his house and tell them to sit on the
> "relaxation platform", then await their reaction.
> My kinda guy...
> 
> As for the in-seat attention-getting action, there are several companies
> that make transducers that are made simply to vibrate, and not produce
> sound (though they operate just like loudspeakers)-
> Yeah sure, I guess I could be fiddling with knobs on the dash while my
> female companion is enjoying the ride in her seat, but hahah those aren't
> the buttons I want to be pushing you know?

sorry, I don't understand at all. what other buttons are worth pushing?

I wasn't picturing a set of knobs to fiddle with on the dash so much
as a more Nicola Tesla meets "The Fast And The Furious" situation,
really. like a sort of, "bitch, get in, sit down, shut up, cream your
fucking panties" sort of thing. if the orgasm-inducing frequency can
be predicted dependably for the majority of women then you just set
the machine to that frequency in the hardware. why would you ever
twiddle the knob? there's no other frequency to set it to. the only
necessary control is an "on" button.

(btw gmail has this weird habit of hiding my sent messages so I only
found your reply today, that might be the reason for the confusion
here.)

anyway, you're thinking too small. it's not a toy to entertain
somebody who would already be having sex with you anyway. it's a
button you push that allows you to give an orgasm to any woman who
gets in your car. this frees you from the requirement of even being
able to speak the woman's language. imagine if you were a limo driver.
you're driving a gorgeous woman from Italy. you don't speak Italian.
she doesn't speak English. you push the button. what happens?

if what you're describing is a bona fide universal
female-orgasm-generating technology, then it's true -- Tesla really
was a genius.

-- 
DJ Soundwave

-----Original Message-----
From: Steve Osteen=20
Sent: Tuesday, April 12, 2005 11:25 AM
To: 'Chester Copperpot'; DJ Soundwave

Subject: RE: [sfraves] smartest dance floor on earth

Imagine a floor like that in a square room covering the entire floor
with 4 projectors set up so that each wall has some winamp visual (R4 is
my favorite) running at a high resolution covering the entire walls.
Then add a few dozen lasers and a little fog. Maybe do a moon and some
stars on the ceiling with planetarium like changing color horizon
lighting (to simulate different time changes).

Full Moon Drum Circle April 23rd

Hey all!

What are you doin this saturday, April 23rd 2005 @ 4pm
till 12am ? We are having a Full Moon Drum Circle here
in Bonny Doon, Ca. Near Santa Cruz. If you would like
to come out to the drum circle please follow these
directions or for more info. please contact me
@<http://by10fd.bay10.hotmail.msn.com/cgi-bin/compose?curmbox=F000000001&a=5bf8d26139299db7af06760d49fd3129&mailto=1&to=sonny_twofeathers@hotmail.com&msg=MSG1113282487.17&start=2750860&len=3751&src=&type=x>sonny_twofeathers@hotmail.com 
or reply to this post.
Remember this is a PotLuck so contribute if you can
and help us feed the fire.

Follow these directions exactly:

 From hwy 1 and bonny doon rd

Turn on Bonny Doon rd. Go 5.3 mi to Ice Cream
Grade.(bonny doon rd
will become pine flat. continue straight)

Just before you get to Ice Cream Grade you will pass
Bonny Doon
Elementary. Turn Right on Ice Cream Grade. We are the
third drive on
the left, after the bend. .49 mi from pine flat to the
house.
( Look for the Fire and Listen for the Drums)





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] Red Jerry and chillout rooms


Anyone familiar with the album (Deep and Chilled Euphoria, Mixed by Red
Jerry)? Ever been in a chillout room with it playing?

Anyone want to share any awesome ambient experiences? Any good chillout
room memories?

Somehow I've managed to connect to the music in this album on a
spiritual level. The songs move me in a way that can't be explained in
words.

Maybe it was the 5-meo-mipt?
Maybe it was the MDMA?
Maybe it was all those nights in the dark on DXM?

Maybe they are just damn great songs.

As I move farther and farther away from daily drug usage I've found my
mind is going a little insane. Or maybe I forgot what being normal is.

Steve

Grace's chics hatch!!!

In the quiet of darkness between the evening of April 11, and the early 
morning hours of April 12, the first eyas of the 2005 season hatched!  Then 
the second eyas hatched shortly before 7AM PDT on camera the morning of 
April 12!  Not wanting to miss out...at 2:25PM PDT eyas number 3 made its 
entrance into the world!  This has been a very busy day indeed!  When 
peregrines are young, they require near-constant brooding by the adults to 
keep warm, so when the chicks are not being fed, the adults will appear 
much as if they are incubating, making the chicks difficult to see the 
first few days after hatching.  One egg now remains in the nest box...

Subject: [sfraves] miss kittin april 30... yes!!!

fuck yeah, she's worth paying $20 to see!  i am SO
psyched she's coming back.  i heard her last year at
mezzanine, and it was the best dj set i heard all
year, hands down!  (and it was a busy year for me, as
i went to both movement in detroit AND sonar and heard
some amazing stuff.)  anyway, i think she rocks.  i
hope she's as good as the last time i saw her.   plus,
it's the eve of beltane/may day, the pagan festival of
spring, one of the best party nights of the year,
imho.  i am giddy.  i may be more giddy about seeing
her than about going to detroit.  (well, maybe not - i
think i'll be getting to see rob hood there!)

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Wed)

just when i was thinking the other day that most of the really really old school
sfr celebrities either are no longer on the list or perhaps are full-time
lurkers, will penna i guess is back on sfraves!  give him a warm welcome.  most
of the people on the list actively posting today are people that joined from
about 1995 and on.  there's a lot of people that used to post from 1992.

anyway, will and the rest of the old school santa cruz collective still keep
things alive down there, and i really appreciate that when i come home to
visit.  if you've never been down there tracy and carlos i believe spin quite a
bit down there.  check it out!

>peregrines are young, they require near-constant brooding by the adults to 
>keep warm, so when the chicks are not being fed, the adults will appear 
>much as if they are incubating, making the chicks difficult to see the

Subject: [sfraves] SASHA & STEVE PORTER @ Element Fridays [SEATTLE][21+]

--0-986630874-1113423962=:72056
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Element Fridays presents...



SASHA - RENAISSANCE THE MIX COLLECTION: 10th ANNIVERSARY EDITION - www.djsasha.com | The Collective | UK

There are DJs who turn up, play records and make people dance. And there are producers who make the dancefloor-igniting records those DJs will kill for. There are very few people in dance music who can do both and Sasha is the leader of the pack. Ever since he rode in on a tidal wave of adoration from the North of England's explosive early 90s club scene, that magic touch has made Alexander Coe one of the most famous, most revered DJ on the planet.

It's because of what he can do with music - the way he can make good records sound better, great records sound awesome, and everything he plays into his own. The way his mixes take elements from across the spectrum of electronic dance, from trance, breaks, progressive and deep house, and create a languidly hypnotic liquid groove. The way his understanding of both melody and momentum can tease, taunt, and en-trance a dancefloor before unleashing a record that will have people not just leaping up and down but bursting with emotion. The best DJs know that Djing is first about being able to read people and then about being able to tap into that human experience and take it on a journey. Sasha has always been noted for being a master at this and it is this universal appeal that he has tapped into that has established his strong fanbase around the globe.

Do not be mistaken, this kind of recognition does not happen overnight. Born and raised in a small town in Wales, Sasha was exposed to Motown records when he was just a baby and it was in the home that his talent for playing the piano was developed. His stepmother forced him to take lessons. At the time, he hated them, but after his first studio session - and this is typical Sasha - he phoned her to say thank you. His first exposure to house music was at Manchester's Hacienda; just as dance music exploded into the summer of love. One visit and the young pony-tailed Sasha was hooked. "The smoke machine, the strobe lights, everyone trance dancing, wearing bandanas and smiley T-shirts," he smiles now. "It definitely had a fuck-you attitude compared to the rest of pop music." This impact encouraged his move from Wales to Manchester. His first exploration into Djing was when a DJ in a local pub announced he was looking for people to play club dates. Sasha volunteered and now says that he
 'had about 30 records and basically just blagged it'.

After honing his deck technique, Sasha's first big break came when he was offered a residency at Stokes legendary club Shelly's. When all the other DJ's were playing US House, Sasha's style was much more uplifting, and he encapsulated clubbers with his mixture of piano led Italian House whilst playing acapella tracks over the top. This combination alongside a wide variety of anthems kept dancefloors full and elevated Sasha to hero status. And, lets not forget, in a world where the DJ had too often been bespectacled nerds, here the headline DJ had the looks and charm to match his growing following. In classic rock n' roll style, here was a star that boys wanted to hang out with and girls wanted to get just that little more bit close to.

Shelly's was the launch pad for the residency at Renaissance, where Sasha created his niche and helped forge a new style in UK house music. At Renaissance two major things happened; Sasha mixed the first ever UK DJ mix album and he met John Digweed which cemented the partnership known as 'Northern Exposure'. Sasha and John have played together on five continents, have mixed 3 'Northern Exposure' albums which have sold to over 1 million people worldwide. This special brother like relationship that Sasha and Digweed have on the decks, is what landed them the monthly residency at New York's "Twilo", following in the footsteps of Vasquez and Tenaglia.

The first DJ cover star - on Mixmag in early 1991 - the still shy DJ was freaked. "I was so used to going to places and just hanging out. Suddenly there was a stream of people coming up," he recalls. "Of course it's bound to happen. You go to Liverpool and you're the first 'pin-up' DJ and you're going to get shit. Frankly, It still weirds me out." Today he still remains shy at heart. "I'm not very good in social situations where I'm put on the spot," he says. "Like meeting new people, small talk. Just never been good with that." It's this contradiction - the coyness that Alexander Coe has when it comes to being Sasha, that's at the core of the Sasha myth.

Although Sasha has clearly reached a celebrity status, it's his generous personality, his love for his peers and of course his completely candid humour that has enabled him to maintain such a likeable high profile in the often-fickle world of club culture. Sasha has gone from DJ to superstar status in America, where 'Sarsha' is a household name for many teenagers - a gruelling three month tour took their sound further out into deepest America, preaching a gospel of repetitive beats and imaginative mixing from coast to coast, and right through the mid western heartland of the States. A punishing gig-a-night schedule that must make nights like the opening of Space in Ibiza in June seem like a holiday by comparison.

There followed a move back into releasing his own music, collaborating with the former Underworld mainstay, DJ Darren Emerson on 'Scorchio'. For Sasha, music is his first love, and what gives him a buzz is being able to share his music with others. Soon after 'Scorchio' came the first concrete proof of the long-awaited, debut Sasha longplayer.

'Airdrawndagger' took his nose for the dancefloor's g-spot and combined it with the ears for a heartstring strumming melody, a smile inducing hook and dirty great b-line to create a 69 minute symphony that sounds as wistfully enchanting doing the hoovering at home as it does reaching for the lasers on Saturday night. Like the best Sasha DJ set you ever heard, it has melancholy mixed with euphoria, downtempo introspection mixed with jump n' shout excitement.

Across the 11 tracks, there's the time and space to reflect his love for music that rarely gets the chance to shine in clubs, whether that's punishingly gnarly breakbeats or glittering modern classical film scores. It's a symphony for all ravers that grew up but never grew out of chasing that buzz. A record of a journey that began, as so many did, in the smoke and strobes of Manchester's Hacienda nightclub and has now taken him to Midwestern stadia and around the globe.

And that's an award-winning journey. The Delta Heavy Tour that consisted of Sasha, John Digweed and Johnny Van M and took in 35 gigs between March and May last year was recently awarded Best Dance Event at the Dancestar Awards 2003. It was a series of gigs that took DJing into unprecedented waters - two mammoth tour buses, visuals by the company behind hit movie 7even's intense opening credit sequence, and crowds of up to 15,000 clubbers crammed into arenas, warehouses and theatres across the United States. The success was such that Sasha and the boys will be back on the road to do it all again, bigger, better, badder come Spring next year.

After a summer of dates across the globe, including sets at Homelands, Creamfields, Dance Valley, and hosting a stage in the forest of the Mount Fuji Festival, Sasha has been in the studio again, working on new plans and ideas, and most recently remixing the forthcoming UNKLE single. Expect a few surprises over the coming months, for the man simply refuses to stand still.

also featuring...


STEVE PORTER - Fade Records | New York, New York

So Fresh, So Clean could be the perfect title for Steve Porter. It can easily describe his personality, his look and more importantly his music. 2003 was another banner year for the boy wonder with his big time single Definite Form and his now classic remix of Amber's Anyway. Adding to that his underground side projects Agent 001, HDF & Bons and his looming artist album, his music sees huge support across the spectrum of DJs from Sasha & John Digweed to Carl Cox to Mark Farina and Derek Carter.

Steve has now made a huge mark with his techno edged house productions. His studio work was only one facet of Steve's two prong attack. His DJing is where he really rocks the funky beats. His move to New York City from Boston has only put more fuel to the fire. Along with dates across the country and tours with Sasha (Airdrawndagger Tour), Sander Kleinenberg (Essential Mix Tour) and Chris Fortier, Steve is in demand from Tokyo to Tampa. With over 20 remixes to his credit, his Agent 001 & HDF & Bons projects busting down doors, he is leading way for the next wave of America's future stars. 


CHAD OWEN - Alphabet City | Sonic City UK | Seattle, WA


THIS EVENT WILL FEATURE SASHA IN BOTH ROOMS VIA LIVE VIDEO & SOUND FEEDS THROUGHOUT THE CLUB!!


Friday | April 22nd | 2005

Element Seattle
332 5th Avenue North
Seattle, WA 98109

Doors @ 9pm | $22/$27 Pre-Sales Available @ www.TicketsWest.com and at Platinum Records, Lights & Sound (Seattle & Portland) | 21+ w/ ID | 206.441.7579

www.elementseattle.com

+++G R O U N D A T I O N+++05/07/05


S T I X N S T O N Z / U R B A N - B R E A K S . C O M P R E S E N T

G R O U N D A T I O N

SATURDAY, MAY 7th, 2K5



FEATURING...


INFLUENCE - www.nfluence.net - SAN FRANCISCO

Representing straight out of San Francisco, Influence has been damaging dance floors with his versatile array of brokenbeat since 1998. His distinguished style combines long precise mixes, cross fader control with bass driven breaks. Influence has shared spotlights with some of brokenbeats most respected artists such as Chris Carter, Auotobots, Lobudg, Jhz, Trona, Aubl, Future Funk Squad, Stakka, Felix The Dog, Gridlok & Madame Mercury. In 2004, Influence started producing brokenbeat with the emphasis on funky, bass driven breaks. 


DJ CANTOS - www.djcantos.com - SACRAMENTO

In just a few short years, Sean Akio Canty a.k.a. Cantos, has advanced to the vanguard of the Sacramento dance music scene. With roots in mixing records reaching back to the underground hip-hop scene of 1992, Cantos possesses a level of skill and professionalism behind the decks that few can claim. His sound  a mixture of deep, progressive beats, dark breaks and smooth vocal tracks  demands control of the dance floor and his live sets can only be described as inspiring. His ability to read individual dancers and understand their desires never fails to satisfy each one. 

Beginning in Sacramento as a resident for a local underground production crew, Cantos is now a regular guest at The Rage Nightclub and has recently acquired residency at Twisted Thursdays located inside The Tower Club. With support from Sacramentos most respected production crews , as well as U.K.s Primalsounds.com, broadcasts of his internet show ProgressiveSoul are streamed live through selekta.com and reaches audiences worldwide. Cantos has utilized opportunities to share the decks with accomplished performers such as DJ Micro, DJ Dragnfly, Gianni, East Coast Boogiemen, MTV's DJ Icon, Aphrodite, Moda, Ariel Cybana, Madame Mercury, Mars & Mystre, Paul Lancaster, Gabriel Black and DJ Dara...


UNDECIDED - www.urban-breaks.com - SEATTLE

In early 2004 Chris aka Undecided moved from Sacramento, where he was responsibile for throwing many breaks shows and hosting weekly breaks nights, to Seattle, where he is quickly making a name for himself. He began deejaying in early 1998 and his skills have rapidly evolved, incorporating into his sets scratches and an unmatched energy, and earning him the opportunity to play with many well known and talented artists such as uberzone, DJ Rap, Trona, Baby Anne, A;Dubl, and influenze. Undecided is well known for his ability to make you groove to dirty funk basslines.


SOULKID - www.urban-breaks.com - SEATTLE

Hailing orginally from Orlando, FL...Soulkid has made Seattle his homebase for the past three years to push his funky Florida Breaks sound all along the west coast. Blending the Miami bass and the female vocal hooks, Soulkid keeps with the trademark of the Florida sound to move the soul. Influenced by breaks producers like Fixx, John Digweed, BT, Bassbin Twins, Huda Hudia, Brad Smith, Soulkid brings 17 years of experience behind the decks with him and a stage presence to match.


BISCUIT - www.urban-breaks.com - SEATTLE

Combining Nuskool, UK, and Funky Breaks, Biscuit has been bringing the best in breaks to dancefloors throughout the Northwest for the last 3 years. In this relatively short amount of time, Biscuit has quickly distinguished himself in the Seattle breaks scene with precise mixing and an enthusiastic stage presence. His talent behind the decks has lead him to share line-ups with numerious breakbeat icons and turntabalism geniuses such as Aquasky vs Masterblaster, Deekline, DJ Fixx, DJ Craze, the Young Punx, Factor e, and Disco D.


PALMER & POOKA - www.urban-breaks.com - OLYMPIA

updating bio

LOKI - www.urban-breaks.com - SEATTLE

updating bio

KENAZ - www.urban-breaks.com - OLYMPIA

updating bio

DJ DZY - SIT N SPIN - PORTLAND

updating bio

JOE NEMO - PZT 503 - PORTLAND

updating bio

URSUS - www.ursus.divitu.com - ASHLAND

updating bio

DJ SE7EN - ShortbusmonkeyS - MEDFORD

updating bio

updating bio


TITRATION - www.monkeytek.com - ASHLAND

)*-*-*-^^^_RaVeTaSTiC!_^^^-*-*-*([o4.23.o5]){SEA}
RAVETASTIC is going to be a production brought to you by the love and spirit of the community. A great number of production crews, djs, and groovers are uniting on this date to bring you a night of local love and chronic beats. Don't expect to hear your favorite locals playing one hour slots. Expecting something much more...

RaVeTaSTiC!





------=Can You Collect Them All?=-------




Reid Speed 
-=Very Special TWO Room Set! One Breaks, One Drum 'n' Bass=-
Reid Speed has had a pretty great year. In the fourteen months since her first mix CD, Resonance, on Breakbeat Science Recordings, she conquered a 35-date tour, moved to Los Angeles, secured a national ad campaign with Triple 5 Soul, and was selected as the official DJ for a network comedy show. As the perfect finish to her outstanding debut year, Reid Speed now releases her powerful new drum + bass mix CD, Life After Dark, a reflection of her packed dancefloor sets that illuminates the depth of her selection and the full spectrum of her talent as a DJ.

None of this attention has in any way distracted Reid from her first love - the dancefloor, to which she dedicates Life After Dark. The tracks on this, her second mix CD, represent a bold cross-section of the varying moods of drum + bass. Reid weaves a musical tapestry of uncommon threads, building a bridge from the musical bounce of "Funhouse", by NYC d+b production kings Mathematics, to the hardcore ragga stabs of DJ Dara and A-Sides' "Unholy Grail". Always one of drum + bass' most talented storytellers, Reid not only manages to get these two sounds into the same room but has them engaged in deep conversation - her greatest strength as a DJ and one of the standout elements of this mix. In a nod to diversity of tempos, the mix is bookended by slower and deeper works; Life After Dark opens with the murderous downtempo of drum + bass legend Dylan's "Black Rainbow" and slows to a sublime close with Omni Trio's remix of the Foul Play classic "Music Is The Key" - a bold gesture for a
 drum + bass DJ, and an illustrative start to the next unpredictable year of Reid Speed's artistic life.

Aaron Simpson

Jimmy Hoffa VS Chris Tremens


Detonate & Sarah Shoxx

VS.

Wheelz & The Corruptor

-+- 2 hours, 2x4, Hard Tekno versus Hard Trance! -+-
Detonate and Sarah Shoxx have been playing hard tekno all over for the last year, aggressively dedicating themselves to this new found love. Wheelz & The Corruptor have been producing and playing some of the best hard trance seattle's been groovin on for the last year. All 4 of these long time Seattle Electronica veterans are going to bring both styles together, in a battle for HARD supremacy!

Flave vs Jordan
-=Get your Funky ass up! Jordan and Flave are 2x4ing!=-
What do you get when you put Flave and Jordan together? You get a lot of ass shakin and lots and lots of funky shit! These cats used to live together and do it every day. Now their unleashing the funky fury at Ravetastic once again. You know it's on!!!

DJ Monkey VS Sonny Chiba VS ?????? VS Sandman
-=Who is the Suprise DJ?=-
Trance brought to you by Sonny C, DJ Monkey, Sandman and the mystery DJ. Who could it be? Only one way to find out! You'll hear lots and lots of rumors, but that just makes it more RaveTasTic! This is sure to be one of the most memorable sets of the night for any trancer out there. 

Sir Kutz vs Kreeper
-=4 decks and 2 mixers. 90 minutes and 50 records =-
Sir Kutz has been extremly busy playing all over Canada, Taiwan and Portland. While not playing in the Bass-Sick Boys rockin speed garage with Dig-Dug he can be seen playing Nu Skool Breaks. We figured what could be more ravetastically delicious then to have him play head to head with our own local bad boy Kreeper!!!!

Bazsic Elementz vs EMU
-+- 2 hours, 4 decks, 2 mixers, a metric raveload of breaks djs! -+-
One of the most interesting match ups, with Baszic and EMU kickin it and playing all sorts of breakbeats all over the northwest. This friendly duo may just end up being an around the world tour of the breaks. 

Goodbeat Drum n Bass!
-+Complex, RiceCube, Juggler, & Edot+-
Oh my god. The Goodbeat Drum and Bass crew in effect. Mash up style for the masses. Goodbeat + Ravetastic + Drum & Bass = GOOD RAVETASTIC DRUM AND BASS BEATS!!!

Jizosh vs Swank
-=UHF "House Ain't Givin Up" 2x4=-
That's right! The United House Front is on board and going to give us 90 minutes of funk! These cool cats have been holdin down Seattle house for a long damn time! Never to be bought, never to be sold, the UHF's finest are gonna funk you and leave you wanting some more!

Hardcore Kids of Doom!
-=Jimni Cricket vs Kid Kaboom vs Element DCLXVI=-
Take three of the most hardcore kids in the northwest and pit them up against each other and you've got a recipe for chaos and destruction. No one is sure how this will end up, but there will most definitely be some black and blue and blood and guts and broken bones.... of doom. 

Tony the Troll vs Loki
-=Treasure Troll vs The God of Mischief in the Breakbeat Arena!=-
Tony and Loki have been squarin off here and there in Seattle since ALL YOUR BASS ARE BELONG TO US, but only in the form of tag sets and improv action. On this night, they take on each other in a 2x4 which pits action figure against norse god! There are rumors of costumes and shenannigans. We'll just have to wait and see.

Heavyweight vs Jowell vs NRGYZR
-+-Pussycat in the house with an hour and a half of HARD trance and NRG-+-
The Pussycat Trio will be taking you on a journey of hard trance and NRG that will show you the best of what's across the water's got to offer. 

Soular
Soular, formerly Plurfict Trip, has been developing an awesome cosmic jazzy sound to his drum and bass. After hearing him play on C89 and at Edot's House Party, we had to bring Soular in to reprezent! This cat plays some smoooth tunes. 

Niugini
Niugini is the CD section of the Mix Orgying "Mendicants" but when he's solo, don't expect breakbeat madness, expect some of the chilliest and deep down relaxing house Soul Seek has to offer! 

Dave Airborne
Dave Airborne is quickly developing a good sound that even those who dislike trance will dig. One of the "goodbeat rookies" Dave is sure to impress with his programming and on point mixing. Just don't trainspot. He hates that!

BillyOKantSpin
BillyOKantSpin is a continuing project. This is the hardest working raver in town. Busting his ass all week long for his family and then comiing out and supporting and helping out with whatever shows go on. Billy0 literally can't spin. But he's going to learn. Consider this live action Reality TV!

Zodiac Productions presents: The Chill Room

The Death of Rich Uncle Skeleton
Radius VS. Manubrium
This is it. The final demise of the union of Rich Uncle Skeleton. Radius and Manubrium decide to have their final battle amongst the sounds of enlightenment. amongst the wailing of hell. No mortal soul dare observe, for your mind and body will belong to them. They will feast on your dumbfoundedness and awe. You'll serve as energy to fuel the chaos and harmony that will rage between the two. Nothing can save you. 

Location: 
9646 17th ave sw
seattle wa, 98106

Prices: 
Limited $15 presales! (Guaranteed Entry into the show!)
$20 at the door before Midnight! (show up early for more music and cheaper admission!)
$25 AFTER Midnight!
GET YOUR PRESALES HERE!!!!

Time: 
8pm till 6am!

Free:
Water tosses, glowsticks, candy, cds, stickers, plur!

09:00-10:00 Tony the Troll vs Loki

>> > >21+ / $FREE
>> > >
>> >
>> >http://www.illstatic.com/venue_list.php?venue=3DMezzanine#the%20415%20S=
ESSIONS
>> > >
>> > >
>> > >"DJ is my main activity, working every weekend in
>> > >clubs or festivals since 1994. I started with hard
>> > >techno-acid sounds: Drop Bass Network, Analog,
>> > >Interr-Ferrence, Force Inc, SP23, to Detroit and
>> > >experimental techno. I figured out it expressed my
>> > >late teenage aggressivity. With experience, I got
>> > >musically softer and more open-minded.
>> > >
>> > >Actually I play everything that entertains me:
>> > >minimal, deep, to kicking techno, mixed with funny
>> > our
>> > >leftfield tunes, classics, electro, no matter what
>> > it
>> > >is. That's why I hardly can describe my style. A 2h
>> > >monotone set really bores me. If I don't have fun
>> > >myself, I'm not able to please people.
>> > >DJing must be, in a way, something selfish. I shout
>> > it
>> > >loud: I don't do it for the people. I never
>> > pretended
>> > >to educate the audience, I just share a big part of
>> > >me, taking it as serious as I love it. Michael
>> > Mayer
>> > >(Kompakt records, Cologne) said: "Taking it serious
>> > >about having fun." Because 1st it's a job, and we
>> > >should never forget being paid to give pleasure to
>> > >people is a great privilege. If the risks I take in
>> > my
>> > >sets are my trademark, my priority is still to make
>> > >dance the ones who make my living. Question of
>> > >respect.
>> > >
>> > >I think I have a sharp technique, pitch-control
>> > born
>> > >in my acid times, I consider my best weapon to
>> > focus
>> > >on musical choices.
>> > >
>> > >I love playing records, it's probably the best
>> > thing I
>> > >know to do in life. I do it because it's big fun
>> > and
>> > >it makes me free, it even turns into a meditation
>> > kind
>> > >of thing. With records, nothing is planned, every
>> > >record is important. I often compares a DJ set to a
>> > >tennis game where each ball counts. But people know
>> > me
>> > >more for my voice even if I never took singing
>> > >lessons."
>> > >
>> > >
>> > >

>From: Warren Shafor <daddy_g_dj@yahoo.com>
>To: San Francisco Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: [sfraves] SASHA & STEVE PORTER @ Element Fridays [SEATTLE][21+]
>Date: Wed, 13 Apr 2005 13:26:02 -0700 (PDT)
>
>Element Fridays presents...
>
>
>
>SASHA - RENAISSANCE THE MIX COLLECTION: 10th ANNIVERSARY EDITION - 
>www.djsasha.com | The Collective | UK
>
>There are DJs who turn up, play records and make people dance. And there 
>are producers who make the dancefloor-igniting records those DJs will kill 
>for. There are very few people in dance music who can do both and Sasha is 
>the leader of the pack. Ever since he rode in on a tidal wave of adoration 
>from the North of England's explosive early 90s club scene, that magic 
>touch has made Alexander Coe one of the most famous, most revered DJ on the 
>planet.
>
>It's because of what he can do with music - the way he can make good 
>records sound better, great records sound awesome, and everything he plays 
>into his own. The way his mixes take elements from across the spectrum of 
>electronic dance, from trance, breaks, progressive and deep house, and 
>create a languidly hypnotic liquid groove. The way his understanding of 
>both melody and momentum can tease, taunt, and en-trance a dancefloor 
>before unleashing a record that will have people not just leaping up and 
>down but bursting with emotion. The best DJs know that Djing is first about 
>being able to read people and then about being able to tap into that human 
>experience and take it on a journey. Sasha has always been noted for being 
>a master at this and it is this universal appeal that he has tapped into 
>that has established his strong fanbase around the globe.
>
>Do not be mistaken, this kind of recognition does not happen overnight. 
>Born and raised in a small town in Wales, Sasha was exposed to Motown 
>records when he was just a baby and it was in the home that his talent for 
>playing the piano was developed. His stepmother forced him to take lessons. 
>At the time, he hated them, but after his first studio session - and this 
>is typical Sasha - he phoned her to say thank you. His first exposure to 
>house music was at Manchester's Hacienda; just as dance music exploded into 
>the summer of love. One visit and the young pony-tailed Sasha was hooked. 
>"The smoke machine, the strobe lights, everyone trance dancing, wearing 
>bandanas and smiley T-shirts," he smiles now. "It definitely had a fuck-you 
>attitude compared to the rest of pop music." This impact encouraged his 
>move from Wales to Manchester. His first exploration into Djing was when a 
>DJ in a local pub announced he was looking for people to play club dates. 
>Sasha volunteered and now says that he
>  'had about 30 records and basically just blagged it'.
>
>After honing his deck technique, Sasha's first big break came when he was 
>offered a residency at Stokes legendary club Shelly's. When all the other 
>DJ's were playing US House, Sasha's style was much more uplifting, and he 
>encapsulated clubbers with his mixture of piano led Italian House whilst 
>playing acapella tracks over the top. This combination alongside a wide 
>variety of anthems kept dancefloors full and elevated Sasha to hero status. 
>And, lets not forget, in a world where the DJ had too often been 
>bespectacled nerds, here the headline DJ had the looks and charm to match 
>his growing following. In classic rock n' roll style, here was a star that 
>boys wanted to hang out with and girls wanted to get just that little more 
>bit close to.
>
>Shelly's was the launch pad for the residency at Renaissance, where Sasha 
>created his niche and helped forge a new style in UK house music. At 
>Renaissance two major things happened; Sasha mixed the first ever UK DJ mix 
>album and he met John Digweed which cemented the partnership known as 
>'Northern Exposure'. Sasha and John have played together on five 
>continents, have mixed 3 'Northern Exposure' albums which have sold to over 
>1 million people worldwide. This special brother like relationship that 
>Sasha and Digweed have on the decks, is what landed them the monthly 
>residency at New York's "Twilo", following in the footsteps of Vasquez and 
>Tenaglia.
>
>The first DJ cover star - on Mixmag in early 1991 - the still shy DJ was 
>freaked. "I was so used to going to places and just hanging out. Suddenly 
>there was a stream of people coming up," he recalls. "Of course it's bound 
>to happen. You go to Liverpool and you're the first 'pin-up' DJ and you're 
>going to get shit. Frankly, It still weirds me out." Today he still remains 
>shy at heart. "I'm not very good in social situations where I'm put on the 
>spot," he says. "Like meeting new people, small talk. Just never been good 
>with that." It's this contradiction - the coyness that Alexander Coe has 
>when it comes to being Sasha, that's at the core of the Sasha myth.
>
>Although Sasha has clearly reached a celebrity status, it's his generous 
>personality, his love for his peers and of course his completely candid 
>humour that has enabled him to maintain such a likeable high profile in the 
>often-fickle world of club culture. Sasha has gone from DJ to superstar 
>status in America, where 'Sarsha' is a household name for many teenagers - 
>a gruelling three month tour took their sound further out into deepest 
>America, preaching a gospel of repetitive beats and imaginative mixing from 
>coast to coast, and right through the mid western heartland of the States. 
>A punishing gig-a-night schedule that must make nights like the opening of 
>Space in Ibiza in June seem like a holiday by comparison.
>
>There followed a move back into releasing his own music, collaborating with 
>the former Underworld mainstay, DJ Darren Emerson on 'Scorchio'. For Sasha, 
>music is his first love, and what gives him a buzz is being able to share 
>his music with others. Soon after 'Scorchio' came the first concrete proof 
>of the long-awaited, debut Sasha longplayer.
>
>'Airdrawndagger' took his nose for the dancefloor's g-spot and combined it 
>with the ears for a heartstring strumming melody, a smile inducing hook and 
>dirty great b-line to create a 69 minute symphony that sounds as wistfully 
>enchanting doing the hoovering at home as it does reaching for the lasers 
>on Saturday night. Like the best Sasha DJ set you ever heard, it has 
>melancholy mixed with euphoria, downtempo introspection mixed with jump n' 
>shout excitement.
>
>Across the 11 tracks, there's the time and space to reflect his love for 
>music that rarely gets the chance to shine in clubs, whether that's 
>punishingly gnarly breakbeats or glittering modern classical film scores. 
>It's a symphony for all ravers that grew up but never grew out of chasing 
>that buzz. A record of a journey that began, as so many did, in the smoke 
>and strobes of Manchester's Hacienda nightclub and has now taken him to 
>Midwestern stadia and around the globe.
>
>And that's an award-winning journey. The Delta Heavy Tour that consisted of 
>Sasha, John Digweed and Johnny Van M and took in 35 gigs between March and 
>May last year was recently awarded Best Dance Event at the Dancestar Awards 
>2003. It was a series of gigs that took DJing into unprecedented waters - 
>two mammoth tour buses, visuals by the company behind hit movie 7even's 
>intense opening credit sequence, and crowds of up to 15,000 clubbers 
>crammed into arenas, warehouses and theatres across the United States. The 
>success was such that Sasha and the boys will be back on the road to do it 
>all again, bigger, better, badder come Spring next year.
>
>After a summer of dates across the globe, including sets at Homelands, 
>Creamfields, Dance Valley, and hosting a stage in the forest of the Mount 
>Fuji Festival, Sasha has been in the studio again, working on new plans and 
>ideas, and most recently remixing the forthcoming UNKLE single. Expect a 
>few surprises over the coming months, for the man simply refuses to stand 
>still.
>
>also featuring...
>
>
>STEVE PORTER - Fade Records | New York, New York
>
>So Fresh, So Clean could be the perfect title for Steve Porter. It can 
>easily describe his personality, his look and more importantly his music. 
>2003 was another banner year for the boy wonder with his big time single 
>Definite Form and his now classic remix of Amber's Anyway. Adding to 
>that his underground side projects Agent 001, HDF & Bons and his looming 
>artist album, his music sees huge support across the spectrum of DJs from 
>Sasha & John Digweed to Carl Cox to Mark Farina and Derek Carter.
>
>Steve has now made a huge mark with his techno edged house productions. His 
>studio work was only one facet of Steve's two prong attack. His DJing is 
>where he really rocks the funky beats. His move to New York City from 
>Boston has only put more fuel to the fire. Along with dates across the 
>country and tours with Sasha (Airdrawndagger Tour), Sander Kleinenberg 
>(Essential Mix Tour) and Chris Fortier, Steve is in demand from Tokyo to 
>Tampa. With over 20 remixes to his credit, his Agent 001 & HDF & Bons 
>projects busting down doors, he is leading way for the next wave of 
>America's future stars.
>
>
>CHAD OWEN - Alphabet City | Sonic City UK | Seattle, WA
>
>
>THIS EVENT WILL FEATURE SASHA IN BOTH ROOMS VIA LIVE VIDEO & SOUND FEEDS 
>THROUGHOUT THE CLUB!!
>
>
>Friday | April 22nd | 2005
>
>Element Seattle
>332 5th Avenue North
>Seattle, WA 98109
>
>Doors @ 9pm | $22/$27 Pre-Sales Available @ www.TicketsWest.com and at 
>Platinum Records, Lights & Sound (Seattle & Portland) | 21+ w/ ID | 
>206.441.7579
>
>www.elementseattle.com
>

is one of the VERY few things I miss about the DC metro area...ok, let me 
recant - the Baltimore area (a mere 30 minutes north of DC). Anything in the 
majority of the bars there, from booze to water, was pretty damn cheap. And 
the drinks in "cHarm city" (as it's known), are retardedly strong. The only 
place I've ever found 16oz Red Bull & Vodkas for $2.50 - you cannot fuck 
with that.

>>> > >Subject: [sfraves] Miss Kitten at Mezzanine
>>> > 4.30.05___ FREE
>>> > >Date: Fri, 11 Mar 2005 09:24:17 -0800 (PST)
>>> > >
>>> > >I cannot believe this is going to be a free show!
>>> > Just
>>> > >found it in my inbox and thought I'd share it with
>>> > you
>>> > >guys. Hope to see you there!
>>> > >
>>> > >love, Heidi
>>> >
>>> >~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>>> > >
>>> > >Saturday April 30th
>>> > >blasthaus presenté
>>> > >Miss Kittin
>>> > >at Mezzanine
>>> > >10pm until 2am
>>> > >21+ / $FREE
>>> > >
>>> >
>>> >http://www.illstatic.com/venue_list.php?venue=Mezzanine#the%20415%20SESSIONS
>>> > >
>>> > >
>>> > >"DJ is my main activity, working every weekend in
>>> > >clubs or festivals since 1994. I started with hard
>>> > >techno-acid sounds: Drop Bass Network, Analog,
>>> > >Interr-Ferrence, Force Inc, SP23, to Detroit and
>>> > >experimental techno. I figured out it expressed my
>>> > >late teenage aggressivity. With experience, I got
>>> > >musically softer and more open-minded.
>>> > >
>>> > >Actually I play everything that entertains me:
>>> > >minimal, deep, to kicking techno, mixed with funny
>>> > our
>>> > >leftfield tunes, classics, electro, no matter what
>>> > it
>>> > >is. That's why I hardly can describe my style. A 2h
>>> > >monotone set really bores me. If I don't have fun
>>> > >myself, I'm not able to please people.
>>> > >DJing must be, in a way, something selfish. I shout
>>> > it
>>> > >loud: I don't do it for the people. I never
>>> > pretended
>>> > >to educate the audience, I just share a big part of
>>> > >me, taking it as serious as I love it. Michael
>>> > Mayer
>>> > >(Kompakt records, Cologne) said: "Taking it serious
>>> > >about having fun." Because 1st it's a job, and we
>>> > >should never forget being paid to give pleasure to
>>> > >people is a great privilege. If the risks I take in
>>> > my
>>> > >sets are my trademark, my priority is still to make
>>> > >dance the ones who make my living. Question of
>>> > >respect.
>>> > >
>>> > >I think I have a sharp technique, pitch-control
>>> > born
>>> > >in my acid times, I consider my best weapon to
>>> > focus
>>> > >on musical choices.
>>> > >
>>> > >I love playing records, it's probably the best
>>> > thing I
>>> > >know to do in life. I do it because it's big fun
>>> > and
>>> > >it makes me free, it even turns into a meditation
>>> > kind
>>> > >of thing. With records, nothing is planned, every
>>> > >record is important. I often compares a DJ set to a
>>> > >tennis game where each ball counts. But people know
>>> > me
>>> > >more for my voice even if I never took singing
>>> > >lessons."
>>> > >
>>> > >
>>> > >
>>> >

NEW YORK (Reuters) - A U.S. Air National Guard pilot and a crew member have=
=20
been arrested for using *official military missions* to smuggle millions of=
=20
dollars worth Ecstasy into the United States, federal authorities said on=
=20
Wednesday=20

Drug Enforcement Administration Special Agent Christopher Giovino, who head=
s=20
the New York organized drug enforcement strike force, said the arrests were=
=20
part of a long-term, ongoing investigation. He described the men as=20
transporters in a bigger conspiracy but said he could not provide any other=
=20
details.=20

Capt. Franklin Rodriguez, a pilot of the U.S. Air Force C-5A "Galaxy" cargo=
=20
aircraft, and Master Sgt. John Fong, in charge of loading and unloading=20
cargo, were arrested on Tuesday and expected to be presented in Manhattan=
=20
federal court on Wednesday night.=20

Officials said some 290,000 Ecstasy pills were found in the defendants'=20
luggage upon their return to the United States. According to the Drug=20
Enforcement Administration Web site, an Ecstasy tablet typically sells=20
between $20 and $30 on the street and its value can be as high as $40.=20

During questioning by law enforcement authorities, the men admitted to=20
authorities that they had also transported Ecstasy on previous military=20
flights, the complaint stated.=20

The men are charged with one count of conspiracy to import Ecstasy into the=
=20
United States and one count of conspiracy to distribute the drug. If=20
convicted, the two men face a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison and a=
=20
$1 million fine on each count.=20

According to the complaint filed in Manhattan federal court, Rodriguez was=
=20
the pilot and Fong was the loadmaster on a U.S. Air Force C-5A aircraft las=
t=20
week from the Stewart Air National Guard Base in Newburgh, New York, on an=
=20
official mission to deliver training supplies to the Republic of Georgia.=
=20

On their return, the crew stopped in Germany where the two defendants went=
=20
to a hotel room and loaded packages of Ecstasy into their luggage, the=20
complaint said.=20

On Tuesday, after the men landed at the Stewart Air National Guard Base,=20
federal law enforcement agents searched their luggage and found 28 large=20
bags filled with Ecstasy tablets.=20

Law enforcement agents who interviewed Rodriguez said he admitted=20
transporting Ecstasy on military flights on a number of other occasions and=
=20
had taken the drug to his Bronx apartment for distribution.=20

Fong told agents he transported pills with Rodriguez on three prior=20
occasions and was paid $10,000 for each trip. Authorities would not comment=
=20
on who had paid Fong.

------=_Part_6638_29452301.1113498123629--

Warren Shafor <daddy_g_dj@yahoo.com> wrote:
+++G R O U N D A T I O N+++05/07/05


S T I X N S T O N Z / U R B A N - B R E A K S . C O M P R E S E N T

G R O U N D A T I O N

SATURDAY, MAY 7th, 2K5



FEATURING...


INFLUENCE - www.nfluence.net - SAN FRANCISCO

Representing straight out of San Francisco, Influence has been damaging dance floors with his versatile array of brokenbeat since 1998. His distinguished style combines long precise mixes, cross fader control with bass driven breaks. Influence has shared spotlights with some of brokenbeats most respected artists such as Chris Carter, Auotobots, Lobudg, Jhz, Trona, Aubl, Future Funk Squad, Stakka, Felix The Dog, Gridlok & Madame Mercury. In 2004, Influence started producing brokenbeat with the emphasis on funky, bass driven breaks. 


DJ CANTOS - www.djcantos.com - SACRAMENTO

In just a few short years, Sean Akio Canty a.k.a. Cantos, has advanced to the vanguard of the Sacramento dance music scene. With roots in mixing records reaching back to the underground hip-hop scene of 1992, Cantos possesses a level of skill and professionalism behind the decks that few can claim. His sound  a mixture of deep, progressive beats, dark breaks and smooth vocal tracks  demands control of the dance floor and his live sets can only be described as inspiring. His ability to read individual dancers and understand their desires never fails to satisfy each one. 

Beginning in Sacramento as a resident for a local underground production crew, Cantos is now a regular guest at The Rage Nightclub and has recently acquired residency at Twisted Thursdays located inside The Tower Club. With support from Sacramentos most respected production crews , as well as U.K.s Primalsounds.com, broadcasts of his internet show ProgressiveSoul are streamed live through selekta.com and reaches audiences worldwide. Cantos has utilized opportunities to share the decks with accomplished performers such as DJ Micro, DJ Dragnfly, Gianni, East Coast Boogiemen, MTV's DJ Icon, Aphrodite, Moda, Ariel Cybana, Madame Mercury, Mars & Mystre, Paul Lancaster, Gabriel Black and DJ Dara...


UNDECIDED - www.urban-breaks.com - SEATTLE

In early 2004 Chris aka Undecided moved from Sacramento, where he was responsibile for throwing many breaks shows and hosting weekly breaks nights, to Seattle, where he is quickly making a name for himself. He began deejaying in early 1998 and his skills have rapidly evolved, incorporating into his sets scratches and an unmatched energy, and earning him the opportunity to play with many well known and talented artists such as uberzone, DJ Rap, Trona, Baby Anne, A;Dubl, and influenze. Undecided is well known for his ability to make you groove to dirty funk basslines.


SOULKID - www.urban-breaks.com - SEATTLE

Hailing orginally from Orlando, FL...Soulkid has made Seattle his homebase for the past three years to push his funky Florida Breaks sound all along the west coast. Blending the Miami bass and the female vocal hooks, Soulkid keeps with the trademark of the Florida sound to move the soul. Influenced by breaks producers like Fixx, John Digweed, BT, Bassbin Twins, Huda Hudia, Brad Smith, Soulkid brings 17 years of experience behind the decks with him and a stage presence to match.


BISCUIT - www.urban-breaks.com - SEATTLE

Combining Nuskool, UK, and Funky Breaks, Biscuit has been bringing the best in breaks to dancefloors throughout the Northwest for the last 3 years. In this relatively short amount of time, Biscuit has quickly distinguished himself in the Seattle breaks scene with precise mixing and an enthusiastic stage presence. His talent behind the decks has lead him to share line-ups with numerious breakbeat icons and turntabalism geniuses such as Aquasky vs Masterblaster, Deekline, DJ Fixx, DJ Craze, the Young Punx, Factor e, and Disco D.


PALMER & POOKA - www.urban-breaks.com - OLYMPIA

updating bio

LOKI - www.urban-breaks.com - SEATTLE

updating bio

KENAZ - www.urban-breaks.com - OLYMPIA

updating bio

DJ DZY - SIT N SPIN - PORTLAND

updating bio

JOE NEMO - PZT 503 - PORTLAND

updating bio

URSUS - www.ursus.divitu.com - ASHLAND

updating bio

DJ SE7EN - ShortbusmonkeyS - MEDFORD

updating bio

MATTHEW THOMAS - ShortbusmonkeyS - MEDFORD

updating bio

WOOKIE - Shortbusmonkeys - MEDFORD

updating bio


TITRATION - www.monkeytek.com - ASHLAND

updating bio

Cafe style munchie bar with enough ENERGY DRINKS to supply an army and enough munchies to satisfy just about anyone.

We will have a beer garden for those 21+W/ID <-BOTH VENUES

Event Description:

Come join AuraSF for another evening of kick ass progressive house in a =
no stress atmosphere. Plenty of parking, drink specials including $2 =
beers and $3 wells and free video games are part of the AuraExperience =
we bring to you.=20

Guest visualists at Sublounge this month features paintings and =
projections by Alison Blickle, Chris Fabbri & Crystal Ann Platt=20

6-8pm :: happy hours (art show curated by Fabbri)
8-10pm :: Fabbri (doublefresh)
10-11pm :: Koroma (AuraSF:Koroma.com)
11-1am :: Pistachio (AuraSF)

Please support our local artists by visiting their websites!

There is no cover all night so make it an inexpensive night out on the =
town with some bangin' beats and great people!

Venue: SubLounge

Address: 628 20th Street at Third Street, San Francisco, CA

Time: 6pm - 1am

Cover: Free All Night, 21+

> NEW YORK (Reuters) - A U.S. Air National Guard pilot and a crew member ha=
ve
> been arrested for using *official military missions* to smuggle millions =
of
> dollars worth Ecstasy into the United States, federal authorities said on
> Wednesday
>=20
> Drug Enforcement Administration Special Agent Christopher Giovino, who he=
ads
> the New York organized drug enforcement strike force, said the arrests we=
re
> part of a long-term, ongoing investigation. He described the men as
> transporters in a bigger conspiracy but said he could not provide any oth=
er
> details.
>=20
> Capt. Franklin Rodriguez, a pilot of the U.S. Air Force C-5A "Galaxy" car=
go
> aircraft, and Master Sgt. John Fong, in charge of loading and unloading
> cargo, were arrested on Tuesday and expected to be presented in Manhattan
> federal court on Wednesday night.
>=20
> Officials said some 290,000 Ecstasy pills were found in the defendants'
> luggage upon their return to the United States. According to the Drug
> Enforcement Administration Web site, an Ecstasy tablet typically sells
> between $20 and $30 on the street and its value can be as high as $40.
>=20
> During questioning by law enforcement authorities, the men admitted to
> authorities that they had also transported Ecstasy on previous military
> flights, the complaint stated.
>=20
> The men are charged with one count of conspiracy to import Ecstasy into t=
he
> United States and one count of conspiracy to distribute the drug. If
> convicted, the two men face a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison and =
a
> $1 million fine on each count.
>=20
> According to the complaint filed in Manhattan federal court, Rodriguez wa=
s
> the pilot and Fong was the loadmaster on a U.S. Air Force C-5A aircraft l=
ast
> week from the Stewart Air National Guard Base in Newburgh, New York, on a=
n
> official mission to deliver training supplies to the Republic of Georgia.
>=20
> On their return, the crew stopped in Germany where the two defendants wen=
t
> to a hotel room and loaded packages of Ecstasy into their luggage, the
> complaint said.
>=20
> On Tuesday, after the men landed at the Stewart Air National Guard Base,
> federal law enforcement agents searched their luggage and found 28 large
> bags filled with Ecstasy tablets.
>=20
> Law enforcement agents who interviewed Rodriguez said he admitted
> transporting Ecstasy on military flights on a number of other occasions a=
nd
> had taken the drug to his Bronx apartment for distribution.
>=20
> Fong told agents he transported pills with Rodriguez on three prior
> occasions and was paid $10,000 for each trip. Authorities would not comme=
nt
> on who had paid Fong.
>=20
>=20
