--=====================_10086563==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit


"It's All Gone Pete Tong": Last night a (deaf) DJ saved my life

SALON.COM


In addition to possessing the most confusing title of the year, Canadian 
filmmaker Michael Dowse's high-energy dance-club saga 
<http://www.itsallgonepetetong.com/>"It's All Gone Pete Tong" arrives in an 
elaborate package of spoof and deception that should win the admiration of 
any practical-joke connoisseur. English comedian Paul Kaye has a 
star-making role as one Frankie Wilde, a deranged Cockney exile who's more 
or less the Keith Richards of the cocaine-drenched club scene on Ibiza, the 
über-trendy Spanish resort island. (The movie's title, by the way, derives 
from Cockney rhyming slang and also name-checks a different well-known DJ, 
and that's all the help you're getting from me.)

As other jet-setting DJs like Carl Cox and Paul van Dyk testify in the 
movie, Frankie's hard-driving dance mixes, hard-partying ways and maniacal 
stage antics revolutionized Ibiza nightlife in the late '90s, until the 
combination of a genetic eardrum issue and all those pumping beats rendered 
Frankie stone deaf. He then falls into the embrace of the Coke Badger, a 
fuzzy, demonic beast whose love requires you to shovel white powder up your 
nose by the kilo. (The Internet campaign for this movie is so extensive 
that even the Badger has his own <http://www.cokebadger.com/>Web site, 
complete with sinister purring noises.)

But thanks to a sexy Spanish lip-reading instructor named Penelope (Beatriz 
Batarda) and a pair of speakers with built-in flip-flops on top, Frankie 
learns to feel the beat he can't hear. He gets off the snow, if not the 
Scotch and ciggies, and rises again to the pinnacle of his profession -- 
before he and Penelope disappear from Ibiza for good. Is he now writing his 
memoirs (or, as Frankie himself observes, writing a pamphlet, since a book 
would take too long)? Running a record shop in Oxford? Busking for change 
on the streets of New York? Holed up in a tropical hideaway plotting his 
next comeback? Rumors fly, but nobody knows for sure.

Frankly, I think you'd have to be an idiot to watch 10 minutes of this 
movie -- what with Frankie's drunken monologue about the many uses of 
"spunk," or the pompous meanderings of Eric Banning (Dan Antopolski), a 
scholar who has supposedly written several books about Frankie's career -- 
without understanding that it's a full-on piss-take, as the Brits would 
say. But the packed houses of boogieing Ibiza nubiles are real enough, and 
trashily exciting, and indeed, if you start spelunking on the Web, you'll 
find all kinds of testimonials to the extraordinary career of 
<http://www.frankiewilde.com/>Frankie Wilde.

Chat rooms about pop music, movies and dance culture are packed with 
Frankie questions (many of them strikingly similar in tone): Have you heard 
about the amazing deaf DJ? How can I find his records? Even Alfonse and 
Horst, the two clownish Austrians who serve as Frankie's chief musical 
assistants, have a Web site for their post-Frankie outfit 
<http://www.ladderhause.com/>Ladder Hause. No one ever went broke by 
overestimating public ignorance, it's said, and a surprising number of 
critics and real human beings have been taken in by "Pete Tong" already.

I have one word of advice for those marketing mavens who constructed this 
game: Amazon. If Frankie Wilde really had all these hit records, albeit 
quasi-obscure Euroclub mixes, wouldn't some of them be for sale somewhere? 
Anyway, Paul Kaye gives an amazing performance, the first half of the movie 
is crudely hilarious, and the love story with the lithe and lovely Batarda 
works surprisingly well. (Kate Magowan and Mike Wilmot get special props 
for their roles as Frankie's Dolce-and-Gabbana-laden trashbag wife and 
skeezeball, bottle-tanned manager, respectively.)

Director Michael Dowse (whose previous movie, "Fubar," took a similar 
approach to heavy metal) blew through New York this week, and I grabbed him 
for a few minutes. He insisted on staying on message, at least officially. 
When I asked him if he wanted to discuss the real deal behind "Pete Tong," 
he said, "You mean the fact that I'm not really Canadian? Go ahead. Say 
whatever you want to about that."

No, but really, Mike, what kind of movie is this?

It's a bio piece about an amazing DJ. It's a comedy, too, but I think 
comedy is a great way to treat it. Something as tragic as Frankie's story 
requires a sense of humor. I'm sick of movies that take a dour approach to 
tragic subject matter. I wanted to make a film that the guy himself would 
have appreciated.

Um, OK, let's move on. You shot in real Ibiza clubs with real crowds. That 
must have been an essential part of the production. Without that, the movie 
wouldn't have worked at all.

Yeah, that was the element I was most nervous about. We needed access to 
the clubs to make it feel authentic. Otherwise, we would have died. You 
know, our musical coordinator was Lol Hammond, who's a part of that club 
world. He was our shepherd, and people were like, "Well, if Lol's doing it, 
it must be all right."

My worst nightmare was having those club scenes look like a beer 
commercial. You know: "Now everybody have fun!" So the cast and crew had to 
be portable and adaptable, no big circus, no trailers. We had to shoot on 
the spot and we had to shoot fast. No way were we going to try to re-create 
an Ibiza nightclub on a set. I hate movies where they do that, like in "Go" 
or whatever, where they hire a warehouse and put 200 extras in it. It 
always looks so fake.

Tell us about the Coke Badger. He's the latest in a line of fuzzy, scary 
creatures in film.

Yes he is!

I was thinking about the rabbits, of course. In 
<http://www.salon.com/ent/movies/review/2001/06/13/sexy_beast/>"Sexy Beast" 
and in 
<http://www.salon.com/ent/movies/review/2001/10/30/donnie_darko/>"Donnie 
Darko."

Yeah, but nobody uses them for comedy. I really wanted the beast to attack 
and kill, but also to be a comic character. I guess he's a gag: Cocaine is 
a very badgering drug. But we've all seen those preachy movies about drugs, 
where four addicts end up in the fetal position. Yes, drugs are bad, but I 
didn't want that to be the message of the film.

Obviously Paul Kaye is the heart and soul of this film, and it feels like a 
breakout performance. He's well known in Britain but not at all over here. 
How'd you find him?

Well, Paul came very well recommended, so we exchanged tapes and mutually 
disliked each other's work. [Laughter from Kaye, who is nearby.] Seriously, 
I love that he tends to "improvise toward the stupid," as he puts it, which 
was just perfect for the character of Frankie.

Isn't this movie a tough sell in the United States? In Britain and Europe, 
club music is huge and DJs are big stars. But it's still a small niche 
audience in America.

Yeah, well, it's harder in some ways. But you don't have to know anything 
about club music, or like it, to enjoy the film. The club kids are our core 
audience -- we just had a screening with BPM magazine, and they went nuts 
for it. But I also had a 70-year-old couple at the Aspen Film Festival tell 
me it was the perfect movie. They were like: "We don't listen to that kind 
of music, but there we were, tappin' our toes!"

"It's All Gone Pete Tong" opens April 15 in New York, April 29 in Los 
Angeles and May 13 in at least 24 other U.S. cities.




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

FRIDAY APRIL 15
HYBRID(dj set) at Cellar Bar, with Serge Devant opening
  Yea, you heard me....
this Friday we(East Side Productions) welcome 2 of the coolest and most talented guys in the business to play a special dj set for us at Cellar Bar....Chris Healing and Mike Truman...known to most people as HYBRID!

Hybrid have seen it all and done it all. In 2000, Hybrid traversed the length and breadth of America as guests of Moby on his tour. He then asked Hybrid to perform at his final London date of the year - Wembley Arena. This marked Hybrid's and Moby's largest indoor performance.
In 2003 Hybrid released Morning Sci-Fi which included collaborations with NYC based DJ/remixer John Creamer, Kirsty Hawkshaw, the legendary Peter Hook (New Order) and The Hermitage String Orchestra, St Petersburg.

They just dont stop, they are still working on numerous projects and we all cant wait to see what they come up with next!!!!

Come on down to Cellar Bar to check them out for a VERY rare appearance. How many times do you think you will have the opportunity to see a group like Hybrid play for FREE in a 200 person intimate and gorgeous lounge?
I think we all know the answer to that one....see you Friday ;)

>
> "It's All Gone Pete Tong": Last night a (deaf) DJ saved my life
>
> SALON.COM
>
>
> In addition to possessing the most confusing title of the year, Canadian
> filmmaker Michael Dowse's high-energy dance-club saga
> <http://www.itsallgonepetetong.com/>"It's All Gone Pete Tong" arrives in
> an
> elaborate package of spoof and deception that should win the admiration of
> any practical-joke connoisseur. English comedian Paul Kaye has a
> star-making role as one Frankie Wilde, a deranged Cockney exile who's more
> or less the Keith Richards of the cocaine-drenched club scene on Ibiza,
> the
> über-trendy Spanish resort island. (The movie's title, by the way, derives
> from Cockney rhyming slang and also name-checks a different well-known DJ,
> and that's all the help you're getting from me.)
>
> As other jet-setting DJs like Carl Cox and Paul van Dyk testify in the
> movie, Frankie's hard-driving dance mixes, hard-partying ways and maniacal
> stage antics revolutionized Ibiza nightlife in the late '90s, until the
> combination of a genetic eardrum issue and all those pumping beats
> rendered
> Frankie stone deaf. He then falls into the embrace of the Coke Badger, a
> fuzzy, demonic beast whose love requires you to shovel white powder up
> your
> nose by the kilo. (The Internet campaign for this movie is so extensive
> that even the Badger has his own <http://www.cokebadger.com/>Web site,
> complete with sinister purring noises.)
>
> But thanks to a sexy Spanish lip-reading instructor named Penelope
> (Beatriz
> Batarda) and a pair of speakers with built-in flip-flops on top, Frankie
> learns to feel the beat he can't hear. He gets off the snow, if not the
> Scotch and ciggies, and rises again to the pinnacle of his profession --
> before he and Penelope disappear from Ibiza for good. Is he now writing
> his
> memoirs (or, as Frankie himself observes, writing a pamphlet, since a book
> would take too long)? Running a record shop in Oxford? Busking for change
> on the streets of New York? Holed up in a tropical hideaway plotting his
> next comeback? Rumors fly, but nobody knows for sure.
>
> Frankly, I think you'd have to be an idiot to watch 10 minutes of this
> movie -- what with Frankie's drunken monologue about the many uses of
> "spunk," or the pompous meanderings of Eric Banning (Dan Antopolski), a
> scholar who has supposedly written several books about Frankie's career --
> without understanding that it's a full-on piss-take, as the Brits would
> say. But the packed houses of boogieing Ibiza nubiles are real enough, and
> trashily exciting, and indeed, if you start spelunking on the Web, you'll
> find all kinds of testimonials to the extraordinary career of
> <http://www.frankiewilde.com/>Frankie Wilde.
>
> Chat rooms about pop music, movies and dance culture are packed with
> Frankie questions (many of them strikingly similar in tone): Have you
> heard
> about the amazing deaf DJ? How can I find his records? Even Alfonse and
> Horst, the two clownish Austrians who serve as Frankie's chief musical
> assistants, have a Web site for their post-Frankie outfit
> <http://www.ladderhause.com/>Ladder Hause. No one ever went broke by
> overestimating public ignorance, it's said, and a surprising number of
> critics and real human beings have been taken in by "Pete Tong" already.
>
> I have one word of advice for those marketing mavens who constructed this
> game: Amazon. If Frankie Wilde really had all these hit records, albeit
> quasi-obscure Euroclub mixes, wouldn't some of them be for sale somewhere?
> Anyway, Paul Kaye gives an amazing performance, the first half of the
> movie
> is crudely hilarious, and the love story with the lithe and lovely Batarda
> works surprisingly well. (Kate Magowan and Mike Wilmot get special props
> for their roles as Frankie's Dolce-and-Gabbana-laden trashbag wife and
> skeezeball, bottle-tanned manager, respectively.)
>
> Director Michael Dowse (whose previous movie, "Fubar," took a similar
> approach to heavy metal) blew through New York this week, and I grabbed
> him
> for a few minutes. He insisted on staying on message, at least officially.
> When I asked him if he wanted to discuss the real deal behind "Pete Tong,"
> he said, "You mean the fact that I'm not really Canadian? Go ahead. Say
> whatever you want to about that."
>
> No, but really, Mike, what kind of movie is this?
>
> It's a bio piece about an amazing DJ. It's a comedy, too, but I think
> comedy is a great way to treat it. Something as tragic as Frankie's story
> requires a sense of humor. I'm sick of movies that take a dour approach to
> tragic subject matter. I wanted to make a film that the guy himself would
> have appreciated.
>
> Um, OK, let's move on. You shot in real Ibiza clubs with real crowds. That
> must have been an essential part of the production. Without that, the
> movie
> wouldn't have worked at all.
>
> Yeah, that was the element I was most nervous about. We needed access to
> the clubs to make it feel authentic. Otherwise, we would have died. You
> know, our musical coordinator was Lol Hammond, who's a part of that club
> world. He was our shepherd, and people were like, "Well, if Lol's doing
> it,
> it must be all right."
>
> My worst nightmare was having those club scenes look like a beer
> commercial. You know: "Now everybody have fun!" So the cast and crew had
> to
> be portable and adaptable, no big circus, no trailers. We had to shoot on
> the spot and we had to shoot fast. No way were we going to try to
> re-create
> an Ibiza nightclub on a set. I hate movies where they do that, like in
> "Go"
> or whatever, where they hire a warehouse and put 200 extras in it. It
> always looks so fake.
>
> Tell us about the Coke Badger. He's the latest in a line of fuzzy, scary
> creatures in film.
>
> Yes he is!
>
> I was thinking about the rabbits, of course. In
> <http://www.salon.com/ent/movies/review/2001/06/13/sexy_beast/>"Sexy
> Beast"
> and in
> <http://www.salon.com/ent/movies/review/2001/10/30/donnie_darko/>"Donnie
> Darko."
>
> Yeah, but nobody uses them for comedy. I really wanted the beast to attack
> and kill, but also to be a comic character. I guess he's a gag: Cocaine is
> a very badgering drug. But we've all seen those preachy movies about
> drugs,
> where four addicts end up in the fetal position. Yes, drugs are bad, but I
> didn't want that to be the message of the film.
>
> Obviously Paul Kaye is the heart and soul of this film, and it feels like
> a
> breakout performance. He's well known in Britain but not at all over here.
> How'd you find him?
>
> Well, Paul came very well recommended, so we exchanged tapes and mutually
> disliked each other's work. [Laughter from Kaye, who is nearby.]
> Seriously,
> I love that he tends to "improvise toward the stupid," as he puts it,
> which
> was just perfect for the character of Frankie.
>
> Isn't this movie a tough sell in the United States? In Britain and Europe,
> club music is huge and DJs are big stars. But it's still a small niche
> audience in America.
>
> Yeah, well, it's harder in some ways. But you don't have to know anything
> about club music, or like it, to enjoy the film. The club kids are our
> core
> audience -- we just had a screening with BPM magazine, and they went nuts
> for it. But I also had a 70-year-old couple at the Aspen Film Festival
> tell
> me it was the perfect movie. They were like: "We don't listen to that kind
> of music, but there we were, tappin' our toes!"
>
> "It's All Gone Pete Tong" opens April 15 in New York, April 29 in Los
> Angeles and May 13 in at least 24 other U.S. cities.
>
>
>
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>

> The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the
> money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the
> world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
> -Hunter S. Thompson

> ghosts will do it after?"

> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

matthew johnson said:
> hey guys,

Subject: [sfraves] nrr: Republican call for Japanese American Internment Memorial

yes, i'm talking about it again.  ;)

-b

Emotional call for internment memorials=20
Bakersfield Republican bucks the White House=20
- Edward Epstein, Chronicle Washington Bureau
Friday, April 15, 2005=20

Washington -- One of California's most powerful Republican House
members is clashing with the Bush administration, which opposes his
proposal to authorize $38 million in federal funds to preserve the
camps where Japanese Americans were interned during World War II.

An emotional Rep. Bill Thomas, R-Bakersfield, choked up a few times
Thursday as he presented his bill at a House Resources subcommittee
meeting and recalled how the passage of years was taking away those
who lived through a dark episode in U.S. history.

First, the 63-year-old Ways and Means Committee chairman remembered
post- World War II Japanese American friends whose parents had a hard
time talking about their bitter wartime years.

And he recalled two men who died recently. Fred Korematsu, who died
March 30, was the man who defied President Franklin D. Roosevelt's
internment order, a stand that led to a historic U.S. Supreme Court
ruling upholding FDR's orders. The late Rep. Robert Matsui,
D-Sacramento, who died on New Year's Day, was sent to the Tule Lake
camp in far Northern California with his parents as an infant, and was
one of Thomas' original co-sponsors for the legislation.

"This legislation is the absolute bottom line of what we should do,''
Thomas said.

President Ronald Reagan and Congress formally apologized in 1988 for
the treatment of the 120,000 Japanese Americans who were sent to 10
camps. The internment represents "an era of history that needs to be
remembered. A lot of the sites are disappearing,'' along with the
surviving internees, many of whom are in their 70s or 80s, Thomas
said.

Thomas also is sponsoring the bill because of his long friendship with
former Democratic state Assemblyman Fred Mori, who is the immediate
past president of the San Francisco-based Japanese American Citizens
League. The political odd couple were roommates in Sacramento when
they both served in the Assembly in the late 1970s.

"It was an unusual relationship politically,'' Mori recalled. "We've
been friends ever since.''

Co-sponsors from internment camps

Among Thomas' co-sponsors are Matsui's widow and successor, Rep. Doris
Matsui, D-Sacramento, who was born in the Poston internment camp in
Arizona, and Rep. Mike Honda, D-San Jose, who spent his early
childhood in a Colorado camp.

Thomas' bill would require nonprofit groups and local governments to
come up with a 25 percent match for federal funds. It would cover 10
internment camps, including Tule Lake and Manzanar in California and a
host of associated sites, including 17 assembly centers in such places
as the old Tanforan racetrack in San Bruno, and at sites in Stockton,
Salinas and Sacramento.

The money would go to buy property now in private hands, help restore
historic buildings and perhaps create museums and visitors centers.

The National Park Service, which would administer the program, says it
has nothing against commemorating the internment episode. But
officials says the agency can't afford a new program mandated by
Congress, especially in a time of tight budgets and huge maintenance
backlogs at federal park properties across the country.

"With the emphasis we have placed on the president's initiative to
reduce the deferred maintenance backlog, it has become more important
than ever to avoid authorizing funding for non-National Park Service
projects that would draw funds from the Park Service's budget,'' said
the service's acting deputy director, Michael Snyder.

Park Service proposals

He said the Park Service already has made the Manzanar camp site on
Highway 395 in the eastern Sierra into a historic site whose visitors'
center attracts 80,000 people a year and that it administers a
five-year-old memorial to Japanese American patriotism during World
War II just a few blocks from the Capitol building. He suggested that
instead of Thomas' proposal the Park Service could work with local
groups to develop programs at the camp sites and publish a guidebook
to internment sites.

That suggestion didn't go over well with the legislation's advocates.

"By itself, I find that insulting,'' Gerald Yamada, national
coordinator of the Japanese American National Heritage Coalition, told
the subcommittee. "The plans don't address the hardship and sacrifice
and the lessons we seek to preserve. Left to their own volition, I'm
not encouraged they would do more than they're doing.''

The subcommittee did not vote on the bill, although passage is likely
when it does. As for the final showdown between Thomas and the Park
Service, congressional aides said they wouldn't bet against the
chairman of one of Congress' most powerful committees, given his deep
commitment to the idea.

'We are the living legacy'

If the proposal ever becomes law, such groups as the Tule Lake
Committee -- which is already involved in preserving the campsite near
the Oregon state line and in developing programs teaching
multicultural understanding -- are getting ready.

"The money we could get would be a start'' toward building a museum of
conscience, said San Franciscan Pat Shiono, who chairs the Tule Lake
group's preservation committee.

The group has reclaimed three wooden sheds that were camp barracks,
which the federal government gave away after the war, and wants to
restore them. It also wants to take over existing war-era buildings
now used by Caltrans and the Bureau of Reclamation.

Tule Lake was the toughest of the camps because it housed the
"no-nos,'' Japanese Americans who refused to declare undivided loyalty
to America, feeling the question was an insult to their citizenship.
The Army guarded the camp, and there was scattered violence, the
committee's history says.

"We are very attached to that site,'' said Shiono, who was born after
the war to parents who were interned. "We know the camps changed the
lives of all Japanese Americans. We are the living legacy of a proud
group of immigrants who were imprisoned without charge.''

E-mail Edward Epstein at eepstein@sfchronicle.com.
--=20

Subject: [sfraves] LTJ Bukem & MC Conrad - Thurs April 21, SF

Thursday April 21, 2005
Progression Sessions touches down in San Francisco!

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  It's All Bullshit....

--=====================_833738==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


http://www.cnn.com/2005/TECH/science/04/14/mit.prank.reut/

CAMBRIDGE, Massachusetts (Reuters) -- In a victory for pranksters at
the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a bunch of
computer-generated gibberish masquerading as an academic paper has been
accepted at a scientific conference.

Jeremy Stribling said Thursday that he and two fellow MIT graduate
students questioned the standards of some academic conferences, so they
wrote a computer program to generate research papers complete with
"context-free grammar," charts and diagrams.

The trio submitted two of the randomly assembled papers to the World
Multi-Conference on Systemics, Cybernetics and Informatics (WMSCI),
scheduled to be held July 10-13 in Orlando, Florida.

To their surprise, one of the papers -- "Rooter: A Methodology for the
Typical Unification of Access Points and Redundancy" -- was accepted
for presentation.

The prank recalled a 1996 hoax in which New York University physicist
Alan Sokal succeeded in getting an entire paper with a mix of truths,
falsehoods, non sequiturs and otherwise meaningless mumbo-jumbo
published in the quarterly journal Social Text, published by Duke
University Press.

Stribling said he and his colleagues only learned about the Social Text
affair after submitting their paper.

"Rooter" features such mind-bending gems as: "the model for our
heuristic consists of four independent components: simulated annealing,
active networks, flexible modalities, and the study of reinforcement
learning" and "We implemented our scatter/gather I/O server in
Simula-67, augmented with opportunistically pipelined extensions."

Stribling said the trio targeted WMSCI because it is notorious within
the field of computer science for sending copious e-mails that solicit
admissions to the conference.

The idea of a fake submission was to counter "fake conferences...which
exist only to make money," explained Stribling and his cohorts'
website, "SCIgen - An Automatic CS Paper Generator."

"Our aim is to maximize amusement, rather than coherence," it said. The
website allows users to "Generate a Random Paper" themselves, with
fields for inserting "optional author names."
"Contrarily, the lookaside buffer might not be the panacea..."

Nagib Callaos, a conference organizer, said the paper was one of a
small number accepted on a "non-reviewed" basis -- meaning that
reviewers had not yet given their feedback by the acceptance deadline.

"We thought that it might be unfair to refuse a paper that was not
refused by any of its three selected reviewers," Callaos wrote in an
e-mail. "The author of a non-reviewed paper has complete responsibility
of the content of their paper."

However, Callaos said conference organizers were reviewing their
acceptance procedures in light of the hoax.

Asked whether he would disinvite the MIT students, Callos replied,
"Bogus papers should not be included in the conference program."

Stribling said conference organizers had not yet formally rescinded
their invitation to present the paper.

The students were soliciting cash donations so they could attend the
conference and give what Stribling billed as a "completely
randomly-generated talk, delivered entirely with a straight face."

They exceeded their goal, with $2,311.09 cents from 165 donors.

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] Doctor Wilson to offer Prescription

--=====================_9010085==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed



An interesting article on my friend Greg Wilson in the UK.

"House music is no longer at the cutting edge of culture.  I think people 
are a little stranded, to be honest. It's not new any more and as a result 
people want to go back and explore the roots of the music they like."


Doctor Wilson to offer Prescription

Richard Hector-Jones

DJ legend Greg Wilson is a walking encyclopaedia of black music. An hour on 
the phone to him on Monday night reveals that.

And, if that weren't indication enough, you should visit his website 
<http://www.electrofunkroutes.co.uk>www.electrofunkroutes.co.uk, where he 
waxes lyrical about a near forgotten period of dance music that rocked his 
post northern soul and pre-acid house world; a scene characterised by New 
York labels such as West End, Tommy Boy, Prelude and Sugarhill.

Music that went on to inform Chicago and Detroit as much as the Europeans 
such as Kraftwerk. Yet somehow it never got the accolades.

Tonight Liverpudlian Greg plays a new night called Prescription, taking 
place at Legends on Whitworth Street, spinning a set of his characteristic 
electro-funk sounds to a crowd that might not have a) paid attention first 
time round or, b) not been born when Greg was spinning back in the day.

MORE: 
http://www.manchesteronline.co.uk/entertainment/clubs/s/154/154806_doctor_wilson_to_offer_prescription.html




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_9010085==.ALT--

> "DJ is my main activity, working every weekend in
> clubs or festivals since 1994. I started with hard
> techno-acid sounds: Drop Bass Network, Analog,
> Interr-Ferrence, Force Inc, SP23, to Detroit and
> experimental techno. I figured out it expressed my
> late teenage aggressivity. With experience, I got
> musically softer and more open-minded.
>=20
> Actually I play everything that entertains me:
> minimal, deep, to kicking techno, mixed with funny our
> leftfield tunes, classics, electro, no matter what it
> is. That's why I hardly can describe my style. A 2h
> monotone set really bores me. If I don't have fun
> myself, I'm not able to please people.
> DJing must be, in a way, something selfish. I shout it
> loud: I don't do it for the people. I never pretended
> to educate the audience, I just share a big part of
> me, taking it as serious as I love it. Michael Mayer
> (Kompakt records, Cologne) said: "Taking it serious
> about having fun." Because 1st it's a job, and we
> should never forget being paid to give pleasure to
> people is a great privilege. If the risks I take in my
> sets are my trademark, my priority is still to make
> dance the ones who make my living. Question of
> respect.
>=20
> I think I have a sharp technique, pitch-control born
> in my acid times, I consider my best weapon to focus
> on musical choices.
>=20
> I love playing records, it's probably the best thing I
> know to do in life. I do it because it's big fun and
> it makes me free, it even turns into a meditation kind
> of thing. With records, nothing is planned, every
> record is important. I often compares a DJ set to a
> tennis game where each ball counts. But people know me
> more for my voice even if I never took singing
> lessons."

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."

Subject: [sfraves] RIP:  Johnnie Johnson

--=====================_29998425==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Johnnie Johnson, 80, Dies; Hall of Fame Rock Pianist

By Adam Bernstein
Washington Post Staff Writer
Thursday, April 14, 2005; Page B07

Rock and Roll Hall of Fame pianist Johnnie Johnson, who worked closely with 
Chuck Berry and insisted that he was the inspiration for the song "Johnny 
B. Goode," died April 13 at his home in St. Louis. He was 80 and suffered 
recently from pneumonia and a kidney ailment.

Mr. Johnson, once known as the "baddest right hand in the land," was a 
rollicking thriller on the ivories. Reared on stride and boogie-woogie 
styles, he went on to support Berry, the flamboyant, duckwalking 
singer-guitarist, for most of the 1950s and then sporadically afterward.

They had a famously complex relationship. Berry, originally hired as a 
replacement in Mr. Johnson's rhythm-and-blues trio, soon overshadowed the 
reserved pianist. "When Chuck started with me, he didn't know but 12 songs 
all the way through and couldn't play the guitar that well," Mr. Johnson 
told his biographer, Travis Fitzpatrick.

Although sidelined by Berry and suffering from alcoholism, Mr. Johnson 
continued to help craft Berry's most famous songs, including "Maybellene," 
"Sweet Little Sixteen," "Roll Over Beethoven" and "Back in the U.S.A." He 
said he provided extensive melodic framework to accompany Berry's ideas, 
but by the time Chess Records made them stars, Berry was the frontman and 
had the glory.

Mr. Johnson drove a bus for the elderly in St. Louis and occasionally went 
on the road with Berry and other musicians. Largely resigned to obscurity, 
he received an unexpected boost when he appeared in Taylor Hackford's 
documentary film "Chuck Berry, Hail! Hail! Rock 'n' Roll" (1987), made to 
celebrate Berry's 60th birthday.

Keith Richards, the Rolling Stones guitarist who was featured in the 
documentary, became one of Mr. Johnson's chief supporters. "You can tell 
how much Johnnie's blues stylings had to do with the music for Chuck's 
tunes," he once said, "by the fact that a lot of those characteristic Chuck 
Berry guitar riffs and compositions are in keys familiar to Johnnie and 
other pianists but seldom used by guitarists."

In 2000, Mr. Johnson sued for co-writing credit on 57 songs, claiming Berry 
had taken advantage of Mr. Johnson's alcoholism to claim sole credit. A 
federal judge dismissed the claim because too many years had passed since 
the disputed songs were written.

Mr. Johnson's final fight was winning recognition from the Rock and Roll 
Hall of Fame, which inducted him in 2001, when it added a new category for 
sidemen. Mr. Johnson saw the long wait as one of rules and politics, 
saying, "I knew there were others in there not as good as me."

Johnnie Clyde Johnson was born July 8, 1924, in Fairmont, W.Va., where his 
father was a coal miner. His parents bought him a secondhand upright piano 
when he was 4. When the youngster sat down and began fingering some music, 
he said his mother "cried out that it was a gift from God."

Mr. Johnson said he learned musical timing by listening to trains near his 
home. He also listened to his parents' blues records and tuned into a 
late-night big-band program in Pittsburgh called "Dawn Patrol."

While serving in the Marine Corps in the Pacific, he played in a group 
composed of musicians from the Count Basie and Lionel Hampton bands. He 
said that meeting many of his idols focused him on a career in music.

In 1952, while fronting a blues trio for a New Year's Eve engagement at the 
Cosmopolitan Club in East St. Louis, Ill., he hired the obscure Berry as a 
last-minute replacement and noticed an immediate impact.

Berry, favoring a raucous, hillbilly-blues style, soon became the star 
presence at the Cosmopolitan. Sir John's Trio, as Mr. Johnson's group was 
called, was soon the Chuck Berry Combo.

Mr. Johnson was deferential, up to a point, mostly because Berry had a car. 
But conflicts ensued over money and Mr. Johnson's habitual lateness to 
engagements. Mr. Johnson once said: "I'd just get there in time for the 
show and Chuck would be shakin' his head, askin' me: 'Why can't you just be 
good, Johnnie? Stay with us.' "

He claimed the phrase inspired Berry to write "Johnny B. Goode" in 1958. 
Berry said the lyrics, which describe a country boy who "could play a 
guitar just like ringing a bell," was more about himself, though some 
sources claim he wrote it for Mr. Johnson.

It became one of Berry's greatest hits, a song so infectiously upbeat that 
NASA blasted it into space in a time capsule as a sample of Earth music. In 
interviews, Mr. Johnson introduced himself as "Johnny B. Goode."

After the Hackford documentary, Mr. Johnson played with such artists as 
Richards, Bob Weir and Eric Clapton, and toured from Scandinavia to 
Australia despite a fear of flying. He appeared on guitarist Buddy Guy's 
1994 Grammy-winning blues album, "Slippin' In."

Survivors include his wife, Frances, whom he married in 1989. He had 
numerous children from previous marriages.

© 2005 The Washington Post Company




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

I'll see you sometime later
When I'm through with my Accumulator

It's no social integrator
It's a one man isolator
It's a back brain stimulator
It's a cerebral vibrator

Those energy stimulators
Turn your eyeballs into crators
But an Orgone Accumulator
Is a superman creator

It's no social integrator
It's a one man isolator
It's a back brain stimulator
It's a cerebral vibrator

I've got an Orgone Accumulator
And it makes me feel grater
I'll see you sometime later
When I'm through with my Accumulator

-- Hawkwind

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] hello? is anybody out there?

I was @ Westworld Saturday night. Absorbed some tasty beats. I was most 
impressed with Freaky Chakra , who busted out some brand new beats for us, 
and played one of the best sets I've heard him play in the last year or so. 
Also, Boreta dropped some illy beats as well. I really enjoyed Tony Rohr's 
tracks, but his segues were a bit awkward at times. Chris Yap brought some 
reallllly ill shit too. I'm glad I finally got to see him spin, very nice 
work Mr.Yap!

All in all it was a nice time, surrounded by plenty of nice folks. Staying 
uber late and hanging with the crew was good times...I'm looking forward to 
the next shindig!

Subject: [sfraves] bsp :: andrea parker :: wed 5/4

Wednesday, MAY 4th, 2005

DimSum and XLR8R present:
THE ANDREA PARKER TOUR 
 
DJ and Live Sets From:

Andrea Parker (!K7, MoWax, Beggers Banquet, Touchin Bass)
Mochipet (DimSum, Tigerbeat6, Bpitchcontrol)
Forest Green (DimSum, SisterSF)
Sindri (DimSum, Imputor?)
Samira (SisterSF)

Cozy Chillout Room by:
-The Ambient Mafia-
64k
drop
Harken
redstickman
4Matt (the drow)

Visuals by Konstrukt

Club Six
60 6th St. (between Market/Mission), SF 
9pm, $10

Andrea Parker, known for her electro mixes and sublime
productions on !K7, MoWax, and Beggers Banquet is
headed stateside to support her own imprint Touchin
Bass!

Parker has contributed to several experimental
electronic releases through out her career including
remixes for Depeche Mode, Ryuichi Sakamoto, and
Tipper.

Miss Parkers DJ style is uncompromising and crosses
all boundaries. Shes supported Radiohead on the US
part of their Kid A tour, experimented live on stage
with avant-garde supremos : Bang On A Can (Philip
Glass and Steve Reich) and provided more than a little
entertainment at parties for director Roman Polanski
and fashion house; Gucci.

Her popularity as a DJ was confirmed by the high sales
of her mix for !K7s DJ Kicks series which showcased
the variety of her musical tastes; shes not afraid to
fuse hip hop pioneers like Man Parish with electronic
pushers Gescom. 

More info :
http://www.xlr8r.com/article.php?uid=3251CA24BE8730E1A8F17C32E7AA7142

Subject: [sfraves] Oh yeah... Anthem Review 4 last Friday =)

OK.. yeah.. I was all about like Adam Freeland, BassBin Twins, la la la, @
1015... well.. I was all gung ho about it like since i found out about
it... but i dunno... got in2 a few like spats w/ my Mom that day 'cause
she was uuuggh.. i dunno.. she just was & took it out on me like she
usually does...

So i dunno, I was kinda bitter,, then fuckin' Joey Mr Frisco IMed me & we
apent most of the afternoon talking & shit.. so 'cause of my mood & I
dunno... I just said Fuck 1015.. I want something else & Joey Suggested
Anthem @ Sublounge.. OK... Danny.. shut.. I can hear what your thinkin!!!

Anywaze.. went 2 his pad in the City... met up w/ his friends, Saw Mr
Tommy Slik working, hung out.. Dope!  Ummm... then we went 2 SunLounge!!

All I gotta say is Good Fuckin' Shit man!!  I have not had a Groovy time
like that in a loooong time!!  The Jungle downstairs was simply fuckin'
Amazing... The Doctor, Bicolas (oh man.. he played an evil dnb set..
EVIL), Kinetik, ummm.. Dymphna, Sic.. it was Awesome!!  Loved It!!!!  Oh
My Gosh man.. I DMAOed so much down there!!  Hello 2Day.. Oh Yeah!!!

OK.. So the upstairs Music was Groovy... all the DJs were Dope.. But ok..
Hello 2day.. ummmmm.. like ok.. Wow.. like Megatron was there.. & he spun
GRIME!!!  YUUUUUUUUUUUMMM!!!  It was fuckin' Sick man.. I Loved it!!! 
lkeOK... ummm... GRIME 4 those who are like unaware is kinda a hybrid of
2Step & ummm.. well.. something else. not sure what.. but it was Sick!!! 
LOVED IT!!  LOVE U MEGA (& I <3 MegaNIC also!!)

OH yeah.. the night was MCed by the MC CHild!!  LOLOLOLMAO.. Love that
Dude so much.. he fuckn' spit 2 rhymes about me.. the 1st 1 was about me &
ketchup & the 2nd was about me & my shirt.. wait.. there was a 3rd.. but i
was like kinda uuuggh 2 remember...

The vibe there was Sick!!  There were heeeeeella people there & People i
really totally care about that i don't get 2 C that often... so it was
really nice!!  Oh yeah... Joey's (shut up Danny) building mates are the
coolest... the 4 of us danced 2 Jungle!!  It was crazy!!  I realized that
I was exactly where i wanted 2 B 'cause I dunno.. big & glitzey 1015
probably wouldn't of done it 4 me... yeah!!

Loved it!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Did anyone catch the party that Thomas was at last weekend?

I was kidding...but the worst part is, I've seen those.

;-p

I don't want to sound jaded or anything, but this list was once quite diffe=
rent.

actually I'll sound hella jaded. back in the late 90s O'Reilly did a
book on the evolution of the web, explaining how e-mail was basically
ill-suited to large group communication and that corporations
communicating important information via e-mail inevitably end up with
multiple versions of the same file distributed to multiple inboxes
with no version control, no clear understanding of who has which
version of what file, and generally all sorts of efficiency problems
caused by the use of an inefficient communications medium. the whole
point of this book was that web-enabled NNTP was a technologically
superior way of organizing corporate communications. sadly this book
has since gone out of print and I can't even remember what type of
animals were on the cover -- I think it was sea lions -- but the
validity of the insight is proven in that most new online communities
develop around Web forums rather than e-mail lists. I think this list
is inherently doomed to obsolence owing to the outdated nature of its
technological foundation, i.e., the fact that it is an e-mail list in
the first place, but like most on here I am still for some reason
hooked. (although I gotta tell you, it's not the chauvinism that
hooked me.)

in my defense, I tried to create an elegant replacement for the
existing bulletin board systems, which are generally both ugly and
clunky, but I got bored. online communication systems are hardly the
thrilling frontier they were ten years ago. instead I did this really
pretty sort of dynamically-generated Flash-based Frank Lloyd Wright
cellular automata art thing which I will post once I get my machine
back online and/or when I remember to do it.

ANYWAY.

movin on...

the downside to this whole thing is of course that $45 parties can
happen featuring people who we on this list had assumed had died or
moved back to Ireland or what have you. the upside is I can talk about
technologically sophisticated subjects for paragraphs at a time and
some of you motherfuckers will actually read the whole thing.

:-)

At 11:54 AM 4/19/2005, Steve Osteen wrote:
>Remember that the Hitler Youth was compulsory.
>
>Sounds like the Catholic church got an even more conservative pope then
>before.
>
>Of course he is 78, and 30% of popes die within the first 6 months...


All true, Steve.  Although most everyone in Nazi Germany said they were 
compelled to participate :-)  Mystery to me how Hitler took and held 
power.  Magic?  Ratzinger left the Germany army in May, 1945, at, he says, 
"great peril to himself."  Well, by May '45 things were pretty much over, 
eh?  His formative years were spent in the Nazi educational and military 
system...there is no doubt of this.

On the other side of the "conservative" definition of Benedict, although 
I'm no longer a member of the RCC, I personally don't believe cafeteria 
ethics -- moral relativity -- is a good thing.  The Church is not a 
democracy :-)  I listened on NPR to some 19-year-old American's reaction to 
the  election of Cardinal Ratzinger with amusement:  "He's old and not 
relevant to the youth of today.  No, I don't know anything about him except 
he's old.  I really don't know anything about Church history before I was 
born."  I paraphrase a bit, but that pretty much sums up America, eh?

I left the Church because I could not adhere to the rules and much of her 
dogma.  I did not, however, expect that the RCC would change because I had 
a different world  view.  LOL.  Not relevant to me, I went elsewhere.

Love,

Apollo

The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Sunset Boat Party - John Tajada

------=_NextPart_000_00C4_01C544F1.9C10F010
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Damn was last night over the top..  John Tajada (sp?) was amazing.. his
beats hit so hard and had every body jumping so much that the boat threw a
second wake.. making it a kinda breakbeat float!  No, seriously.. it was
hella fun trying to dance while the waves were tossin everyone around.. but
if you timed it right you could do all these amazing spins coming up off the
floor and shit.. it was super fun.  The crowd was beautiful and a lot of
great energy was in that place.  Everyone getting hella drunk and peoples
all making out all over the place.. a little cheesy.. but in a fun spirited
way that made me happy to be on the boat again.  It has been three years
since my last sunset boat party.. way too long.. I finally got to hang out
with Manny (M3), and Laird who I hadn't seen in a few months, and hella
girlies that I knew from way back when.  So when it was over.. we were all
wobbly with sea legs and everyone had to learn to walk on land again.
*grin*

 

Bon Voyage!

Ranger


------=_NextPart_000_00C4_01C544F1.9C10F010--

Subject: [sfraves] Intro/Hugger Mugger

Hi, I don't think I've posted here yet but I've been lurking for a  
couple of months. I'm Tim, I just moved to SF from DC. I know a few  
people on here already (mostly people who also moved from DC recently)  
but not too many.

I DJ (who doesn't?)...not as much as I used to but I'm hoping to change  
that now that I'm out here. Mostly I spin techno these days but I've  
been known to do hard house, acid, NRG, and hardcore in the  
past...anything with a lot of energy and an edge to it really. But on  
the other hand, lately I've been picking up more microhouse and  
Detroity style techno...maybe I'm just getting old. My website is still  
under construction, but here's a recent mix I did:

http://www.timresistor.com/Mixes/YearOfReflection/TimResistor- 
YearOfReflection.mp3


I haven't made it out to any parties here yet, but I was thinking about  
checking out Hugger Mugger tonight. Anyone else planning to go? Do  
people tend to get there early or late? If anyone wants to keep the new  
guy company, that would be great...

-- 
Tim Moore

> Andrea Parker, known for her electro mixes and
> sublime
> productions on !K7, MoWax, and Beggers Banquet is
> headed stateside to support her own imprint Touchin
> Bass!
> 
> Parker has contributed to several experimental
> electronic releases through out her career including
> remixes for Depeche Mode, Ryuichi Sakamoto, and
> Tipper.
> 
> Miss Parkers DJ style is uncompromising and crosses
> all boundaries. Shes supported Radiohead on the US
> part of their Kid A tour, experimented live on stage
> with avant-garde supremos : Bang On A Can (Philip
> Glass and Steve Reich) and provided more than a
> little
> entertainment at parties for director Roman Polanski
> and fashion house; Gucci.
>

> sales
> of her mix for !K7s DJ Kicks series which showcased
> the variety of her musical tastes; shes not afraid
> to
> fuse hip hop pioneers like Man Parish with
> electronic
> pushers Gescom.

Message-Id: <6.2.1.2.2.20050419183928.029cbd80@localhost>
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 6.2.1.2
Date: Tue, 19 Apr 2005 18:40:45 -0700
To: "SFR" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_16794338==.ALT"

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  COGNITIVE LIBERTY NEWS

--=====================_16794338==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

COGNITIVE LIBERTY NEWS


=============================================================
Supreme Court to Review Ayahuasca Case
<http://en.groundspring.org/EmailNow/pub.php?module=URLTracker&cmd=track&j=27681995&u=251676>http://www.cognitiveliberty.org/dll/ayahuasca_index.htm
=============================================================

On Friday April 15, the US Supreme Court agreed to review an important case 
involving US members of the ayahuasca-using Uniao Do Vegetal (UDV) church. 
The CCLE's Richard Glen Boire is an expert on the legal issues concerning 
ayahuasca use and spoke about them live on the BBC Radio 5 on April 18, 
2005, noting that the case pits Freedom of Religion against the symbolism 
of the War on Drugs. Ayahuasca is not a drug of abuse, and has zero impact 
on the "drug war," whereas freedom of religion is one of the most cherished 
freedoms enshrined in the Constitution. During alcohol prohibition, 
religious users of wine (a drug far more habituating than ayahuasca) were 
exempted, and the CCLE maintains that a similar exemption ought to be 
recognized for the members of the UDV. Indeed, the Religious Freedom 
Restoration Act mandates such an accommodation. The case is Gonzales v. O 
Centro Espirita Beneficiente Uniao Do Vegetal, No. 04-1084.

=============================================================
CCLE Supreme Court Legal Brief Makes Waves
<http://en.groundspring.org/EmailNow/pub.php?module=URLTracker&cmd=track&j=27681995&u=251677>http://www.uakron.edu/law/lawreview/pdf/Schultz382.pdf
=============================================================

In 2003-4 the CCLE was an amicus party before the United States Supreme 
Court in the case of Sell v. United States. The case was successful, with 
Dr. Sell winning a bar on being force-drugged in an effort to make him 
legally competent to stand trial.  All evidence was that Dr. Sell was 
mentally competent and posed no danger to himself or others. In that case, 
our amicus brief argued that the First Amendment protects cognitive liberty 
- a right to integrity over one's own thought processes and underlying 
neurochemistry. A new law review article published by Elizabeth G. Shultz 
"Sell-ing Your Soul to the Courts: Forced Medication to Achieve Trial 
Competency in the Wake of Sell v. United States," 38 Akron L. Rev. 503 
(2005) cites the CCLE's brief and adopts our argument, noting: "In light of 
the seriousness of the First Amendment right to freedom of thought at 
stake, the Court should have recognized that no governmental interest can 
outweigh a person's right to freedom of thought, especially when the 
defendant is non-dangerous and charged with non-violent crimes." The 
complete article (in PDF format) can be obtained by clicking the above link.


=============================================================
American Journal of Bioethics Publishes CCLE Commentary
<http://en.groundspring.org/EmailNow/pub.php?module=URLTracker&cmd=track&j=27681995&u=251678>http://www.bioethics.net/journal/
=============================================================

The prestigious American Journal of Bioethics will be publishing an article 
by Richard Glen Boire in the upcoming issue. The article examines a new 
breed of brain-based lie detectors, and argues that existing Fourth 
Amendment jurisprudence is ill-equipped to deal with law enforcement uses 
of these devices. Richard's article argues that the notion of cognitive 
security would provide the missing legal concept, and ought to make 
nonconsensual use of such devices by law enforcement agents an 
unconstitutional "search" within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment. The 
article should appear at the above link later this month.


=============================================================
Cognitive Liberty at University of Pennsylvania
<http://en.groundspring.org/EmailNow/pub.php?module=URLTracker&cmd=track&j=27681995&u=251679>http://www.bioethics.upenn.edu/nubc/promotional.html
=============================================================

On April 1-2, Richard Glen Boire flew to Philadelphia where he spoke about 
cognitive liberty and gave a response to the keynote talk by renowned 
neuroscientist Dr. Michael Gazzaniga. The event was called "The Brain and 
Beyond: The 8th National Undergraduate Bioethics Conference," and brought 
together over 300 undergraduate and graduate students from 25 states and 7 
countries. Richard's talks focused on the need to update the legal notion 
of "freedom of thought" to include protections for autonomy and 
self-determination over one's own functional neurochemistry. Richard spoke 
with many of the attendees and with the other presenters about the way that 
a legal right to cognitive liberty and cognitive security would provide a 
framework for encouraging advancements in neuroscience and 
psychopharmacology, while advancing a legal principle that protects both 
those who want to say "yes" to using such technologies, and those who want 
to say "no." Check the above link for an eventual DVD and archived webcast 
of thetalks.


============================================================
New Answer: Ask Dr. Shulgin Online
<http://en.groundspring.org/EmailNow/pub.php?module=URLTracker&cmd=track&j=27681995&u=251680>http://www.cognitiveliberty.org/shulgin/blg/index.html
============================================================
We posted a new answer by Dr. Alexander Shulgin. The question was:

What exactly is "ice" and how does it differ from "crank" "speed" or 
"methamphetamine"?
What are the adverse effects of this drug on an individual? - Jennifer

Follow the above link to read Dr. Shulgin's reply.

===========================================================
RGB guest on Science Today Radio Show
<http://en.groundspring.org/EmailNow/pub.php?module=URLTracker&cmd=track&j=27681995&u=251681>http://www.kdvs.org
===========================================================

On Tuesday March 29, Richard Glen Boire was a guest on the half-hour 
"Science Today" radio show on KDVS. KDVS is a college radio station 
broadcasting from Davis, California with mp3 podcasting programs archived. 
Richard explored the intersection of constitutional rights and 
psychopharmacology, ranging from the use of peyote in religious ceremonies, 
to future-coming drugs that will make it possible to manage one's memories 
- either boosting or attenuating them.

===========================================================
America's New Drugs - URB Magazine
<http://en.groundspring.org/EmailNow/pub.php?module=URLTracker&cmd=track&j=27681995&u=251682>http://www.urb.com/online/guts_125.shtml
===========================================================

The April 2005 issue of URB Magazine carried an article on the way in which 
criminal drug prohibition actual drives the creation of new synthetic 
drugs. The article includes Richard Glen Boire's comments comparing the 
harms of today's drug prohibition with the harms produced by alcohol 
prohibition, and ends with a deeper critique of
the war on ecstasy:

Boire, continues and proposes a plausible theory: "There's a fear of
Ecstasy, not [just] the drug [by that name], but the experience, the
idea that people can have this autonomous joy that is not limited by
church protocols or socially-constructed modes. It's okay to be happy
when your team scores a touchdown in the Super Bowl, but it's
[considered] odd for people to be ecstatically dancing in fields."


==========================================================
Should Salvia Divinorum Be Made Illegal?
<http://en.groundspring.org/EmailNow/pub.php?module=URLTracker&cmd=track&j=27681995&u=251683>http://www.timesonline.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=14184335&BRD
==========================================================
The Beaver County Times, a small paper in Pennsylvania reported on the 
CCLE's efforts to educate legislators in that state who are seeking to add 
the plant Salvia divinorum to the state's list of controlled substances. 
Unfortunately, it is unlikely that this misguided legislative effort can be 
forestalled because Salvia divinorum is just one among a group of 
substances named in the bill for control. For the latest news on this bill 
or on other legal threats to this plant visit 
<http://en.groundspring.org/EmailNow/pub.php?module=URLTracker&cmd=track&j=27681995&u=251684>http://www.sagewisdom.org/new.html 
Daniel Siebert's Salvia Divinorum Research and Information Center.

==========================================================
Yes on Child Medication & Safety Act
<http://en.groundspring.org/EmailNow/pub.php?module=URLTracker&cmd=track&j=27681995&u=251685>http://releases.usnewswire.com/GetRelease.asp?id=46015
==========================================================
Last year, the CCLE launched its "Choices for Children" campaign aimed at 
ending schools from conditioning a child's education on the use of Ritalin 
or other psychotropic medication. Today, April 19th, actresses Kirstie 
Alley and Kelly Preston will address the Florida Education Council on 
legislation (HB 209 and SB 1766) to prevent schools that receive state 
funding from forcing parents to put their children on psychotropic drugs as 
a condition of attendance in the schools, and to give parents the 
information they need to make an informed decision for their child's 
behavior problems. Although the issue of psychiatric child drugging is 
controversial, their message is straightforward, as is the CCLE's: "Give 
parents all the information needed to make an informed medication choice 
for their children."

==========================================================




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Acid Totem Acid Test This Friday

--=====================_33291230==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Acid Totem Acid Test-

40 Years ago, Ken Kesey, author of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" 
embarked on a psychedelic journey to Edge City. The first of what was to be 
many Acid Tests took place in Santa Cruz County in 1965. Ken Kesey and his 
clan of Merry Prankers initially spawned the framework for the psychedellic 
and counter culture revolution of the 1960's. Circa 25 years later, another 
revolution which fused music and elements of psychedelia was again 
happening in our beloved California. Doc Martin, Garth, and Jeno all played 
huge roles in putting the West Coast on the map throughout the 90's, laying 
the foundation for the next decade plus.

We invite everyone to celebrate all that is good among the old, and the 
new, and ask the question: Can YOU Pass the ACID TEST?
Doc Martin
Garth
Jeno
Ben Haus vs Dave L

10-4am
Club Mighty
119 Utah at 15th St, San Francisco
21+
$5 b4 11 $15 after
Presales available at mighty119.com
Or HERE: <http://www.mollyguard.com/event/16787211>Click here!
DRESS The WAY You Are

Info line: 415 267-6172






Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

the=20
>world who tries to make us uncomfortable."

>while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time
before=20
>death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think

>ghosts will do it after?"
>-Kabir

the=20
>rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually
become=20

other. All over the world Buddhists remember Siddartha, and the ability to 
communicate with higher levels of intelligence is sublime.

The Sun is in peaceful Taurus (think of Buddha under the Bodhi Tree) but 
the Moon is in Scorpio. Coupled with an eclipse, the energy is perfect for 
dumping every toxic thing in your life safely in to the ethers for 
recycling and healing. It's the perfect time to dance and let go.

Be willing under the Wesak Full Moon Eclipse to be washed clean, renewed, 
refreshed, restored and RECHARGED ... innocent again and ready for a new start.

while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Message-ID: <2941.67.188.23.49.1114075018.squirrel@secure.saturn5.com>

From: "Osby Oi Oi Jamz" <osby@viberation.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Rise @ 1015... Get Your Proggy House Groovy ON!


Introducing...

-=RISE=-

A new night in San Francisco bringing together the international artists
pushing progressive forward, and local crews true to the sound right here
at home.  Be there for the debut event, featuring the label launch party
for progressive & tech-house imprint Railyard Recordings and all their
headlining artists, including...

In the Main Room:

Michael Thomas aka BLACKWATCH (Live)
Blackwatch is nothing short of a progressive phenomenon.  His skillful,
powerful productions have dominated the industry with over 50 releases and
remixes on such labels as Global Underground, Renaissance, HOOJ Choons,
Bedrock, YoshiToshi, Plastic Fantastic, Hope, SOG, Fade, Shinichi, Pitch
Black, and Ministry Of Sound. His recent smash hit "Gentle Rain" with
Greed went on to top major DJ charts all over the world in 2004.  And now
his current label home is Paramount Pictures, where he's opening up the
space within his legendary sound further than ever.

Justin Scott Dixon aka VOYAGER (Live + DJ)
Voyager's extensive body of work has been widely acclaimed throughout the
dance industry. His tracks and remixes have been licensed to heavyweight
CDs including Sasha's Global Underground San Francisco, and John Digweed's
GU:Los Angeles & 'Stark Raving Mad' compilations. Scott was one of the
first artists signed to Sasha's Excession label, and since then his music
has been released on Bedrock, Rhythm Syndicate, and Fire. He was also
chosen to remix John Digweed's Bedrock stormer, 'Beautiful Strange'. 
Today Voyager is forging a new sound in progressive: towering beats,
wide-open soundscapes, innovative melodic progressions, and SF is proud to
host the debut of his groundbreaking new material.

Plus be there early for an opening set by local hero Spesh (Looq, Qool,
Renaissance, Bedrock).  Come and welcome him back for his first solo set
at 1015 in years.


Upstairs:

Adam Collins aka OMNI AM
Since his emergence from the Chicago underground in the mid 90's, Adam
Collins has been instantly synonymous with the true underground Tech-House
movement in America, well before the upstart genre's emergence among the
transpotters as a cool musical buzzword. Adam owns and operates the
extremely influential Euphoria Recordings and has released on such labels
as Swag (uk), Big Chief (nyc), New Life, Crayon and Primal Recordings. He
has produced work with Uk tech house guru's Terry Francis, Eddie Richards,
and Grant Dell, and remixed such acts as Derrick Carter, Jay Tripwire and
Mr. C. His Dj'ng career brings him all over the globe with performances at
Crobar (Chicago), Arc/Twilo (NYC), Space and Concorde2 (UK). Today, Adam
in every way represents success in bringing the biggest sounds of the
globe to North American dancefloors.

plus Matt Xavier & Sean Detech aka GrUvHaUs  (LA/NYC - Railyard Recordings).


And in the front room:

Holdin' it down all night, local crews SOLIDSF and FunkyCozy, including
the supastars you know and love:

Jonathan Beech (FunkyCozy, Electrocelt)
D Spurlock (SolidSF, Clear)
Justin Corbett (Slow Motion Sequence, SolidSF)
Tim McCormack (FunkyCozy)

droppin' the funky, techy, progressive beats all night!


To sum up....

-=Rise=-
Friday, April 22nd
1015 Folsom
10pm til' they kick us out

$20 (but reply to rise-list@djwillspencer.com for half-off admission until
midnight!)


Looking forward to seeing you there, as progressive comes home to San
Francisco.

Cheers,
Will


-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

From: Acid Totem <acidtotem@gmail.com>
Reply-To: Acid Totem <acidtotem@gmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Mime-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Acid Test this Friday: Doc Martin, Jeno, Garth!

the ACID TEST reproduced by Acid Totem

Friday, April 22, 2005 @ Club Mighty SF

DOC MARTIN (sublevel)

GARTH (wicked, grayhound)

JENO (wicked, whoosh!)

Ben Haus vs Dave L (acid totem)

10pm-4am
21+
$5 b4 11pm
$15 thereafter

Presale tickets available at www.mighty119.com

DRESS The Way YOU Are~

www.mission-1.net
415 267-6172


1965, Ken Kesey, author of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest", and his
band of Merry Pranksters stage the first Acid Test; a radical and
psychedelic experiment based around music and lighting projections in
Santa Cruz County. Many Acid Tests would follow the Soquel Acid Test,
and would prove to be a major catalyst of things to come in the
counter-culture revolution of the 1960's. Circa 25 years later, a
different revolution was occuring on the Beaches and in the Deserts of
California. Under the watch of the full moon, DJ's such as Doc Martin,
and Garth and Jeno of the Wicked Crew introduced House and Electronic
music to thousands, and would lay the foundation for the West Coast
Sound for the next decade plus.

Join us as we celebrate all that is positive with the Old, the New, and
everything in between. Re-experience the pure and virgin energy that
helped create and build our House Nation.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Ya.. I just got that BBD tune.. but mixed into a breakbeat set.

And going under the GG Bridge was phenomenal.. everybody was out on the deck
hootin and hollarin.. starin straight up at the muthafucka.. it was a pretty
epic moment for the party for sure.  

I was grooving on everyone vibin eachother before the boat left.. out on the
deck with all their kewl ass gear and mad Sf style.. it was a crazy lil
scene. And that sunset was freakin amnazing!! Can't wait to go again!!

From: "Osby Oi Oi Jamz" <osby@viberation.com>

>
> Introducing...
>
> -=RISE=-
>
> A new night in San Francisco bringing together the international artists
> pushing progressive forward, and local crews true to the sound right here
> at home.  Be there for the debut event, featuring the label launch party
> for progressive & tech-house imprint Railyard Recordings and all their
> headlining artists, including...
>
> In the Main Room:
>
> Michael Thomas aka BLACKWATCH (Live)
> Blackwatch is nothing short of a progressive phenomenon.  His skillful,
> powerful productions have dominated the industry with over 50 releases and
> remixes on such labels as Global Underground, Renaissance, HOOJ Choons,
> Bedrock, YoshiToshi, Plastic Fantastic, Hope, SOG, Fade, Shinichi, Pitch
> Black, and Ministry Of Sound. His recent smash hit "Gentle Rain" with
> Greed went on to top major DJ charts all over the world in 2004.  And now
> his current label home is Paramount Pictures, where he's opening up the
> space within his legendary sound further than ever.
>
> Justin Scott Dixon aka VOYAGER (Live + DJ)
> Voyager's extensive body of work has been widely acclaimed throughout the
> dance industry. His tracks and remixes have been licensed to heavyweight
> CDs including Sasha's Global Underground San Francisco, and John Digweed's
> GU:Los Angeles & 'Stark Raving Mad' compilations. Scott was one of the
> first artists signed to Sasha's Excession label, and since then his music
> has been released on Bedrock, Rhythm Syndicate, and Fire. He was also
> chosen to remix John Digweed's Bedrock stormer, 'Beautiful Strange'.
> Today Voyager is forging a new sound in progressive: towering beats,
> wide-open soundscapes, innovative melodic progressions, and SF is proud to
> host the debut of his groundbreaking new material.
>
> Plus be there early for an opening set by local hero Spesh (Looq, Qool,
> Renaissance, Bedrock).  Come and welcome him back for his first solo set
> at 1015 in years.
>
>
> Upstairs:
>
> Adam Collins aka OMNI AM
> Since his emergence from the Chicago underground in the mid 90's, Adam
> Collins has been instantly synonymous with the true underground Tech-House
> movement in America, well before the upstart genre's emergence among the
> transpotters as a cool musical buzzword. Adam owns and operates the
> extremely influential Euphoria Recordings and has released on such labels
> as Swag (uk), Big Chief (nyc), New Life, Crayon and Primal Recordings. He
> has produced work with Uk tech house guru's Terry Francis, Eddie Richards,
> and Grant Dell, and remixed such acts as Derrick Carter, Jay Tripwire and
> Mr. C. His Dj'ng career brings him all over the globe with performances at
> Crobar (Chicago), Arc/Twilo (NYC), Space and Concorde2 (UK). Today, Adam
> in every way represents success in bringing the biggest sounds of the
> globe to North American dancefloors.
>
> plus Matt Xavier & Sean Detech aka GrUvHaUs  (LA/NYC - Railyard
Recordings).
>
>
> And in the front room:
>
> Holdin' it down all night, local crews SOLIDSF and FunkyCozy, including
> the supastars you know and love:
>
> Jonathan Beech (FunkyCozy, Electrocelt)
> D Spurlock (SolidSF, Clear)
> Justin Corbett (Slow Motion Sequence, SolidSF)
> Tim McCormack (FunkyCozy)
>
> droppin' the funky, techy, progressive beats all night!
>
>
> To sum up....
>
> -=Rise=-
> Friday, April 22nd
> 1015 Folsom
> 10pm til' they kick us out
>
> $20 (but reply to rise-list@djwillspencer.com for half-off admission until
> midnight!)
>
>
> Looking forward to seeing you there, as progressive comes home to San
> Francisco.
>
> Cheers,
> Will

In A.D. 2005
Papacy was beginning.

Priest: What happen ?
Altar Boy: Somebody set up us the pope.
Altar Boy: We get white smoke.
Priest: What !
Altar Boy: Main balcony doors open.
Priest: It's you !!
Pope Benedict XVI: How are you congregants !!
Pope Benedict XVI: All your saint are belong to us.
Pope Benedict XVI: You are on the way to salvation.
Priest: What you say !!
Pope Benedict XVI: You have no chance to convert make your time.
Pope Benedict XVI: Ha Ha Ha Ha ....
Altar Boy: Father !!
Priest: Exit square every 'Zig'!!
Priest: You know what you doing.
Priest: Move 'Zig'.
Priest: For great holiness.

I just want to say something about this.

Dogs have barbed penises. The barbs aren't sharp, they just keep the
dog's dick in the female dog to ensure maximum sperm dispersal.

If any of you ladies are considering fucking a dog, be aware that
every so often, a woman fucks a dog and the dog gets stuck inside her
because of the barbs -- human pussies aren't adapted to these things
and shit happens.

And the lady and the dog have to go to the emergency room, which is
funny, and sometimes the dog has to be killed, which is not funny.

So, ladies, be kind, be responsible, and don't fuck your dog.

This message brought to you by the holy shit dude how do you even know
that foundation for the prevention of tragically embarassing canine
death.

IN THE LAB (Hard/Prog/Psytrance)

**Enemy vs Peeche (Skills/N=FC)**
  2 x 4 Turntable Battle between two fierce dj's. Be prepared for=20
pounding techno rhythms with filtered funk to make you jump!

*Liam Shy (Tantra/N=FC)
*Obu (Bombay Power/N=FC)
*Psy2k (Mexico City/Shaman Films)
*Apot (djapot.com)
*Sunshyne (Utopia Dreamz/N=FC)

IN THE CUBE (Breaks & House)

**Ooah the Turntable Junky (Los Angeles - LABA/El Circo)**
	This 23 year old has rocked the dance floors at Burning Man, Get=20=

Freaky and Fusion, playing a mix of original tracks and the hottest=20
cuts on wax.  Don't miss out on this 3 turntable performance of bass=20
grinding tech-hop, electric mind-bending breaks, psychedelic=20
dream-rhythms and intellectual glitch frequencies.

*Denise (djdenise.com/Sound Asylum)
*Antiserum (N=FC)
*Adam Ant (Love All Stars)
*RPM (Movement)
*Bumiputra (bumiputra.com)

18+ to enter, 21+ to drink
10pm - 5am
$10 @ Door

Located @ The Blue Cube - 34 Mason street, San Francisco
(just off market between 5th & 6th)

N=FC is a diverse collective of young artists, primarily under 25. =A0Our=20=

main goal is to empower other young artists to showcase their talent in=20=

a late-night dance environment.

We believe that dancing is good for the mind, body and soul. =A0We=20
provide you with a technologically advanced playground of audio and=20
visual stimulation so you can let go of your day-to-day worries and=20
dance the night away!

www.nusf.net
www.bluecubesf.com

N=FC Music - N=FC Technology - N=FC Vibe=

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Acid Test this Friday: Doc Martin, Jeno, Garth!

Hiya!
I went to this, and had a great time! Thanks :) Heres my review;
Ive only been to a couple things in SF, havent really had many
chances, but anyway..
Club Mighty is a decent space, easy to get to and good sized. Good
sound for a club, and it filled up well. I was happy to see a wide
range of groovers, and a lot of them dancing too. And how could you
not?? These DJs were GREAT! I dont know who played in what order, but
the first guy definetly got things moving, packing the floor with some
very danceable stuff. The second DJ played what I came to hear -
bumpin tracks *dripping* with 303 sounds - YUUM!! I couldnt sit down
if I wanted to, and I didnt want to :) The third guy was tearin it up,
dropping disco hooks through a bangin set. I had to leave after that,
but I could have danced all night. Thanks SF for the good time ;)

Love,=20
Lily

> 1965, Ken Kesey, author of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest", and his
> band of Merry Pranksters stage the first Acid Test; a radical and
> psychedelic experiment based around music and lighting projections in
> Santa Cruz County. Many Acid Tests would follow the Soquel Acid Test,
> and would prove to be a major catalyst of things to come in the
> counter-culture revolution of the 1960's. Circa 25 years later, a
> different revolution was occuring on the Beaches and in the Deserts of
> California. Under the watch of the full moon, DJ's such as Doc Martin,
> and Garth and Jeno of the Wicked Crew introduced House and Electronic
> music to thousands, and would lay the foundation for the West Coast
> Sound for the next decade plus.
>=20
> Join us as we celebrate all that is positive with the Old, the New, and
> everything in between. Re-experience the pure and virgin energy that
> helped create and build our House Nation.
