Subject: [sfraves] How do you feel about "Electric Guitars" in dance music?

--0-2097359094-1114290445=:59381
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

How do you feel about "Electric Guitars" in dance music?

My self I find electric guitars are a good tool to move a crowd. The new (Daft Punk) album use a ton of guitar loops in there newest album called "We Are Human" If have have not heard none of the tracks then you are missing out good French house music at its best. Much love goes out to (Daft Punk)  

I feel the more that people experiment with musical instruments with dance music. The more dance music will grow.

My self I play the Electric Bass Guitar as well as Electric Guitar & I would love to put my Bass Guitar into some of my mix sets. I think the more musical instruments in the dance music would leave it open to new ideas and sub styles such as (House Rock, Electric Trance) and so on. 

In my mind, when someone talks down on dance music saying it is crap. I just laugh at them and think about how far we have made it in the muisc world from Classical Orchestras to CD-DJ & Drum Machines. 


So let me hear your thoughts: D

Subject: Re: [sfraves] How do you feel about "Electric Guitars" in dance music?

It really depends how they're used.  I play bass in my productions and
live with my own djing and others (Andrew Phelan quite a bit), and I
also incorporate guitar and bass in the Cubik & Origami live show.

Raging distorted guitar wank soloing in a house track?  That can get to
me, for sure.  Otherwise, I say, it's just another sound source.  I
have house tracks that have 12 guitar parts in them, and if I didn't
tell you, you might not even know the parts are guitars- but the
instrument they were played on certainly "informed" what came out in
the end.

Bass is a little easier, because, well, everybody wants more bass. ;)

gee out

george c | origami
newstylesound.com
--- Warren Shafor <daddy_g_dj@yahoo.com> wrote:
> How do you feel about "Electric Guitars" in dance music?
> 
> My self I find electric guitars are a good tool to move a crowd. The
> new (Daft Punk) album use a ton of guitar loops in there newest album
> called "We Are Human" If have have not heard none of the tracks then
> you are missing out good French house music at its best. Much love
> goes out to (Daft Punk)  
> 
> I feel the more that people experiment with musical instruments with
> dance music. The more dance music will grow.
> 
> My self I play the Electric Bass Guitar as well as Electric Guitar &
> I would love to put my Bass Guitar into some of my mix sets. I think
> the more musical instruments in the dance music would leave it open
> to new ideas and sub styles such as (House Rock, Electric Trance) and
> so on. 
> 
> In my mind, when someone talks down on dance music saying it is crap.
> I just laugh at them and think about how far we have made it in the
> muisc world from Classical Orchestras to CD-DJ & Drum Machines. 
> 
> 
> So let me hear your thoughts: D

From sfraves-return-120860-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sat Apr 23 23:43:12 2005

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 4318 invoked by uid 1103); 23 Apr 2005 23:43:11 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 4292 invoked from network); 23 Apr 2005 23:43:10 -0000
Content-Type: text/plain; charset
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: skylab2000 listmonkey <dbarton@pacbell.net>
Date: Sat, 23 Apr 2005 23:43:03 +0000
Reply-To: db@skylab2000.com
X-Mailer: Turbo-Mailer
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] [skylab2000] a lovely story for you

Hi all, 

The next live skylab2000 show is in Nagasaki, Japan. Since most of you wont make it, I thought I'd just tell ya bit about Mexico last week. Kind of a one off blog kinda thing. Fun, huh? 

Mexico.. Well, at first, no one was there to pick us up from the airport. Bad start. I tried a few phone numbers I had, but my spanish didn't help much here. No luck, so we just decided to have a seat at a bar, and decide what to do. We popped open a couple of Tecatas and ate some chips. After an hour we did see a girl with a sign, that said "DJ Danny Barton", so that must have meant us. :) 

We got in the car and there was lot of fast spanish talking into cell phones and a lot of general confusion about the hotel, customs, money, soundcheck etc etc. Mayhem, but we finally made it to the location. 

Not the club I was told it would be at, but now was a nice outdoor club called Yabu. Cool. Set up, did a sound check, and realized that a very important synth wasn't working properly. No big deal. I was a repair tech in a prior career, so after a while of poking and prodding, we were back in biz. Must have looked funny seeing me onstage with a pocketknife and travel screwdriver trying to fix a synth, but ya do whatever it takes. 

It was a great event with a ton of people, and was very fun to play for such a large enthusiastic crowd. Was mobbed afterwards for chit chat and sign-me-here and sign this. Fun, but a bit scary when there was people completely surrounding me. Fun to be famous now and again, but being truly famous 24/7 would be quite weird. 

Anyhow, hit the afterparty hoping for a ride back, as we were abndoned yet again, but had a great time there with large group of wonderful and friendly strangers. It was at a large house, so we got a great chance to meet so many cool Mexican people. Big thanks to the unnamed girt that trusted strange Americans and drove us back! 

Was a very fun trip, and I'm sure Japan will be even more of an adventure! 

Hope you enjoyed this email.. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

There are still some summer dates open for skylab2000, so if you do a club or event, please contact us. Easy to have skylab2000 play at your event! 

Lastly, the new folks on this list haven't heard info on the $5 live skylab2000 CD available, so here's info: "LIVE BOOTLEG B001" is out now! For ten years we have secretly recorded skylab2000 live sets, and now we are excited to release some of these live tracks in a series of low cost CDs called LIVE BOOTLEG. 

More info at http://skylab2000.com/b001.htm 
Audio sample only: http://skylab2000.com/b001sample.m3u 




Check out http://skylab2000.com 

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From: Erin Akamine <xiro317@mac.com>
Date: Sat, 23 Apr 2005 17:07:02 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.622)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] How do you feel about "Electric Guitars" in dance music?

In general, it tends to swing to the severe end of the good/bad 
spectrum: It can exponentially amplify the energy of an already great 
track into something truly inspiring & innovating, or it can take a 
perfect good tune & send its momentum to a crashing halt. I think, like 
the addition of any instrument, it depends on the skill of the 
musician/deejay; Last year Baby Mammoth's "Sizzling Finch" successfully 
incorporated a clarinet into one of their songs, which I never even 
thought could be remotely possible in a techno song, let alone be 
really cool.


On Apr 23, 2005, at 2:07 PM, Warren Shafor wrote:

> How do you feel about "Electric Guitars" in dance music?
>
> My self I find electric guitars are a good tool to move a crowd. The 
> new (Daft Punk) album use a ton of guitar loops in there newest album 
> called "We Are Human" If have have not heard none of the tracks then 
> you are missing out good French house music at its best. Much love 
> goes out to (Daft Punk)
>
> I feel the more that people experiment with musical instruments with 
> dance music. The more dance music will grow.
>
> My self I play the Electric Bass Guitar as well as Electric Guitar & I 
> would love to put my Bass Guitar into some of my mix sets. I think the 
> more musical instruments in the dance music would leave it open to new 
> ideas and sub styles such as (House Rock, Electric Trance) and so on.
>
> In my mind, when someone talks down on dance music saying it is crap. 
> I just laugh at them and think about how far we have made it in the 
> muisc world from Classical Orchestras to CD-DJ & Drum Machines.
>
>
> So let me hear your thoughts: D
>
>

> Do You Yahoo!?
> Tired of spam?  Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around
> http://mail.yahoo.com

In fact, I was probably at the same show as you stickman ;)=20

It was funny. The crowd would be bumpin and then the guitar would SLAM
in with this crazy repetitive riff and EVERY TIME the mob would leap
and howl and stomp. Elite.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ravemaster review

Some sick ass drum and bass last night.
That impressed me.

What did not impress me:

The constant feeling of unease that followed me all night.
The blood in the bathroom.
The 12-person brawl in the hallway that shut the party down. (How is
it every time I go to that venue, now, a fight breaks out?)
The fuckawful sound setup in the main room. Poor Dyloot trying to spin
trance in there. :/

I had fun anyway. Everyone was hella crazy and drunk and I laughed a lot.=
=20
But still. As fun as it may be to get rowdy and beat up drug dealers,
do you really want people to remember your parties as brutally violent
and crazy? Being 'the other side' of rave culture doesn't mean you
have to cultivate the atmosphere of a gutter punk show.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] How do you feel about "Electric Guitars" in dance music?

--0-2109067355-1114352072=:97932
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

thanks for all the feedback i think it is fucking really good to use new styles of music in dance :-) if anyone can get there hands on this track it is hot. i know for a fact Felix The House cat is banging this track Death_From_Above - Romantic Rights (Erol Alkan Remix) it is pure raw nrg on the dance floor :-) or just pick up MIXMAG and get the free cd that felix the house mixed for them :-) and if you are lucky you get to hear puff daddys house track. witch is not bad at all i can not belive felix da hosue cat made the beat for his track the song is called P Diddy - Jack U 
 
-warren 

Warren Shafor <daddy_g_dj@yahoo.com> wrote:
How do you feel about "Electric Guitars" in dance music?

My self I find electric guitars are a good tool to move a crowd. The new (Daft Punk) album use a ton of guitar loops in there newest album called "We Are Human" If have have not heard none of the tracks then you are missing out good French house music at its best. Much love goes out to (Daft Punk) 

I feel the more that people experiment with musical instruments with dance music. The more dance music will grow.

My self I play the Electric Bass Guitar as well as Electric Guitar & I would love to put my Bass Guitar into some of my mix sets. I think the more musical instruments in the dance music would leave it open to new ideas and sub styles such as (House Rock, Electric Trance) and so on. 

In my mind, when someone talks down on dance music saying it is crap. I just laugh at them and think about how far we have made it in the muisc world from Classical Orchestras to CD-DJ & Drum Machines. 


So let me hear your thoughts: D

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ravemaster review

I left that part out on purpose.  I don't like fighting and I think that 
it's lame that the dude sucker punched me in the first place.  I don't feel 
bad about beating them up, but I don't want people to look at us and think 
that we're shit disturbers.  We really are peaceful people who throw good 
parties with a good vibe.  I honestly don't think that we started any of the 
drama friday night.  It was a birthday party for a really good friend and 
people brought their drama in the party.  As far as the party went; it was 
off the chain.  As far as fighting, I'd perfer that never happen.  In any 
case, it was a crazy night that I'll never forget.
-jf

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ravemaster review

something weird is going on with BayRaves and DNS, so I'll just say
this here: violence leads to retaliation. some kid tried to jack me at
a rave, he put me in a half nelson and I just twisted out of it and
turned around and looked at him. I had been studying Tai Chi, if you
study Tai Chi you learn there's no such thing as an unbreakable hold.
so now I'm looking at this kid who tried to jack me. he was like a
foot shorter than me and fifty pounds lighter at least, but he was
black, and in America a black kid will be described as a "big black
guy" whether he's 8 feet tall or 4 feet tall. so I just stared at him,
like, you're black, you're a guy, but you're not a big black guy.
you're short, you're ten years younger than me, you have the physical
build of a willow tree, your unbreakable hold was very breakable, the
light you turned out I just turned back on, and now you're looking at
a large man from Chicago who isn't scared of shit. what are you going
to do? and he ran away. which realistically was a very sensible
choice.

I never laid a finger on him. I just showed him that my understanding
of fighting was infinitely superior to his, and then I stared him in
the eyes. and that was the worst thing that happened to him all night.
and he never had to beg anyone for mercy.

if these guys were seriously begging you not to hit them any more then
you should have stopped hitting them. there's a lot of people in
certain cultures who go around getting into fights so that women will
look at them. that's all there is to what they're doing. they don't
hit hard; in fact, when they get arrested, they look out for each
other. they lie to the cops and say, no, we weren't fighting. a dude
who thinks that way will go out in a gang to beat up some other dudes
from some other gang, but if the cops ask a guy from gang A if some
guy from gang B was fighting them, they'll say no. because the truth
is they're not really fighting at all.

if you're hitting somebody so hard that they're begging for mercy,
THAT is fighting. if you hit somebody and they're still standing
afterwards, that's not fighting. that's just look-at-me bullshit. it's
just a method of getting female attention.

it's a fucked up method, yes. but responding to violence with more
severe violence is not going to work. it's bad for the scene, it's bad
for your soul, it's bad for the world. use your strength to neutralize
violence, to see it coming and to defuse it. stooping to their level
only degrades your parties. if you're stronger than they are and
smarter than they are, use your intelligence to see their next move
before they make it, and use your strength to protect them from their
own stupidity. they are the weak and the foolish, and they are more
dangerous to themselves than they are to you.

hope your armpit heals OK.

Subject: Fwd: [sfraves] Record shopping in Minneapolis/St. Paul

vital vinyl and let it be were fantastic record shops!

let it be had a very diverse selection of music.  lots of house and
techno.  breaks selection sucked, but they did have a fair amount of
old soul and rnb.  good stuff!

vital vinyl had more breaks than any SF store i've been to so far.=20
really good selection.  i listened to maybe 60-100 records there.  and
brought home about a dozen.

didn't get out clubbing.  but did drink my ass off.

yay.

Just to explain to everyone how it went down..

I came in the room after these guys has already disrespect a female 
friend of ours and MC Fader was just sticking up for her. I had pushed 
fader out of the room and got him to calm down but the guys kept going 
on and on. One of them then punched me in the back of the head and I was 
only truing to break it up. They then threw a second punch at Joey and 
all hell broke lose. We did out very best to control the situation. This 
was about the 4th time that night these guys were caught trying to start 
a fight. We did not want anyone to get hurt and it sucks the night ended 
this way.

Sorry for the multiple posts.

-- 
SideShow Nick

DJ Soundwave wrote:

>something weird is going on with BayRaves and DNS, so I'll just say
>this here: violence leads to retaliation. some kid tried to jack me at
>a rave, he put me in a half nelson and I just twisted out of it and
>turned around and looked at him. I had been studying Tai Chi, if you
>study Tai Chi you learn there's no such thing as an unbreakable hold.
>so now I'm looking at this kid who tried to jack me. he was like a
>foot shorter than me and fifty pounds lighter at least, but he was
>black, and in America a black kid will be described as a "big black
>guy" whether he's 8 feet tall or 4 feet tall. so I just stared at him,
>like, you're black, you're a guy, but you're not a big black guy.
>you're short, you're ten years younger than me, you have the physical
>build of a willow tree, your unbreakable hold was very breakable, the
>light you turned out I just turned back on, and now you're looking at
>a large man from Chicago who isn't scared of shit. what are you going
>to do? and he ran away. which realistically was a very sensible
>choice.
>
>I never laid a finger on him. I just showed him that my understanding
>of fighting was infinitely superior to his, and then I stared him in
>the eyes. and that was the worst thing that happened to him all night.
>and he never had to beg anyone for mercy.
>
>if these guys were seriously begging you not to hit them any more then
>you should have stopped hitting them. there's a lot of people in
>certain cultures who go around getting into fights so that women will
>look at them. that's all there is to what they're doing. they don't
>hit hard; in fact, when they get arrested, they look out for each
>other. they lie to the cops and say, no, we weren't fighting. a dude
>who thinks that way will go out in a gang to beat up some other dudes
>from some other gang, but if the cops ask a guy from gang A if some
>guy from gang B was fighting them, they'll say no. because the truth
>is they're not really fighting at all.
>
>if you're hitting somebody so hard that they're begging for mercy,
>THAT is fighting. if you hit somebody and they're still standing
>afterwards, that's not fighting. that's just look-at-me bullshit. it's
>just a method of getting female attention.
>
>it's a fucked up method, yes. but responding to violence with more
>severe violence is not going to work. it's bad for the scene, it's bad
>for your soul, it's bad for the world. use your strength to neutralize
>violence, to see it coming and to defuse it. stooping to their level
>only degrades your parties. if you're stronger than they are and
>smarter than they are, use your intelligence to see their next move
>before they make it, and use your strength to protect them from their
>own stupidity. they are the weak and the foolish, and they are more
>dangerous to themselves than they are to you.
>
>hope your armpit heals OK.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>On 4/24/05, Joey Frisco <josephwhunt@hotmail.com> wrote:

>
>>I left that part out on purpose.  I don't like fighting and I think that
>>it's lame that the dude sucker punched me in the first place.  I don't feel
>>bad about beating them up, but I don't want people to look at us and think
>>that we're shit disturbers.  We really are peaceful people who throw good
>>parties with a good vibe.  I honestly don't think that we started any of the
>>drama friday night.  It was a birthday party for a really good friend and
>>people brought their drama in the party.  As far as the party went; it was
>>off the chain.  As far as fighting, I'd perfer that never happen.  In any
>>case, it was a crazy night that I'll never forget.
>>-jf

Subject: [sfraves] Chemical Imbalance Lastnight

OK... so like lastnight was weeeeird.. Like I really didn't plan @ all on
going out... on the Real, I was just gonna stay home & hunt 4 a fuckin'
article 4 my Accounting Class that startts on Thursaday & it's close 2
impossible finding this article... anywqze, so liek I"m on IRC in a few
channels & some1 mentioned RAVE, SF in 1 of them & I started talkin' 2
this random person, who later I found out his name was Tien, & we went 2
Chemical Imbalace in the City...

It was fun...  I mean.. I dunno.. I kinda felt kinda giped when i fronted
$20 @ the door 2 get in.. but oh well.. I had fun!!!  Totally man.. it
good seein' alota people I raely get 2 C & hang out w/ them!!!

There wre 3 sets that really got me... Nick Niqul spun this really Groovy
Breakbeats set.... danced as much as i could in there.. The Doctor was up
next in that room.. Ooooh my gosh.. i been waiting 4 a Jungle set all week
to dance tooo... YUM!!  LoL.. He dropped NIN in the middle of his set.. it
was Aw3some!!  Hello 2Day...

OK.. i do have 2 say that Miss Dragnfly's set was SIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIICK!!! 
I LOVED IT!!!She started out playing like 80's Rock Tunes like a few song
by like Def Lepard, Iron Maiden, Glen Fry,  The Alman Brother.. It was
fun... then she went in2 some UK hardhouse & directly in2 Techno.. oh
man.. Hard Techno.. I Loved it!!!  OH gosh man.. then she spun some EVIL
ELECTRO CLASH & somehow beat matched Ghetto Tek to it!!!  It was fun!! 
Then she went in2 "Hard Dance"... all throughout the rest of her set...

While Dragnfly was playing she did a few cartwheels after like jumping
from up behind the decks on2 the dance floor kinda Ninja style!  It was
Dope.. 'cause they even like well this monkey bar swingie thingie like
appeard in the DJ booth & like did 1 of those jumped up, grabbed it swing
bar, then like lifted, turned herself so that she was hangin' on the swing
by her legs.. then she started like mixing upside down.. It was AMAZING!!!
All this done while she was in a hella cute ass pink Tutu.. then i
remember her training as a Trapeze artist w/ Cirq DeSoile which explained
alot!!

1 of the best sets I've ever seened like in my whole life!!

Unfortunately, there wre cops wating outside, which i learned earlier,
visited TheDungeon & walked around... apparetnly there's neighbor
complaints & la la la.. so the party kinda ended early...

It was a fun time.. but seriously, Tien who a totally Groover newbie 2 the
scene as well as SF.. he just moved here 2 months ago from NJ...

OK.. hope all is Groovy & y'all have a Dope Week!!!

LoL.. Fun Fun Stuff!


-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: THRUST w/ Lee Coombs, Friday, April 29th @ Mighty

 A new residency for Lee Coombs at MIGHTY with Space Cowboy DJs on the Unim=
og
& Visuals by James Green of pixnstones.com

Space Cowboys are proud to welcome back good friend and rockstar Lee
Coombs. Lee is settling down for a chunky extended 4 hour set at
Mighty while the cowboys rock the Unimog out front.

THRUST Recordings is Lee's new label, and San Francisco's newest
party. Being one of his favorite cities in the world to DJ, he can't
wait. The full line-up includes members from crews that are helping to
make San Francisco one of the great breaks communities in the world:

Fred Funk (Brass Tax)
Goldilox (Brass Tax)
Samira (Seismic, SisterSF)
Aaron Jae (Evil Breaks)
Bam (Evil Breaks)
Adam Ohana (Get Freaky)

The guest list page is up and running on Lee's website, so get on it!

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  For the Kids, A NextAid Benefit - 15 May

--=====================_13085546==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Hosted By:
NextAid

When:
Sunday May 15, 2005
at 12:00 PM

Where:
Cafe Cocomo
650 Indiana St.
San Francisco, CA 94101
US

For the Kids, A NextAid Benefit - 15 May, 2005 In loving memory of Wert Terry

In the long-heralded San Francisco tradition of supporting worthy causes, 
the house music community is responding to such shocking statistics as the 
fact that 95% of the 15 million children orphaned by AIDS are living in 
Africa, and is joining forces to make a difference around the world. This 
same community united last year in the first "For the Kids" which was 
inspired by "For the Love" (2002), an unprecedented community event that 
raised money to help Wert Terry, a beloved member of the community, in his 
fight against cancer and towards his daughter's education.

This year's "For the Kids" is presented by: Grayhound, Om Records, DJ 
Adnan, Zone AV, Sunset/Pacific Sound, Raindance, Green Gorilla, Nitevibe, 
DJ Seven, Tweakin', Anon Salon, Opel Productions, Spundae, Cloud Factory, 
staplemusic, and SFbyDEF.

Artists include: Miguel Migs, Jeno, Garth, MRK aka Markie Mark, Ellen 
Ferrato, Adnan, Andy Caldwell, Rick Preston, M3, Little John, Tracy, Galen, 
Solar, Joshua, Monty Luke, TK Disko, Fluid, Late Night Sneaky, Antonio, DJ 
Seven, Nikola, Fil Latorre, and Dr. D.R.E.

With support from: YBR Promotions, WorldDJ.com, flavorpill, SFSTATION.com, 
and * The Big Love Show * on 90.1FM KZSU Stanford, EmailLabs.com

Café Cocomo
650 Indiana St. (Indiana @ Mariposa)
NOON - 2AM
Healthy Food & BBQ
Full Bar
21 + over

Come early for 3 PM set-times by Rick Preston and Miguel Migs

Sound: Funktion One and Cloud Factory
Silent Auction
Bazaar

Cover: $5 b4 3pm, $10 b4 7pm, $15 after 7pm

NextAid is a Los Angeles based non-profit organization dedicated to 
creating sustainable solutions for African children orphaned as a result of 
AIDS. By partnering with other organizations in the production of music 
benefits and awareness-raising activities, NextAid channels emergency and 
long-term aid to African children in need. NextAid is committed to 
represent the international dance community as the charity promoting an 
effective and practical response to the AIDS pandemic NextAid aims to 
inspire people into tangible action, taking responsibility and making a 
difference.

Proceeds from the event will go towards the building of an earth-friendly 
multi-purpose center for Youth for a Vision, a non-profit organization 
comprised of teens mostly orphaned by AIDS who use theater and music to 
teach AIDS awareness to their peers, literally saving lives. This center 
will serve as a template for future centers throughout Africa. One of the 
center's buildings will be named after Wert Terry.

<http://nexstaid.org/>http://nextaid.org/



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_13085546==.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  The PC and the Internet sprang from pot-smoking,
  acid-dropping California dreamers

--=====================_18281327==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed



The PC and the Internet sprang from pot-smoking, acid-dropping California 
dreamers

The author even recounts how Apple founder Steve Jobs once told him that 
"taking LSD was one of the two or three most important things he had done 
in his life."

By John Markoff

VIKING; 310 PAGES; $25.95

----------
In the world of high technology, a visionary is a person whose obsessively 
held hunch happens to come true. For everyone else, fate holds either 
obscurity, or, for an unlucky few, habitual derision, as with Digital 
Equipment Corp. founder Ken Olsen, who has been unfairly held up as an 
example of technological cluelessness ever since he told a convention in 
1977 that "there is no reason for any individual to have a computer in his 
home."

A similar fate was courted by Xerox Corp. when it elected not to 
commercialize the Alto, a prototype personal computer invented at its Palo 
Alto Research Center (PARC) in 1973, almost a decade before companies like 
Apple, Radio Shack and IBM entered the PC market. In contrast, PARC itself 
would go down in business history as a nexus of farsighted West Coast 
researchers who were ignored by their buttoned-down East Coast masters.

John Markoff, a San Francisco technology writer for the New York Times, 
extends this visionary-centered narrative even deeper into the history of 
personal computing and the Internet. "What the Dormouse Said: How the 60s 
Counterculture Shaped the Personal Computer Industry" is an enthusiastic 
argument in favor of the idea that it was the uniquely Californian scene 
that brought forth the technologies we depend on so much today -- that the 
PC and the Internet sprang as much from a cultural environment of 
back-to-nature independence, personal freedom and psychedelic drugs as they 
did from engineering diagrams.

Based on the evidence Markoff presents, there is much to this. The most 
recent ancestors of modern PCs were the kit-based computers beloved by 
hobbyists in the mid-1970s (a favorite model was the Altair 8800), and one 
of the centers of the hobby movement was Menlo Park's own Homebrew Computer 
Club, founded in 1975 by peace activist Fred Moore. Homebrewers swapped 
software and components and advised each other on how to build computers 
from the ground up -- a do-it-yourself ethos with close links both to the 
Whole Earth Catalog phenomenon and to the ideas of radical educator Ivan 
Illich, who believed that technology should be limited to the human scale.

Homebrew was in turn an outgrowth of the storefront-based People's Computer 
Co. (PCC), which played a vanguard role in selling hands-on computing time 
and training to anyone who walked in off the street. PCC was one expression 
of the era's general reaction against corporate power, which in the world 
of computing was symbolized by the "glass house": the room in which the 
central computer was kept, attended by its priesthood of operators. For 
frustrated scientists and hackers, the notion of having a computer 
dedicated to an individual was immensely attractive. As Ted Nelson declared 
in his influential 1974 manifesto, "Computer Lib/Dream Machines," computing 
should be available to all, "without necessary [sic] complication or human 
servility being required."


MORE: 
http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2005/04/24/RVGSIC93AT1.DTL&type=printable





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


The US is:  "...a nation of 200 million used-car salesmen with all the 
money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_18281327==.ALT--

> 
> My self I find electric guitars are a good tool to move a crowd. The new (Daft Punk) album use a ton of guitar loops in there newest album called "We Are Human" If have have not heard none of the tracks then you are missing out good French house music at its best. Much love goes out to (Daft Punk)  
> 
> I feel the more that people experiment with musical instruments with dance music. The more dance music will grow.
> 
> My self I play the Electric Bass Guitar as well as Electric Guitar & I would love to put my Bass Guitar into some of my mix sets. I think the more musical instruments in the dance music would leave it open to new ideas and sub styles such as (House Rock, Electric Trance) and so on. 
> 
> In my mind, when someone talks down on dance music saying it is crap. I just laugh at them and think about how far we have made it in the muisc world from Classical Orchestras to CD-DJ & Drum Machines. 
> 
>

> crowd. The new (Daft Punk) album use a ton of guitar loops in
> there newest album called "We Are Human" If have have not
> heard none of the tracks then you are missing out good French
> house music at its best. Much love goes out to (Daft Punk)  
> > 
> > I feel the more that people experiment with musical
> instruments with dance music. The more dance music will grow.
> > 
> > My self I play the Electric Bass Guitar as well as Electric
> Guitar & I would love to put my Bass Guitar into some of my
> mix sets. I think the more musical instruments in the dance
> music would leave it open to new ideas and sub styles such as
> (House Rock, Electric Trance) and so on. 
> > 
> > In my mind, when someone talks down on dance music saying
> it is crap. I just laugh at them and think about how far we
> have made it in the muisc world from Classical Orchestras to
> CD-DJ & Drum Machines. 
> > 
> > 
> > So let me hear your thoughts: D
> > 
> > 
> > __________________________________________________
> > Do You Yahoo!?
> > Tired of spam?  Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection
> around 
> > http://mail.yahoo.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] How do you feel about "Electric Guitars" in dance music?

i started doing live mashups of that song about 3 years ago. 
granted, it didn't go over as nicely as i wanted (real-time
drummer made it difficult) but it was worth it to see the
shocked expressions on peoples' faces.  most didn't like it:
pretty similar to the response to my techno mashup of
starship's "we built this city".

speaking of "owner of a lonely heart", a friend of mine once
played that song at DVC, wearing a suit made entirely of meat.

m

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Quote of the Day (Tue)

last night, a friend of mine told me a funny horror restaurant horror story,
something we've all had at one time or another.  this one is right out of a
movie it seems like though.

he was at this lazy south carolinan diner having some lunch with a few
friends.  no brand name diner, just something like suzy's diner or whatever.
his friend was drinking his iced tea and suddenly discovered there was a fly
in the drink.  they called the waitress over, and guess what the waitress
did?  you guessed it!  she came right over there, stuck her hand in the
glass, pulled the fly out, and said "is that good enough for you?"  he said
they were laughing their asses off right after that.  this was around lunch
time.  i asked them if they left after that and he said he wasn't sure, he
thought so.

do you have any funny restaurant horror stories that sound like they came
out of better off dead or some comedy movie?  let us know!

--

How the elephant got into my pajamas I'll never know.

- Marx, "Animal Crackers"

Subject: [sfraves] National Dance Week - Dance is Sacred

Happy National Dance Week :)

http://bacndw.org/index.php

All free! All dance! All week!
Bay Area Celebrates National Dance Week is an annual week of free dance 
events in the Bay Area that are open to the public. National Dance Week 
showcases the dynamic diversity and critically acclaimed quality of Bay 
Area dance, to educate audiences about dance that is accessible in their 
own communities, and to increase the visibility of individual artists, 
companies, studios, and theaters.

ALL FREE, ALL DANCE, ALL WEEK
sponsored by
Voice of Dance
the ultimate
online resource
for dance

Bay Area Celebrates National Dance Week began in 1998, and now more than 
300 artists and organizations participate. Please join us in the Bay 
Area's celebration of National Dance Week!

From sfraves-return-120912-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 27 13:31:01 2005
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-120912-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Received: (qmail 49416 invoked by uid 1101); 27 Apr 2005 13:31:00 -0000
Date: Wed, 27 Apr 2005 06:31:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20050427062913.O28838@taz3.hyperreal.org>
Hyperreal<-_->http: //www.hyperreal.org/ SFRaves<-_->http://www.sfraves.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] What is SFRaves? (That 'Ol Vision Thang)

In the seven years of my volunteer work and responsibility to this 
community, as well as the 13 years I've followed SFRaves & Hyperreal.org: 
This has always been my inspiration as well as my guide, this is the 
vision I hope that SFRaves is to this community. SFRaves is a beautiful 
gift to all of us, let its future be bright, positive and a dream turned 
into reality. <3 Karina

>From the FAQ located @ http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/doc/whatis

In the wise words of Brian Behlendorf, SFRaves Founder:

"...
Subject:
A little of that ol' VISION thang.
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Fri, 2 Jul 1993 11:14:36 -0700
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu

I'm not sure exactly what form this post is going to make, it's gonna come 
out pretty stream of conscious-like, but then again everything I've ever 
written here has been stream of consciousness so I'm not worried. Just 
giving you warning to bear with me.  In fact, now that I've written it and 
like it, I'll add a PLEASE READ THIS, NOW.

 	*what* is SFRaves?

 	The idea mainly came out of frustration with my situation back in 
March 1992.  I had moved up from LA the previous fall, where I had been 
going out once a week to parties down there, and when I moved up here I 
found myself completely out of touch with what was going on.  I heard 
about one called ToonTown, tried to go to it, but alas found out after 
waiting an hour and a half in line at King St Garage that it was 21+, 
something I had never run into in LA.  I had heard about parties here and 
there, but never could find anyone who even liked the music enough to want 
to venture out and check them out.  I also feel in love with the Internet 
at this time, and I saw a post from a certain Jon Drukman mentioning the 
Woopy Ball on the Manchester mailing list, and another post from someone 
on rec.music.industrial about a local party.  I figured there HAD to be 
SOME people on the net who knew what was up around here, so I asked the 
sysadmin of my machine if I could run a mailing list and he said sure.

 	Within a week we had 80 subscribers.  The Woopy Ball was the first 
weekend, and I met Jon and Mike there, and Andrea, and it began to click 
that maybe there were quite a few people on this; and I began to become 
really good friends with many of you, which was completely different from 
my college social environment in which I found most people rather cold and 
self-absorbed.

We held a picnic in May, and it clicked that here we had an incredible 
group of people who have this elusive thing called a "vibe"... and I began 
to feel like family with you, and with the list at large, and I began to 
be less and less inhibited about what I post, who I talk to, everything. 
It's like someone said, it feels like the community of SFRaves have always 
existed, it just took an entry in an aliases file to bring us all 
together.

 	And then we threw Connection, which, until the day I get married 
and/or the day I die, will rank as the most intense experience I have ever 
had.  It was the feel of a community putting on a party, where everyone 
felt GOOD, where we felt like we were leapfrogging into a future full of 
warmth.  It was a personally very transformational thing for me, and I 
think the same is true for many others.

 	It was also the beginning of my journey into the realm of becoming 
someone in the SF House Music culture.  I found a group of people I really 
liked being with; I also found that our method of communication could be a 
model, a basis for something bigger.  Even as we were having the time of 
our lives, we began to identify things in the scene, and even in the 
world, that we wanted to see changed.  SFRaves became a channeler for 
memes, for emotions, for expressions on what house culture is and how San 
Francisco is/could be the center of it all.

 	Now, you could say I got stars in my eyes... but I don't think it 
was unjustified, and I know many people felt the same way too.  I didn't 
feel and still don't feel like I was responsible for it, I was just the 
janitor of this majestic House.

 	The cycles of life, though, ebb and flow, and as high as SFRaves 
ever got, there were low points too, points where I wanted to send a 
message to the list saying "UNSUBSCRIBE" or even consider shutting it down 
for a day or two to calm some peoples' nerves.  I ultimately resisted the 
urge, mainly because I believe the list could self-check itself, for every 
low the people would wake up and give it a high, etc.

 	However, this cycle concerned me because I was afraid (and still 
am) that this cycle could affect our ability to spread and enhance the 
vibe.  I wondered if this was just an expression of insecurity, if I 
really could define the "vibe" anyways.  I saw a huge procession of people 
subscribe and then unsubscribe within days... my rational side said ignore 
this, SFRaves shouldn't and can't please everyone, but my emotional side 
wanted SFRaves to serve as a basis for uniting people and engendering that 
"family" feel we all had at the beginning, towards the scene as a whole.

 	There are still lots of sicknesses in the scene, perhaps more now 
than ever, and if we could playa part, by spreading ideas and memes and 
opinions around for everyone to share, that we COULD make the scene 
better.  I wanted to include everyone on this - I was actively working to 
get the promoters I know hooked up in one way or another to share in this 
Great Experiment, because communication is the main thing I felt was 
missing in the scene. The Come/Unity meetings of promoters and DJs and 
concerned folk enhanced this, and I could see barriers of distrust being 
shattered.  I wanted to bring that to the electronic realm, and them to 
us, because I feel the synergy would just be incredible.

 	This is still a dream right now.  There are a few promoters on the 
net, some more vocal than others, there are a few DJ's, there are a LOT of 
people who go out and spread the vibe, and we are known as an entity by 
many if not most people in the scene.  The calendar you see every Thursday 
is going to have an "official" status, as a way for promoters to plan 
their schedules out and try and avoid massive clumping of parties around 
certain weekends.  In other words, we are making inroads.

 	But sometimes we stumble.  I haven't been communicating this dream 
as much over the net as I should have; I'd talk about it to others outside 
the scene, we'd become excited about the possibilities, and then we'd come 
home and read our email and get discouraged at times.

 	But there's no way I'm gonna give up that easily.  I *know* I'm 
not alone in this dream, and for the most part I think SFRaves has had 
that spreading-the-vibe effect for awhile.  But we have so much POTENTIAL 
I want to see used.  Right now the most vital thing the scene needs is 
COMMUNICATION, people need a forum for expressing their views and for 
listening and understanding each other.  Right now the many-to-many nature 
of email mailing lists is the single most powerful format for this. 
Let's use it right - let's take the concept of love, peace, harmony, and 
RESPECT for each other back into our lives and spread it.  I'm going to 
work this summer on making the SF scene the most wired scene on the planet 
(it already is, I'm gonna make it even more so), and watch the fireworks 
fly.  Sure, we'll always have our ups and downs, and I still want people 
to talk about ANYTHING they feel like talking about while still providing 
a high-qualityhigh signal-to-noise-ratio mailing list.

 	Remember that when you send mail to sfraves@hyperreal.org you are 
sending personal mail to about 500 people.  That is an awesome power for 
such a subtle action.  Please don't abuse it - use it freely, but just 
think about what you're saying for a second.  If it's something more 
appropriate in personal email, take it there.  But if it's something we 
all can learn from, by all means bring it forward.

 	SFRaves and the fractalizing threads that have led from it are the 
most significant thing that's ever happened to me.  I know most other 
people aren't going to go to THAT level of enthusiasm but I want people to 
feel what I'm feeling.  This "dream" I have of making SFRaves a powerfully 
positive force in the scene is nebulous, and we may never know if we've 
ever gotten there, but I think as long as we keep it in mind a lot of good 
can come about.  In fact, the medium has so much potential it is our 
RESPONSIBILITY to see this happens.  I've seen so much over the past month 
and a half of my travels that has led me to think we tend to take our 
scene for granted a lot, and its almost become a victim of its own 
success.  Let's not let that happen.

 	See you all at Connection 3!!

 	Brian


..."

-- 
**************************************************************
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
**************************************************************

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is SFRaves? (That 'Ol Vision Thang)

*sigh..*

Why, why, oh why, did I wait 'til 1999 to go to a rave?  (especially
when I'd been actively making "rave" music since '96 or '97?)

Looking at glowing texts like these really makes me feel like I missed
out on something really important.  My time in the scene, while short,
most certainly has been sweet..  ..but I think, by the time I got here,
most folks were over this whole "change the world" thing.

big effin' *sigh*

Oh well, at least the people I've met have been wonderful and I can't
complain in the least about my life..  Just wish I'd have taken notice
when those friends of mine started buying RECORDS of all things back in
the early 90s, instead of writing them off as stupid kids listening to
annoying "techno" music. ;)

Cheers,
-george cochrane | origami
-info (at) newstylesound.com
-djorigami.com
-foldedsf.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is SFRaves? (That 'Ol Vision Thang)

i wish i'd listened to this girl in my high school yearbook class back
in 1992 in southern california.

she was telling me about "raves" and "techno" and i just couldn't wrap
my head around the concept.  i was really curious and wanted to go,
but i was a pussy and couldn't break out of my shell.

i can't imagine what my life would be like if i'd gone to a party in
LA in 1992.  better?  worse?  who knows!

-b

From sfraves-return-120917-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 27 17:30:00 2005

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 64780 invoked from network); 27 Apr 2005 17:29:58 -0000
DomainKey-Signature: a=rsa-sha1; q=dns; c=nofws;
        s=beta; d=gmail.com;
        h=received:message-id:date:from:reply-to:to:subject:cc:in-reply-to:mime-version:content-type:content-transfer-encoding:content-disposition:references;
        b=JtdeUIP62kvCcFp3MjOVR+CaAa7X1hhqlzngJF2n9oWu1zFDvF4H+0uGpXiwhNwD+tLiROG5vWV0NGaxZM0Zninl7r8urOJNnefhCe9MbzidJLyGggzol5OIZ01rS6q7wsHiG7cjnFV35SaWq/adp4rLvrQnwUxnG1cKWAd696M=
Message-ID: <4688f311050427102978b259f8@mail.gmail.com>
Date: Wed, 27 Apr 2005 10:29:55 -0700
From: DJ Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
Reply-To: DJ Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
To: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20050427062913.O28838@taz3.hyperreal.org>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is SFRaves? (That 'Ol Vision Thang)

I like and admire Brian Behlendorf but I've seen this fucking e-mail
so many fucking times. what is he, the pope? this thing was written 12
years ago.

in nomine patrum, et filii, et spiritus sanctum :-p

1993 was an astonishing year for anyone with a computer, a brain, and
a love of electronic music, but for fuck's sake, it's 2005. some of
the kids you see at raves were BORN on the day this e-mail was sent.

!!!!!!

(sorry, I'm always a bit cranky before breakfast.)

if you meet the Buddha on the road, kill him.

hero worship is stupid. Brian Behlendorf didn't have the power to turn
back the hordes of MBAs who took over our little internet cultural
revolution thing and turned into the biggest scam until Enron. he's
just a guy. he's a cool guy. he's a smart guy. but he's just a fucking
guy. some cool shit that was right on the money in 1993 doesn't belong
in my inbox in 2005!!!!!!!!!!!!

definitely cranky. time for breakfast.

but if I have breakfast, I'll probably have to go to work.

OK, fuck it. I'll compromise. I'll have some coffee, and I'll continue
my tirade.

hold on.

**makes coffee**

**watches Invader Zim**

**plays drums**

**watches QBert DVD, attempts scratching**

**stalks the Tigger sluts**

holy shit.

are you people still HERE?

look. if there's something you find fascinating, if there's something
you love, if there's some memory from the past that you still adore,
take that vibe forward into the future for fuck's sake. the past is
the past. carpe diem or shut the fuck up. :-)


On 4/27/05, Karina <karina@hyperreal.org> wrote:
> In the seven years of my volunteer work and responsibility to this
> community, as well as the 13 years I've followed SFRaves & Hyperreal.org:
> This has always been my inspiration as well as my guide, this is the
> vision I hope that SFRaves is to this community. SFRaves is a beautiful
> gift to all of us, let its future be bright, positive and a dream turned
> into reality. <3 Karina
>=20
> From the FAQ located @ http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/doc/whatis
>=20
> In the wise words of Brian Behlendorf, SFRaves Founder:
>=20
> "...
> Subject:
> A little of that ol' VISION thang.
> From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
> Date: Fri, 2 Jul 1993 11:14:36 -0700
> To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
>=20
> I'm not sure exactly what form this post is going to make, it's gonna com=
e
> out pretty stream of conscious-like, but then again everything I've ever
> written here has been stream of consciousness so I'm not worried. Just
> giving you warning to bear with me.  In fact, now that I've written it an=
d
> like it, I'll add a PLEASE READ THIS, NOW.
>=20
>         *what* is SFRaves?
>=20
>         The idea mainly came out of frustration with my situation back in
> March 1992.  I had moved up from LA the previous fall, where I had been
> going out once a week to parties down there, and when I moved up here I
> found myself completely out of touch with what was going on.  I heard
> about one called ToonTown, tried to go to it, but alas found out after
> waiting an hour and a half in line at King St Garage that it was 21+,
> something I had never run into in LA.  I had heard about parties here and
> there, but never could find anyone who even liked the music enough to wan=
t
> to venture out and check them out.  I also feel in love with the Internet
> at this time, and I saw a post from a certain Jon Drukman mentioning the
> Woopy Ball on the Manchester mailing list, and another post from someone
> on rec.music.industrial about a local party.  I figured there HAD to be
> SOME people on the net who knew what was up around here, so I asked the
> sysadmin of my machine if I could run a mailing list and he said sure.
>=20
>         Within a week we had 80 subscribers.  The Woopy Ball was the firs=
t
> weekend, and I met Jon and Mike there, and Andrea, and it began to click
> that maybe there were quite a few people on this; and I began to become
> really good friends with many of you, which was completely different from
> my college social environment in which I found most people rather cold an=
d
> self-absorbed.
>=20
> We held a picnic in May, and it clicked that here we had an incredible
> group of people who have this elusive thing called a "vibe"... and I bega=
n
> to feel like family with you, and with the list at large, and I began to
> be less and less inhibited about what I post, who I talk to, everything.
> It's like someone said, it feels like the community of SFRaves have alway=
s
> existed, it just took an entry in an aliases file to bring us all
> together.
>=20
>         And then we threw Connection, which, until the day I get married
> and/or the day I die, will rank as the most intense experience I have eve=
r
> had.  It was the feel of a community putting on a party, where everyone
> felt GOOD, where we felt like we were leapfrogging into a future full of
> warmth.  It was a personally very transformational thing for me, and I
> think the same is true for many others.
>=20
>         It was also the beginning of my journey into the realm of becomin=
g
> someone in the SF House Music culture.  I found a group of people I reall=
y
> liked being with; I also found that our method of communication could be =
a
> model, a basis for something bigger.  Even as we were having the time of
> our lives, we began to identify things in the scene, and even in the
> world, that we wanted to see changed.  SFRaves became a channeler for
> memes, for emotions, for expressions on what house culture is and how San
> Francisco is/could be the center of it all.
>=20
>         Now, you could say I got stars in my eyes... but I don't think it
> was unjustified, and I know many people felt the same way too.  I didn't
> feel and still don't feel like I was responsible for it, I was just the
> janitor of this majestic House.
>=20
>         The cycles of life, though, ebb and flow, and as high as SFRaves
> ever got, there were low points too, points where I wanted to send a
> message to the list saying "UNSUBSCRIBE" or even consider shutting it dow=
n
> for a day or two to calm some peoples' nerves.  I ultimately resisted the
> urge, mainly because I believe the list could self-check itself, for ever=
y
> low the people would wake up and give it a high, etc.
>=20
>         However, this cycle concerned me because I was afraid (and still
> am) that this cycle could affect our ability to spread and enhance the
> vibe.  I wondered if this was just an expression of insecurity, if I
> really could define the "vibe" anyways.  I saw a huge procession of peopl=
e
> subscribe and then unsubscribe within days... my rational side said ignor=
e
> this, SFRaves shouldn't and can't please everyone, but my emotional side
> wanted SFRaves to serve as a basis for uniting people and engendering tha=
t
> "family" feel we all had at the beginning, towards the scene as a whole.
>=20
>         There are still lots of sicknesses in the scene, perhaps more now
> than ever, and if we could playa part, by spreading ideas and memes and
> opinions around for everyone to share, that we COULD make the scene
> better.  I wanted to include everyone on this - I was actively working to
> get the promoters I know hooked up in one way or another to share in this
> Great Experiment, because communication is the main thing I felt was
> missing in the scene. The Come/Unity meetings of promoters and DJs and
> concerned folk enhanced this, and I could see barriers of distrust being
> shattered.  I wanted to bring that to the electronic realm, and them to
> us, because I feel the synergy would just be incredible.
>=20
>         This is still a dream right now.  There are a few promoters on th=
e
> net, some more vocal than others, there are a few DJ's, there are a LOT o=
f
> people who go out and spread the vibe, and we are known as an entity by
> many if not most people in the scene.  The calendar you see every Thursda=
y
> is going to have an "official" status, as a way for promoters to plan
> their schedules out and try and avoid massive clumping of parties around
> certain weekends.  In other words, we are making inroads.
>=20
>         But sometimes we stumble.  I haven't been communicating this drea=
m
> as much over the net as I should have; I'd talk about it to others outsid=
e
> the scene, we'd become excited about the possibilities, and then we'd com=
e
> home and read our email and get discouraged at times.
>=20
>         But there's no way I'm gonna give up that easily.  I *know* I'm
> not alone in this dream, and for the most part I think SFRaves has had
> that spreading-the-vibe effect for awhile.  But we have so much POTENTIAL
> I want to see used.  Right now the most vital thing the scene needs is
> COMMUNICATION, people need a forum for expressing their views and for
> listening and understanding each other.  Right now the many-to-many natur=
e
> of email mailing lists is the single most powerful format for this.
> Let's use it right - let's take the concept of love, peace, harmony, and
> RESPECT for each other back into our lives and spread it.  I'm going to
> work this summer on making the SF scene the most wired scene on the plane=
t
> (it already is, I'm gonna make it even more so), and watch the fireworks
> fly.  Sure, we'll always have our ups and downs, and I still want people
> to talk about ANYTHING they feel like talking about while still providing
> a high-qualityhigh signal-to-noise-ratio mailing list.
>=20
>         Remember that when you send mail to sfraves@hyperreal.org you are
> sending personal mail to about 500 people.  That is an awesome power for
> such a subtle action.  Please don't abuse it - use it freely, but just
> think about what you're saying for a second.  If it's something more
> appropriate in personal email, take it there.  But if it's something we
> all can learn from, by all means bring it forward.
>=20
>         SFRaves and the fractalizing threads that have led from it are th=
e
> most significant thing that's ever happened to me.  I know most other
> people aren't going to go to THAT level of enthusiasm but I want people t=
o
> feel what I'm feeling.  This "dream" I have of making SFRaves a powerfull=
y
> positive force in the scene is nebulous, and we may never know if we've
> ever gotten there, but I think as long as we keep it in mind a lot of goo=
d
> can come about.  In fact, the medium has so much potential it is our
> RESPONSIBILITY to see this happens.  I've seen so much over the past mont=
h
> and a half of my travels that has led me to think we tend to take our
> scene for granted a lot, and its almost become a victim of its own
> success.  Let's not let that happen.
>=20
>         See you all at Connection 3!!
>=20
>         Brian
>=20
> ..."
>=20
> --
> **************************************************************
> ******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
> If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
> much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
> & in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
> -- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
> **************************************************************
>=20
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>=20
>=20


--=20
DJ Soundwave

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What is SFRaves? (That 'Ol Vision Thang)

carpe diem or stfu! biatch!

yeesh.

I went to Medusa's in Chicago when I was 17. I played dance music on
the radio when I was 16. I made beats on a Korg M1 when I was 15. This
was Chicago, late 80s. Worship my hairy balls.

Actually with all of that I still didn't go to my first rave until 97.
But that was still 8 years ago!!!!!!!!! Jebus.

(ps worshipping my hairy balls is not actually necessary.)

seriously all you do is this. look into the past. take the bits you
love, put those bits in your future. take the bits you hate, xerox
them, write the lesson you learned on the xerox, throw the original
away. take the bits you wish you had, the things you wanted, the
things that should have happened or could have happened or maybe would
have happened, and put those right smack dab in the middle of your
future so that you are heading straight towards them. and baddabing
baddabang, you're fucking DONE.

> my head around the concept.  i was really curious and wanted to go,
> but i was a pussy and couldn't break out of my shell.
>=20

> LA in 1992.  better?  worse?  who knows!
>=20

>=20

SO given the fact that this was sent out as an impetus, let's rephrase the 
question.

What *is your definition* SFRaves ? (2005)

I concur with many of the things said, this isn't so much about 
worshipping the past as it is taking bits and pieces of it, reflecting on 
it at present, and looking towards the future.

From sfraves-return-120921-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 27 20:02:25 2005
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-120921-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 50095 invoked by uid 1103); 27 Apr 2005 20:02:24 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 50074 invoked from network); 27 Apr 2005 20:02:23 -0000

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy

On Wed, 27 Apr 2005, Karina wrote:

-&e->In the seven years of my volunteer work and responsibility to this
-&e->community, as well as the 13 years I've followed SFRaves & Hyperreal.org:
-&e->This has always been my inspiration as well as my guide, this is the vision
-&e->I hope that SFRaves is to this community. SFRaves is a beautiful gift to
-&e->all of us, let its future be bright, positive and a dream turned into
-&e->reality. <3 Karina
-&e->
-&e->> From the FAQ located @ http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/doc/whatis
-&e->
-&e->In the wise words of Brian Behlendorf, SFRaves Founder:
-&e->
-&e->"...
-&e->Subject:
-&e->A little of that ol' VISION thang.
-&e->From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
-&e->Date: Fri, 2 Jul 1993 11:14:36 -0700
-&e->To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
-&e->
-&e->I'm not sure exactly what form this post is going to make, it's gonna come
-&e->out pretty stream of conscious-like, but then again everything I've ever
-&e->written here has been stream of consciousness so I'm not worried. Just
-&e->giving you warning to bear with me.  In fact, now that I've written it and
-&e->like it, I'll add a PLEASE READ THIS, NOW.
-&e->
-&e->	*what* is SFRaves?
-&e->
-&e->	The idea mainly came out of frustration with my situation back in
-&e->March 1992.  I had moved up from LA the previous fall, where I had been
-&e->going out once a week to parties down there, and when I moved up here I
-&e->found myself completely out of touch with what was going on.  I heard about
-&e->one called ToonTown, tried to go to it, but alas found out after waiting an
-&e->hour and a half in line at King St Garage that it was 21+, something I had
-&e->never run into in LA.  I had heard about parties here and there, but never
-&e->could find anyone who even liked the music enough to want to venture out
-&e->and check them out.  I also feel in love with the Internet at this time,
-&e->and I saw a post from a certain Jon Drukman mentioning the Woopy Ball on
-&e->the Manchester mailing list, and another post from someone on
-&e->rec.music.industrial about a local party.  I figured there HAD to be SOME
-&e->people on the net who knew what was up around here, so I asked the sysadmin
-&e->of my machine if I could run a mailing list and he said sure.
-&e->
-&e->	Within a week we had 80 subscribers.  The Woopy Ball was the first
-&e->weekend, and I met Jon and Mike there, and Andrea, and it began to click
-&e->that maybe there were quite a few people on this; and I began to become
-&e->really good friends with many of you, which was completely different from
-&e->my college social environment in which I found most people rather cold and
-&e->self-absorbed.
-&e->
-&e->We held a picnic in May, and it clicked that here we had an incredible
-&e->group of people who have this elusive thing called a "vibe"... and I began
-&e->to feel like family with you, and with the list at large, and I began to be
-&e->less and less inhibited about what I post, who I talk to, everything. It's
-&e->like someone said, it feels like the community of SFRaves have always
-&e->existed, it just took an entry in an aliases file to bring us all together.
-&e->
-&e->	And then we threw Connection, which, until the day I get married
-&e->and/or the day I die, will rank as the most intense experience I have ever
-&e->had.  It was the feel of a community putting on a party, where everyone
-&e->felt GOOD, where we felt like we were leapfrogging into a future full of
-&e->warmth.  It was a personally very transformational thing for me, and I
-&e->think the same is true for many others.
-&e->
-&e->	It was also the beginning of my journey into the realm of becoming
-&e->someone in the SF House Music culture.  I found a group of people I really
-&e->liked being with; I also found that our method of communication could be a
-&e->model, a basis for something bigger.  Even as we were having the time of
-&e->our lives, we began to identify things in the scene, and even in the world,
-&e->that we wanted to see changed.  SFRaves became a channeler for memes, for
-&e->emotions, for expressions on what house culture is and how San Francisco
-&e->is/could be the center of it all.
-&e->
-&e->	Now, you could say I got stars in my eyes... but I don't think it
-&e->was unjustified, and I know many people felt the same way too.  I didn't
-&e->feel and still don't feel like I was responsible for it, I was just the
-&e->janitor of this majestic House.
-&e->
-&e->	The cycles of life, though, ebb and flow, and as high as SFRaves
-&e->ever got, there were low points too, points where I wanted to send a
-&e->message to the list saying "UNSUBSCRIBE" or even consider shutting it down
-&e->for a day or two to calm some peoples' nerves.  I ultimately resisted the
-&e->urge, mainly because I believe the list could self-check itself, for every
-&e->low the people would wake up and give it a high, etc.
-&e->
-&e->	However, this cycle concerned me because I was afraid (and still
-&e->am) that this cycle could affect our ability to spread and enhance the
-&e->vibe.  I wondered if this was just an expression of insecurity, if I really
-&e->could define the "vibe" anyways.  I saw a huge procession of people
-&e->subscribe and then unsubscribe within days... my rational side said ignore
-&e->this, SFRaves shouldn't and can't please everyone, but my emotional side
-&e->wanted SFRaves to serve as a basis for uniting people and engendering that
-&e->"family" feel we all had at the beginning, towards the scene as a whole.
-&e->
-&e->	There are still lots of sicknesses in the scene, perhaps more now
-&e->than ever, and if we could playa part, by spreading ideas and memes and
-&e->opinions around for everyone to share, that we COULD make the scene better.
-&e->I wanted to include everyone on this - I was actively working to get the
-&e->promoters I know hooked up in one way or another to share in this Great
-&e->Experiment, because communication is the main thing I felt was missing in
-&e->the scene. The Come/Unity meetings of promoters and DJs and concerned folk
-&e->enhanced this, and I could see barriers of distrust being shattered.  I
-&e->wanted to bring that to the electronic realm, and them to us, because I
-&e->feel the synergy would just be incredible.
-&e->
-&e->	This is still a dream right now.  There are a few promoters on the
-&e->net, some more vocal than others, there are a few DJ's, there are a LOT of
-&e->people who go out and spread the vibe, and we are known as an entity by
-&e->many if not most people in the scene.  The calendar you see every Thursday
-&e->is going to have an "official" status, as a way for promoters to plan their
-&e->schedules out and try and avoid massive clumping of parties around certain
-&e->weekends.  In other words, we are making inroads.
-&e->
-&e->	But sometimes we stumble.  I haven't been communicating this dream
-&e->as much over the net as I should have; I'd talk about it to others outside
-&e->the scene, we'd become excited about the possibilities, and then we'd come
-&e->home and read our email and get discouraged at times.
-&e->
-&e->	But there's no way I'm gonna give up that easily.  I *know* I'm not
-&e->alone in this dream, and for the most part I think SFRaves has had that
-&e->spreading-the-vibe effect for awhile.  But we have so much POTENTIAL I want
-&e->to see used.  Right now the most vital thing the scene needs is
-&e->COMMUNICATION, people need a forum for expressing their views and for
-&e->listening and understanding each other.  Right now the many-to-many nature
-&e->of email mailing lists is the single most powerful format for this. Let's
-&e->use it right - let's take the concept of love, peace, harmony, and RESPECT
-&e->for each other back into our lives and spread it.  I'm going to work this
-&e->summer on making the SF scene the most wired scene on the planet (it
-&e->already is, I'm gonna make it even more so), and watch the fireworks fly.
-&e->Sure, we'll always have our ups and downs, and I still want people to talk
-&e->about ANYTHING they feel like talking about while still providing a
-&e->high-qualityhigh signal-to-noise-ratio mailing list.
-&e->
-&e->	Remember that when you send mail to sfraves@hyperreal.org you are
-&e->sending personal mail to about 500 people.  That is an awesome power for
-&e->such a subtle action.  Please don't abuse it - use it freely, but just
-&e->think about what you're saying for a second.  If it's something more
-&e->appropriate in personal email, take it there.  But if it's something we all
-&e->can learn from, by all means bring it forward.
-&e->
-&e->	SFRaves and the fractalizing threads that have led from it are the
-&e->most significant thing that's ever happened to me.  I know most other
-&e->people aren't going to go to THAT level of enthusiasm but I want people to
-&e->feel what I'm feeling.  This "dream" I have of making SFRaves a powerfully
-&e->positive force in the scene is nebulous, and we may never know if we've
-&e->ever gotten there, but I think as long as we keep it in mind a lot of good
-&e->can come about.  In fact, the medium has so much potential it is our
-&e->RESPONSIBILITY to see this happens.  I've seen so much over the past month
-&e->and a half of my travels that has led me to think we tend to take our scene
-&e->for granted a lot, and its almost become a victim of its own success.
-&e->Let's not let that happen.
-&e->
-&e->	See you all at Connection 3!!
-&e->
-&e->	Brian
-&e->
-&e->
-&e->..."
-&e->
-&e->-- 
-&e->**************************************************************
-&e->******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
-&e->If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
-&e->much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
-&e->& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-&e->-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
-&e->**************************************************************
-&e->

-&e->For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
-&e->
