From sfraves-return-120923-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 27 20:13:31 2005
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-120923-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 59462 invoked by uid 1103); 27 Apr 2005 20:13:31 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 59440 invoked by uid 1101); 27 Apr 2005 20:13:30 -0000
Date: Wed, 27 Apr 2005 13:13:30 -0700 (PDT)
From: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <20050427131301.E28838@taz3.hyperreal.org>
Hyperreal<-_->http: //www.hyperreal.org/ SFRaves<-_->http://www.sfraves.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] News? : US: Ecstasy's Lost 'Its Panache' Among Teens

US: Ecstasy's Lost 'Its Panache' Among Teens
URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v05/n662/a12.html
Newshawk: Empower Activists www.drugsense.org/donate.htm
Rate this article Votes: 0
Webpage: 
http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2005-04-21-ecstasy-use-down_x.htm
Pubdate: Fri, 22 Apr 2005
Source: USA Today (US)
Page: 3A
Copyright: 2005 USA TODAY, a division of Gannett Co. Inc
Contact: editor@usatoday.com
Website: http://www.usatoday.com/news/nfront.htm
Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/466
Author: Donna Leinwand
Cited: DanceSafe http://www.dancesafe.org
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/mdma.htm (Ecstasy)
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/raves.htm (Raves)
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/pot.htm (Cannabis)
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/coke.htm (Cocaine)
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/heroin.htm (Heroin)
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/oxycontin.htm (Oxycontin/Oxycodone)
Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/topics/DanceSafe (DanceSafe)

ECSTASY'S LOST 'ITS PANACHE' AMONG TEENS

Ecstasy was the "it" drug among certain teens and young adults for a few 
years beginning in the late 1990s: a feel-good, dance-all-night stimulant 
that was a driving force behind rave parties that featured pulsating, 
melody-free music.

But after peaking in popularity in 2001, Ecstasy isn't so cool anymore.

Tighter airport security since the 9/11 attacks has pinched the flow of 
the drug into the USA from chief suppliers in the Netherlands and Belgium, 
making it less available and more expensive.

Meanwhile, federally funded anti-drug campaigns have produced poignant TV 
spots warning that Ecstasy users risk brain damage or death.

Teens and young adults have taken note.  Last year, 57.7% of high school 
seniors said they believed that taking Ecstasy just once or twice could 
harm them, up from 33.8% in 1997, according to an annual survey of teen 
drug use by the University of Michigan.

Mike, a 24-year-old musician from Long Island, N.Y., who didn't want his 
last name published because he is in drug treatment at Phoenix House in 
Ronkonkoma, N.Y., says he used to go to raves where Ecstasy was popular. 
But he says he stopped two years ago, after seeing "younger and younger" 
ravers get so high that "they would get incapacitated and lie there like 
dust."

Ecstasy is "just not new anymore," says Mark Brandl, executive director of 
DanceSafe Org, a New York-based group that works to prevent drug abuse 
among recreational users at nightclubs and raves.  "It's lost its .  .  . 
freshness, its panache."

Moving on to Other Drugs

The bad news, says Lloyd Johnston, chief investigator for the Michigan 
study, is that some teens appear to have moved on to drugs that are less 
expensive, more available and potentially just as dangerous.

The use of highly addictive prescription painkillers such as OxyContin and 
Vicodin has jumped since 2000, and both drugs have become more popular 
than Ecstasy among high school seniors, the Michigan study reported last 
year.

More than 9% of high school seniors said they had used Vicodin during the 
previous year, the study said, a level of popularity that roughly matched 
that of Ecstasy when it was at its peak four years ago.  About 5% of 
seniors said they had used OxyContin in the previous year, compared with 
4% who said they had taken Ecstasy.

When drug researchers at Michigan first started tracking OxyContin and 
Vicodin abuse among teens in 2002, many users tended to steal small doses 
from their parents' medicine cabinets.  "Trail mixing" parties -- where 
teens would mix pills in bowls and then hand them out randomly - -- gained 
popularity, according to the Community Epidemiology Working Group, 
researchers who report drug-use trends to the National Institute on Drug 
Abuse.

Teens also have gotten prescription narcotics from Internet pharmacies 
that sell such drugs illegally.  This week, agents with the Drug 
Enforcement Administration ( DEA ) and other agencies broke up an alleged 
drug ring that is accused of illegally selling more than 2.5 million pills 
a month via the Internet.

Some Internet pharmacies allow any teen with a credit card to order 
narcotics without a prescription.  Even after a big markup by sellers, the 
drugs often are cheaper than Ecstasy.  The price for Ecstasy varies; in 
some cities it can cost as much as $30 a pill, the DEA says.

Safer Than Street Drugs

Teens also perceive prescription drugs as safer than street drugs such as 
heroin and cocaine, Johnston says, adding that many teens don't appear to 
recognize the risks of abusing prescription drugs, or to understand that 
OxyContin is in the same drug family as heroin.

"The increases ( in prescription drug abuse ) aren't dramatic, but I find 
the absolute levels -- one in every 20 ( seniors having tried OxyContin ) 
-- disturbing," Johnston says.  "If I told you that 5% were using heroin, 
I think you'd go screaming into the night."

( Nearly 1% of high school seniors said last year that they had used 
heroin in the previous year, the Michigan study said.  )

Opening Door for Inhalants

Ecstasy's demise also appears to have cleared the way for a rise in teens' 
use of inhalants.

They were a problem a decade ago, before public health campaigns that 
warned of the damage they could cause to a person's brain and nervous 
system helped to dramatically lower usage among teens.

Now, a new generation of teens unfamiliar with those dangers is 
experimenting with inhalants, Johnston says.

Overall, the percentage of seniors who said they had used any illegal drug 
in the previous year dropped from 41.4% in 2001 to 38.8% in 2004, the 
Michigan study said.

Marijuana remains the most widely used illicit drug; last year 34.3% of 
high school seniors said they had used it in the previous year.

Ecstasy is difficult to make here because the U.S.  government monitors 
the necessary chemicals and it licenses pill-pressing machines.  Canada 
and the Netherlands do not license pill-pressers, and such chemicals are 
more available in the Netherlands.

Before 9/11, Ecstasy smugglers from Europe faced little scrutiny at U.S. 
airports.  They could move thousands of pills at once in suitcases or 
strapping packets to their bodies.

"It was coming right from Europe into ( John F.  Kennedy International 
Airport in New York ) in every way possible," says Dean Boyd, spokesman 
for Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

In fiscal 2002, customs and border agents seized a record 4,633 pounds of 
Ecstasy pills, up about 12.4% from the previous year.  That changed in 
2003, when Ecstasy smugglers began to avoid airports.  The amount seized 
that year dropped by more than 77%.

At the same time, Ecstasy's presence in the USA declined, suggesting that 
some drug rings scaled back their operations or simply gave up trying to 
send Ecstasy here.

Meanwhile, investigators' pursuits of Ecstasy distributors are beginning 
to pay off.  U.S.  and Canadian agents last year busted a smuggling ring 
that allegedly accounted for about 15% of the Ecstasy in the USA.

A DEA analysis later found that the average price of an Ecstasy pill 
jumped in several cities.  In New Orleans, undercover DEA agents paid an 
average of $17.50 a pill, up from $10.50.
MAP posted-by: Richard Lake

--

******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

On 4/27/05, Karina <karina@hyperreal.org> wrote:
> US: Ecstasy's Lost 'Its Panache' Among Teens
> URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v05/n662/a12.html
> Newshawk: Empower Activists www.drugsense.org/donate.htm
> Rate this article Votes: 0
> Webpage:
> http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2005-04-21-ecstasy-use-down_x.htm
> Pubdate: Fri, 22 Apr 2005
> Source: USA Today (US)
> Page: 3A
> Copyright: 2005 USA TODAY, a division of Gannett Co. Inc
> Contact: editor@usatoday.com
> Website: http://www.usatoday.com/news/nfront.htm
> Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/466
> Author: Donna Leinwand
> Cited: DanceSafe http://www.dancesafe.org
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/mdma.htm (Ecstasy)
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/raves.htm (Raves)
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/pot.htm (Cannabis)
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/coke.htm (Cocaine)
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/heroin.htm (Heroin)
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/oxycontin.htm (Oxycontin/Oxycodone)
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/topics/DanceSafe (DanceSafe)
>=20
> ECSTASY'S LOST 'ITS PANACHE' AMONG TEENS
>=20
> Ecstasy was the "it" drug among certain teens and young adults for a
few
> years beginning in the late 1990s: a feel-good, dance-all-night
stimulant
> that was a driving force behind rave parties that featured pulsating,
> melody-free music.
>=20
> But after peaking in popularity in 2001, Ecstasy isn't so cool
anymore.
>=20
> Tighter airport security since the 9/11 attacks has pinched the flow
of
> the drug into the USA from chief suppliers in the Netherlands and
Belgium,
> making it less available and more expensive.
>=20
> Meanwhile, federally funded anti-drug campaigns have produced poignant
TV
> spots warning that Ecstasy users risk brain damage or death.
>=20
> Teens and young adults have taken note.  Last year, 57.7% of high
school
> seniors said they believed that taking Ecstasy just once or twice
could
> harm them, up from 33.8% in 1997, according to an annual survey of
teen
> drug use by the University of Michigan.
>=20
> Mike, a 24-year-old musician from Long Island, N.Y., who didn't want
his
> last name published because he is in drug treatment at Phoenix House
in
> Ronkonkoma, N.Y., says he used to go to raves where Ecstasy was
popular.
> But he says he stopped two years ago, after seeing "younger and
younger"
> ravers get so high that "they would get incapacitated and lie there
like
> dust."
>=20
> Ecstasy is "just not new anymore," says Mark Brandl, executive
director of
> DanceSafe Org, a New York-based group that works to prevent drug abuse
> among recreational users at nightclubs and raves.  "It's lost its .  .
.
> freshness, its panache."
>=20
> Moving on to Other Drugs
>=20
> The bad news, says Lloyd Johnston, chief investigator for the Michigan
> study, is that some teens appear to have moved on to drugs that are
less
> expensive, more available and potentially just as dangerous.
>=20
> The use of highly addictive prescription painkillers such as OxyContin
and
> Vicodin has jumped since 2000, and both drugs have become more popular
> than Ecstasy among high school seniors, the Michigan study reported
last
> year.
>=20
> More than 9% of high school seniors said they had used Vicodin during
the
> previous year, the study said, a level of popularity that roughly
matched
> that of Ecstasy when it was at its peak four years ago.  About 5% of
> seniors said they had used OxyContin in the previous year, compared
with
> 4% who said they had taken Ecstasy.
>=20
> When drug researchers at Michigan first started tracking OxyContin and
> Vicodin abuse among teens in 2002, many users tended to steal small
doses
> from their parents' medicine cabinets.  "Trail mixing" parties --
where
> teens would mix pills in bowls and then hand them out randomly - --
gained
> popularity, according to the Community Epidemiology Working Group,
> researchers who report drug-use trends to the National Institute on
Drug
> Abuse.
>=20
> Teens also have gotten prescription narcotics from Internet pharmacies
> that sell such drugs illegally.  This week, agents with the Drug
> Enforcement Administration ( DEA ) and other agencies broke up an
alleged
> drug ring that is accused of illegally selling more than 2.5 million
pills
> a month via the Internet.
>=20
> Some Internet pharmacies allow any teen with a credit card to order
> narcotics without a prescription.  Even after a big markup by sellers,
the
> drugs often are cheaper than Ecstasy.  The price for Ecstasy varies;
in
> some cities it can cost as much as $30 a pill, the DEA says.
>=20
> Safer Than Street Drugs
>=20
> Teens also perceive prescription drugs as safer than street drugs such
as
> heroin and cocaine, Johnston says, adding that many teens don't appear
to
> recognize the risks of abusing prescription drugs, or to understand
that
> OxyContin is in the same drug family as heroin.
>=20
> "The increases ( in prescription drug abuse ) aren't dramatic, but I
find
> the absolute levels -- one in every 20 ( seniors having tried
OxyContin )
> -- disturbing," Johnston says.  "If I told you that 5% were using
heroin,
> I think you'd go screaming into the night."
>=20
> ( Nearly 1% of high school seniors said last year that they had used
> heroin in the previous year, the Michigan study said.  )
>=20
> Opening Door for Inhalants
>=20
> Ecstasy's demise also appears to have cleared the way for a rise in
teens'
> use of inhalants.
>=20
> They were a problem a decade ago, before public health campaigns that
> warned of the damage they could cause to a person's brain and nervous
> system helped to dramatically lower usage among teens.
>=20
> Now, a new generation of teens unfamiliar with those dangers is
> experimenting with inhalants, Johnston says.
>=20
> Overall, the percentage of seniors who said they had used any illegal
drug
> in the previous year dropped from 41.4% in 2001 to 38.8% in 2004, the
> Michigan study said.
>=20
> Marijuana remains the most widely used illicit drug; last year 34.3%
of
> high school seniors said they had used it in the previous year.
>=20
> Ecstasy is difficult to make here because the U.S.  government
monitors
> the necessary chemicals and it licenses pill-pressing machines.
Canada
> and the Netherlands do not license pill-pressers, and such chemicals
are
> more available in the Netherlands.
>=20
> Before 9/11, Ecstasy smugglers from Europe faced little scrutiny at
U.S.
> airports.  They could move thousands of pills at once in suitcases or
> strapping packets to their bodies.
>=20
> "It was coming right from Europe into ( John F.  Kennedy International
> Airport in New York ) in every way possible," says Dean Boyd,
spokesman
> for Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
>=20
> In fiscal 2002, customs and border agents seized a record 4,633 pounds
of
> Ecstasy pills, up about 12.4% from the previous year.  That changed in
> 2003, when Ecstasy smugglers began to avoid airports.  The amount
seized
> that year dropped by more than 77%.
>=20
> At the same time, Ecstasy's presence in the USA declined, suggesting
that
> some drug rings scaled back their operations or simply gave up trying
to
> send Ecstasy here.
>=20
> Meanwhile, investigators' pursuits of Ecstasy distributors are
beginning
> to pay off.  U.S.  and Canadian agents last year busted a smuggling
ring
> that allegedly accounted for about 15% of the Ecstasy in the USA.
>=20
> A DEA analysis later found that the average price of an Ecstasy pill
> jumped in several cities.  In New Orleans, undercover DEA agents paid
an
> average of $17.50 a pill, up from $10.50.
> MAP posted-by: Richard Lake
>=20

On 4/27/05, Karina <karina@hyperreal.org> wrote:
> US: Ecstasy's Lost 'Its Panache' Among Teens
> URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v05/n662/a12.html
> Newshawk: Empower Activists www.drugsense.org/donate.htm
> Rate this article Votes: 0
> Webpage:
> http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2005-04-21-ecstasy-use-down_x.htm
> Pubdate: Fri, 22 Apr 2005
> Source: USA Today (US)
> Page: 3A
> Copyright: 2005 USA TODAY, a division of Gannett Co. Inc
> Contact: editor@usatoday.com
> Website: http://www.usatoday.com/news/nfront.htm
> Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/466
> Author: Donna Leinwand
> Cited: DanceSafe http://www.dancesafe.org
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/mdma.htm (Ecstasy)
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/raves.htm (Raves)
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/pot.htm (Cannabis)
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/coke.htm (Cocaine)
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/heroin.htm (Heroin)
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/oxycontin.htm (Oxycontin/Oxycodone)
> Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/topics/DanceSafe (DanceSafe)
>
> ECSTASY'S LOST 'ITS PANACHE' AMONG TEENS
>
> Ecstasy was the "it" drug among certain teens and young adults for a few
> years beginning in the late 1990s: a feel-good, dance-all-night stimulant
> that was a driving force behind rave parties that featured pulsating,
> melody-free music.
>
> But after peaking in popularity in 2001, Ecstasy isn't so cool anymore.
>
> Tighter airport security since the 9/11 attacks has pinched the flow of
> the drug into the USA from chief suppliers in the Netherlands and Belgium,
> making it less available and more expensive.
>
> Meanwhile, federally funded anti-drug campaigns have produced poignant TV
> spots warning that Ecstasy users risk brain damage or death.
>
> Teens and young adults have taken note.  Last year, 57.7% of high school
> seniors said they believed that taking Ecstasy just once or twice could
> harm them, up from 33.8% in 1997, according to an annual survey of teen
> drug use by the University of Michigan.
>
> Mike, a 24-year-old musician from Long Island, N.Y., who didn't want his
> last name published because he is in drug treatment at Phoenix House in
> Ronkonkoma, N.Y., says he used to go to raves where Ecstasy was popular.
> But he says he stopped two years ago, after seeing "younger and younger"
> ravers get so high that "they would get incapacitated and lie there like
> dust."
>
> Ecstasy is "just not new anymore," says Mark Brandl, executive director of
> DanceSafe Org, a New York-based group that works to prevent drug abuse
> among recreational users at nightclubs and raves.  "It's lost its .  .  .
> freshness, its panache."
>
> Moving on to Other Drugs
>
> The bad news, says Lloyd Johnston, chief investigator for the Michigan
> study, is that some teens appear to have moved on to drugs that are less
> expensive, more available and potentially just as dangerous.
>
> The use of highly addictive prescription painkillers such as OxyContin and
> Vicodin has jumped since 2000, and both drugs have become more popular
> than Ecstasy among high school seniors, the Michigan study reported last
> year.
>
> More than 9% of high school seniors said they had used Vicodin during the
> previous year, the study said, a level of popularity that roughly matched
> that of Ecstasy when it was at its peak four years ago.  About 5% of
> seniors said they had used OxyContin in the previous year, compared with
> 4% who said they had taken Ecstasy.
>
> When drug researchers at Michigan first started tracking OxyContin and
> Vicodin abuse among teens in 2002, many users tended to steal small doses
> from their parents' medicine cabinets.  "Trail mixing" parties -- where
> teens would mix pills in bowls and then hand them out randomly - -- gained
> popularity, according to the Community Epidemiology Working Group,
> researchers who report drug-use trends to the National Institute on Drug
> Abuse.
>
> Teens also have gotten prescription narcotics from Internet pharmacies
> that sell such drugs illegally.  This week, agents with the Drug
> Enforcement Administration ( DEA ) and other agencies broke up an alleged
> drug ring that is accused of illegally selling more than 2.5 million pills
> a month via the Internet.
>
> Some Internet pharmacies allow any teen with a credit card to order
> narcotics without a prescription.  Even after a big markup by sellers, the
> drugs often are cheaper than Ecstasy.  The price for Ecstasy varies; in
> some cities it can cost as much as $30 a pill, the DEA says.
>
> Safer Than Street Drugs
>
> Teens also perceive prescription drugs as safer than street drugs such as
> heroin and cocaine, Johnston says, adding that many teens don't appear to
> recognize the risks of abusing prescription drugs, or to understand that
> OxyContin is in the same drug family as heroin.
>
> "The increases ( in prescription drug abuse ) aren't dramatic, but I find
> the absolute levels -- one in every 20 ( seniors having tried OxyContin )
> -- disturbing," Johnston says.  "If I told you that 5% were using heroin,
> I think you'd go screaming into the night."
>
> ( Nearly 1% of high school seniors said last year that they had used
> heroin in the previous year, the Michigan study said.  )
>
> Opening Door for Inhalants
>
> Ecstasy's demise also appears to have cleared the way for a rise in teens'
> use of inhalants.
>
> They were a problem a decade ago, before public health campaigns that
> warned of the damage they could cause to a person's brain and nervous
> system helped to dramatically lower usage among teens.
>
> Now, a new generation of teens unfamiliar with those dangers is
> experimenting with inhalants, Johnston says.
>
> Overall, the percentage of seniors who said they had used any illegal drug
> in the previous year dropped from 41.4% in 2001 to 38.8% in 2004, the
> Michigan study said.
>
> Marijuana remains the most widely used illicit drug; last year 34.3% of
> high school seniors said they had used it in the previous year.
>
> Ecstasy is difficult to make here because the U.S.  government monitors
> the necessary chemicals and it licenses pill-pressing machines.  Canada
> and the Netherlands do not license pill-pressers, and such chemicals are
> more available in the Netherlands.
>
> Before 9/11, Ecstasy smugglers from Europe faced little scrutiny at U.S.
> airports.  They could move thousands of pills at once in suitcases or
> strapping packets to their bodies.
>
> "It was coming right from Europe into ( John F.  Kennedy International
> Airport in New York ) in every way possible," says Dean Boyd, spokesman
> for Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
>
> In fiscal 2002, customs and border agents seized a record 4,633 pounds of
> Ecstasy pills, up about 12.4% from the previous year.  That changed in
> 2003, when Ecstasy smugglers began to avoid airports.  The amount seized
> that year dropped by more than 77%.
>
> At the same time, Ecstasy's presence in the USA declined, suggesting that
> some drug rings scaled back their operations or simply gave up trying to
> send Ecstasy here.
>
> Meanwhile, investigators' pursuits of Ecstasy distributors are beginning
> to pay off.  U.S.  and Canadian agents last year busted a smuggling ring
> that allegedly accounted for about 15% of the Ecstasy in the USA.
>
> A DEA analysis later found that the average price of an Ecstasy pill
> jumped in several cities.  In New Orleans, undercover DEA agents paid an
> average of $17.50 a pill, up from $10.50.
> MAP posted-by: Richard Lake
>
> --
> **************************************************************
> ******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************

> much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
> & in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
> -- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

>From: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>
>To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: [sfraves] News? : US: Ecstasy's Lost 'Its Panache' Among Teens
>Date: Wed, 27 Apr 2005 13:13:30 -0700 (PDT)
>
>US: Ecstasy's Lost 'Its Panache' Among Teens
>URL: http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v05/n662/a12.html
>Newshawk: Empower Activists www.drugsense.org/donate.htm
>Rate this article Votes: 0
>Webpage: 
>http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2005-04-21-ecstasy-use-down_x.htm
>Pubdate: Fri, 22 Apr 2005
>Source: USA Today (US)
>Page: 3A
>Copyright: 2005 USA TODAY, a division of Gannett Co. Inc
>Contact: editor@usatoday.com
>Website: http://www.usatoday.com/news/nfront.htm
>Details: http://www.mapinc.org/media/466
>Author: Donna Leinwand
>Cited: DanceSafe http://www.dancesafe.org
>Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/mdma.htm (Ecstasy)
>Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/raves.htm (Raves)
>Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/pot.htm (Cannabis)
>Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/coke.htm (Cocaine)
>Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/heroin.htm (Heroin)
>Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/oxycontin.htm (Oxycontin/Oxycodone)
>Bookmark: http://www.mapinc.org/topics/DanceSafe (DanceSafe)
>
>ECSTASY'S LOST 'ITS PANACHE' AMONG TEENS
>
>Ecstasy was the "it" drug among certain teens and young adults for a few 
>years beginning in the late 1990s: a feel-good, dance-all-night stimulant 
>that was a driving force behind rave parties that featured pulsating, 
>melody-free music.
>
>But after peaking in popularity in 2001, Ecstasy isn't so cool anymore.
>
>Tighter airport security since the 9/11 attacks has pinched the flow of the 
>drug into the USA from chief suppliers in the Netherlands and Belgium, 
>making it less available and more expensive.
>
>Meanwhile, federally funded anti-drug campaigns have produced poignant TV 
>spots warning that Ecstasy users risk brain damage or death.
>
>Teens and young adults have taken note.  Last year, 57.7% of high school 
>seniors said they believed that taking Ecstasy just once or twice could 
>harm them, up from 33.8% in 1997, according to an annual survey of teen 
>drug use by the University of Michigan.
>
>Mike, a 24-year-old musician from Long Island, N.Y., who didn't want his 
>last name published because he is in drug treatment at Phoenix House in 
>Ronkonkoma, N.Y., says he used to go to raves where Ecstasy was popular. 
>But he says he stopped two years ago, after seeing "younger and younger" 
>ravers get so high that "they would get incapacitated and lie there like 
>dust."
>
>Ecstasy is "just not new anymore," says Mark Brandl, executive director of 
>DanceSafe Org, a New York-based group that works to prevent drug abuse 
>among recreational users at nightclubs and raves.  "It's lost its .  .  . 
>freshness, its panache."
>
>Moving on to Other Drugs
>
>The bad news, says Lloyd Johnston, chief investigator for the Michigan 
>study, is that some teens appear to have moved on to drugs that are less 
>expensive, more available and potentially just as dangerous.
>
>The use of highly addictive prescription painkillers such as OxyContin and 
>Vicodin has jumped since 2000, and both drugs have become more popular than 
>Ecstasy among high school seniors, the Michigan study reported last year.
>
>More than 9% of high school seniors said they had used Vicodin during the 
>previous year, the study said, a level of popularity that roughly matched 
>that of Ecstasy when it was at its peak four years ago.  About 5% of 
>seniors said they had used OxyContin in the previous year, compared with 4% 
>who said they had taken Ecstasy.
>
>When drug researchers at Michigan first started tracking OxyContin and 
>Vicodin abuse among teens in 2002, many users tended to steal small doses 
>from their parents' medicine cabinets.  "Trail mixing" parties -- where 
>teens would mix pills in bowls and then hand them out randomly - -- gained 
>popularity, according to the Community Epidemiology Working Group, 
>researchers who report drug-use trends to the National Institute on Drug 
>Abuse.
>
>Teens also have gotten prescription narcotics from Internet pharmacies that 
>sell such drugs illegally.  This week, agents with the Drug Enforcement 
>Administration ( DEA ) and other agencies broke up an alleged drug ring 
>that is accused of illegally selling more than 2.5 million pills a month 
>via the Internet.
>
>Some Internet pharmacies allow any teen with a credit card to order 
>narcotics without a prescription.  Even after a big markup by sellers, the 
>drugs often are cheaper than Ecstasy.  The price for Ecstasy varies; in 
>some cities it can cost as much as $30 a pill, the DEA says.
>
>Safer Than Street Drugs
>
>Teens also perceive prescription drugs as safer than street drugs such as 
>heroin and cocaine, Johnston says, adding that many teens don't appear to 
>recognize the risks of abusing prescription drugs, or to understand that 
>OxyContin is in the same drug family as heroin.
>
>"The increases ( in prescription drug abuse ) aren't dramatic, but I find 
>the absolute levels -- one in every 20 ( seniors having tried OxyContin ) 
>-- disturbing," Johnston says.  "If I told you that 5% were using heroin, I 
>think you'd go screaming into the night."
>
>( Nearly 1% of high school seniors said last year that they had used heroin 
>in the previous year, the Michigan study said.  )
>
>Opening Door for Inhalants
>
>Ecstasy's demise also appears to have cleared the way for a rise in teens' 
>use of inhalants.
>
>They were a problem a decade ago, before public health campaigns that 
>warned of the damage they could cause to a person's brain and nervous 
>system helped to dramatically lower usage among teens.
>
>Now, a new generation of teens unfamiliar with those dangers is 
>experimenting with inhalants, Johnston says.
>
>Overall, the percentage of seniors who said they had used any illegal drug 
>in the previous year dropped from 41.4% in 2001 to 38.8% in 2004, the 
>Michigan study said.
>
>Marijuana remains the most widely used illicit drug; last year 34.3% of 
>high school seniors said they had used it in the previous year.
>
>Ecstasy is difficult to make here because the U.S.  government monitors the 
>necessary chemicals and it licenses pill-pressing machines.  Canada and the 
>Netherlands do not license pill-pressers, and such chemicals are more 
>available in the Netherlands.
>
>Before 9/11, Ecstasy smugglers from Europe faced little scrutiny at U.S. 
>airports.  They could move thousands of pills at once in suitcases or 
>strapping packets to their bodies.
>
>"It was coming right from Europe into ( John F.  Kennedy International 
>Airport in New York ) in every way possible," says Dean Boyd, spokesman for 
>Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
>
>In fiscal 2002, customs and border agents seized a record 4,633 pounds of 
>Ecstasy pills, up about 12.4% from the previous year.  That changed in 
>2003, when Ecstasy smugglers began to avoid airports.  The amount seized 
>that year dropped by more than 77%.
>
>At the same time, Ecstasy's presence in the USA declined, suggesting that 
>some drug rings scaled back their operations or simply gave up trying to 
>send Ecstasy here.
>
>Meanwhile, investigators' pursuits of Ecstasy distributors are beginning to 
>pay off.  U.S.  and Canadian agents last year busted a smuggling ring that 
>allegedly accounted for about 15% of the Ecstasy in the USA.
>
>A DEA analysis later found that the average price of an Ecstasy pill jumped 
>in several cities.  In New Orleans, undercover DEA agents paid an average 
>of $17.50 a pill, up from $10.50.
>MAP posted-by: Richard Lake
>
>--
>**************************************************************
>******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
>If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
>much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
>& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
>-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
>**************************************************************
>

>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> >ECSTASY'S LOST 'ITS PANACHE' AMONG TEENS
> >
> >Ecstasy was the "it" drug among certain teens and young adults for a few
> >years beginning in the late 1990s: a feel-good, dance-all-night stimulan=
t
> >that was a driving force behind rave parties that featured pulsating,
> >melody-free music.
> >
> >But after peaking in popularity in 2001, Ecstasy isn't so cool anymore.
> >
> >Tighter airport security since the 9/11 attacks has pinched the flow of =
the
> >drug into the USA from chief suppliers in the Netherlands and Belgium,
> >making it less available and more expensive.
> >
> >Meanwhile, federally funded anti-drug campaigns have produced poignant T=
V
> >spots warning that Ecstasy users risk brain damage or death.
> >
> >Teens and young adults have taken note.  Last year, 57.7% of high school
> >seniors said they believed that taking Ecstasy just once or twice could
> >harm them, up from 33.8% in 1997, according to an annual survey of teen
> >drug use by the University of Michigan.
> >
> >Mike, a 24-year-old musician from Long Island, N.Y., who didn't want his
> >last name published because he is in drug treatment at Phoenix House in
> >Ronkonkoma, N.Y., says he used to go to raves where Ecstasy was popular.
> >But he says he stopped two years ago, after seeing "younger and younger"
> >ravers get so high that "they would get incapacitated and lie there like
> >dust."
> >
> >Ecstasy is "just not new anymore," says Mark Brandl, executive director =
of
> >DanceSafe Org, a New York-based group that works to prevent drug abuse
> >among recreational users at nightclubs and raves.  "It's lost its .  .  =
.
> >freshness, its panache."
> >
> >Moving on to Other Drugs
> >
> >The bad news, says Lloyd Johnston, chief investigator for the Michigan
> >study, is that some teens appear to have moved on to drugs that are less
> >expensive, more available and potentially just as dangerous.
> >
> >The use of highly addictive prescription painkillers such as OxyContin a=
nd
> >Vicodin has jumped since 2000, and both drugs have become more popular t=
han
> >Ecstasy among high school seniors, the Michigan study reported last year=
.
> >
> >More than 9% of high school seniors said they had used Vicodin during th=
e
> >previous year, the study said, a level of popularity that roughly matche=
d
> >that of Ecstasy when it was at its peak four years ago.  About 5% of
> >seniors said they had used OxyContin in the previous year, compared with=
 4%
> >who said they had taken Ecstasy.
> >
> >When drug researchers at Michigan first started tracking OxyContin and
> >Vicodin abuse among teens in 2002, many users tended to steal small dose=
s
> >from their parents' medicine cabinets.  "Trail mixing" parties -- where
> >teens would mix pills in bowls and then hand them out randomly - -- gain=
ed
> >popularity, according to the Community Epidemiology Working Group,
> >researchers who report drug-use trends to the National Institute on Drug
> >Abuse.
> >
> >Teens also have gotten prescription narcotics from Internet pharmacies t=
hat
> >sell such drugs illegally.  This week, agents with the Drug Enforcement
> >Administration ( DEA ) and other agencies broke up an alleged drug ring
> >that is accused of illegally selling more than 2.5 million pills a month
> >via the Internet.
> >
> >Some Internet pharmacies allow any teen with a credit card to order
> >narcotics without a prescription.  Even after a big markup by sellers, t=
he
> >drugs often are cheaper than Ecstasy.  The price for Ecstasy varies; in
> >some cities it can cost as much as $30 a pill, the DEA says.
> >
> >Safer Than Street Drugs
> >
> >Teens also perceive prescription drugs as safer than street drugs such a=
s
> >heroin and cocaine, Johnston says, adding that many teens don't appear t=
o
> >recognize the risks of abusing prescription drugs, or to understand that
> >OxyContin is in the same drug family as heroin.
> >

d
> >the absolute levels -- one in every 20 ( seniors having tried OxyContin =
)
> >-- disturbing," Johnston says.  "If I told you that 5% were using heroin=
, I
> >think you'd go screaming into the night."

> >in the previous year, the Michigan study said.  )

s'
> >use of inhalants.

> >warned of the damage they could cause to a person's brain and nervous
> >system helped to dramatically lower usage among teens.

> >experimenting with inhalants, Johnston says.

>>ECSTASY'S LOST 'ITS PANACHE' AMONG TEENS
>>
>>Ecstasy was the "it" drug among certain teens and young adults for a few
>>years beginning in the late 1990s: a feel-good, dance-all-night stimulant
>>that was a driving force behind rave parties that featured pulsating,
>>melody-free music.
>>
>>But after peaking in popularity in 2001, Ecstasy isn't so cool anymore.
>>
>>Tighter airport security since the 9/11 attacks has pinched the flow of
>>the drug into the USA from chief suppliers in the Netherlands and Belgium,
>>making it less available and more expensive.
>>
>>Meanwhile, federally funded anti-drug campaigns have produced poignant TV
>>spots warning that Ecstasy users risk brain damage or death.
>>
>>Teens and young adults have taken note.  Last year, 57.7% of high school
>>seniors said they believed that taking Ecstasy just once or twice could
>>harm them, up from 33.8% in 1997, according to an annual survey of teen
>>drug use by the University of Michigan.
>>
>>Mike, a 24-year-old musician from Long Island, N.Y., who didn't want his
>>last name published because he is in drug treatment at Phoenix House in
>>Ronkonkoma, N.Y., says he used to go to raves where Ecstasy was popular.
>>But he says he stopped two years ago, after seeing "younger and younger"
>>ravers get so high that "they would get incapacitated and lie there like
>>dust."
>>
>>Ecstasy is "just not new anymore," says Mark Brandl, executive director of
>>DanceSafe Org, a New York-based group that works to prevent drug abuse
>>among recreational users at nightclubs and raves.  "It's lost its .  .  .
>>freshness, its panache."
>>
>>Moving on to Other Drugs
>>
>>The bad news, says Lloyd Johnston, chief investigator for the Michigan
>>study, is that some teens appear to have moved on to drugs that are less
>>expensive, more available and potentially just as dangerous.
>>
>>The use of highly addictive prescription painkillers such as OxyContin and
>>Vicodin has jumped since 2000, and both drugs have become more popular
>>than Ecstasy among high school seniors, the Michigan study reported last
>>year.
>>
>>More than 9% of high school seniors said they had used Vicodin during the
>>previous year, the study said, a level of popularity that roughly matched
>>that of Ecstasy when it was at its peak four years ago.  About 5% of
>>seniors said they had used OxyContin in the previous year, compared with
>>4% who said they had taken Ecstasy.
>>
>>When drug researchers at Michigan first started tracking OxyContin and
>>Vicodin abuse among teens in 2002, many users tended to steal small doses
>>from their parents' medicine cabinets.  "Trail mixing" parties -- where
>>teens would mix pills in bowls and then hand them out randomly - -- gained
>>popularity, according to the Community Epidemiology Working Group,
>>researchers who report drug-use trends to the National Institute on Drug
>>Abuse.
>>
>>Teens also have gotten prescription narcotics from Internet pharmacies
>>that sell such drugs illegally.  This week, agents with the Drug
>>Enforcement Administration ( DEA ) and other agencies broke up an alleged
>>drug ring that is accused of illegally selling more than 2.5 million pills
>>a month via the Internet.
>>
>>Some Internet pharmacies allow any teen with a credit card to order
>>narcotics without a prescription.  Even after a big markup by sellers, the
>>drugs often are cheaper than Ecstasy.  The price for Ecstasy varies; in
>>some cities it can cost as much as $30 a pill, the DEA says.
>>
>>Safer Than Street Drugs
>>
>>Teens also perceive prescription drugs as safer than street drugs such as
>>heroin and cocaine, Johnston says, adding that many teens don't appear to
>>recognize the risks of abusing prescription drugs, or to understand that
>>OxyContin is in the same drug family as heroin.
>>
>>"The increases ( in prescription drug abuse ) aren't dramatic, but I find
>>the absolute levels -- one in every 20 ( seniors having tried OxyContin )
>>-- disturbing," Johnston says.  "If I told you that 5% were using heroin,
>>I think you'd go screaming into the night."
>>
>>( Nearly 1% of high school seniors said last year that they had used
>>heroin in the previous year, the Michigan study said.  )
>>
>>Opening Door for Inhalants
>>
>>Ecstasy's demise also appears to have cleared the way for a rise in teens'
>>use of inhalants.
>>
>>They were a problem a decade ago, before public health campaigns that
>>warned of the damage they could cause to a person's brain and nervous
>>system helped to dramatically lower usage among teens.
>>
>>Now, a new generation of teens unfamiliar with those dangers is
>>experimenting with inhalants, Johnston says.
>>
>>Overall, the percentage of seniors who said they had used any illegal drug
>>in the previous year dropped from 41.4% in 2001 to 38.8% in 2004, the
>>Michigan study said.
>>
>>Marijuana remains the most widely used illicit drug; last year 34.3% of
>>high school seniors said they had used it in the previous year.
>>
>>Ecstasy is difficult to make here because the U.S.  government monitors
>>the necessary chemicals and it licenses pill-pressing machines.  Canada
>>and the Netherlands do not license pill-pressers, and such chemicals are
>>more available in the Netherlands.
>>
>>Before 9/11, Ecstasy smugglers from Europe faced little scrutiny at U.S.
>>airports.  They could move thousands of pills at once in suitcases or
>>strapping packets to their bodies.
>>
>>"It was coming right from Europe into ( John F.  Kennedy International
>>Airport in New York ) in every way possible," says Dean Boyd, spokesman
>>for Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
>>
>>In fiscal 2002, customs and border agents seized a record 4,633 pounds of
>>Ecstasy pills, up about 12.4% from the previous year.  That changed in
>>2003, when Ecstasy smugglers began to avoid airports.  The amount seized
>>that year dropped by more than 77%.
>>
>>At the same time, Ecstasy's presence in the USA declined, suggesting that
>>some drug rings scaled back their operations or simply gave up trying to
>>send Ecstasy here.
>>
>>Meanwhile, investigators' pursuits of Ecstasy distributors are beginning
>>to pay off.  U.S.  and Canadian agents last year busted a smuggling ring
>>that allegedly accounted for about 15% of the Ecstasy in the USA.
>>
>>A DEA analysis later found that the average price of an Ecstasy pill
>>jumped in several cities.  In New Orleans, undercover DEA agents paid an
>>average of $17.50 a pill, up from $10.50.
>>MAP posted-by: Richard Lake
>>
>>--
>>**************************************************************
>>******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
>>If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
>>much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
>>& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
>>-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
>>**************************************************************

At 02:46 PM 4/27/2005, Joey Frisco wrote:
>"Meanwhile, federally funded anti-drug campaigns have produced poignant TV

>     __

I'm relieved to hear that kids are now using heroin and permanently 
damaging mental function by sniffing inhalants.  My nephew started with 
Oxycontin at 12 and moved on to needles.  WOD has made pot, E and other 
relatively innocuous drugs too expensive for the average kid so they find 
other things.  Hell, glue sniffing was  so popular when I was growing up 
that they locked airplane glue away in hobby stores.  So you ordered it by 
mail.  Thank the heavens cheap shake became abundant then or I wouldn't be 
typing this email :-)

We get the country we deserve, eh?

As for drugs,


Ask Dr. Andrew Weil

I'm sending this note to remind you that best-selling author Andrew Weil, 
M.D., and I will be online for an audio web chat on the revised and updated 
editions of <http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=90538>From 
Chocolate to Morphine: Everything You Need to Know About Mind-Altering 
Drugs and <http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=90539>The 
Natural Mind.

Before Dr. Weil became known to tens of millions for his pioneering work 
and writing on integrative medicine, he was already highly regarded for his 
insightful writing about drugs. His first book, The Natural Mind, is one of 
the greatest books ever written about psychoactive drug use. It played an 
important role in shaping my thinking on the subject, and is widely 
regarded as a classic in the field. As for Chocolate to Morphine, which 
Andy co-authored with Winifred Rosen, there is simply no better drug 
education book -- both for young people and adults.

Dr. Weil will be online to address your questions on a range of topics. 
Please email <mailto:questions@drugpolicy.org>questions@drugpolicy.org to 
submit questions, and don't forget to bookmark the chat address!

When: Thursday, April 28, 2005, 3 PM PST / 6 PM EST
Where: 
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=90529>http://www.drugpolicy.org/news/041205weilchat.cfm

Read on for further information about Dr. Weil and myself:

About Andrew Weil:

Recognized as one of the world's most influential people by Time magazine, 
Andrew Weil, M.D., is a world-renowned leader and pioneer in the field of 
integrative medicine. He is also a clinical professor of medicine and the 
founder and director of the Program in Integrative Medicine at the 
University of Arizona in Tucson. He is an expert in the traditional use of 
mind altering substances and the different effects of various legal and 
illegal drugs.

Dr. Weil is a best-selling author whose books include Spontaneous Healing; 
8 Weeks to Optimum Health; Eating Well for Optimum Health; The Healthy 
Kitchen; The Natural Mind; The Marriage of the Sun and Moon; Health and 
Healing; Natural Health, Natural Medicine; and From Chocolate to Morphine: 
Everything You Need to Know About Mind-Altering Drugs. His new book, 
Healthy Aging: Your Lifelong Guide to Physical and Spiritual Well-Being, 
will be available in October 2005. Andrew Weil, M.D., also authors the 
popular Self Healing newsletter, a monthly column for Prevention magazine, 
and is the editorial director of DrWeil.com, the leading online resource 
for healthy living based on an integrative medicine philosophy.

I am the founder and executive director of the Drug Policy Alliance, the 
leading organization in the United States promoting alternatives to the 
"war on drugs." I've spent many wonderful hours with Andy over the years. 
It will be a real pleasure to have you join our conversation.

To submit a question now, please use the following email address: 
<mailto:questions@drugpolicy.org>questions@drugpolicy.org .






Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

money we need to buy guns and no qualms about killing anybody else in the 
world who tries to make us uncomfortable."
-Hunter S. Thompson

"Friend, hope for the truth while you are alive.  Jump into experience 
while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

>I'm sending this note to remind you that best-selling author Andrew Weil, 
>M.D., and I will be online for an audio web chat on the revised and updated 
>editions of <http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=90538>From 
>Chocolate to Morphine: Everything You Need to Know About Mind-Altering 
>Drugs and <http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=90539>The 
>Natural Mind.
>
>Before Dr. Weil became known to tens of millions for his pioneering work 
>and writing on integrative medicine, he was already highly regarded for his 
>insightful writing about drugs. His first book, The Natural Mind, is one of 
>the greatest books ever written about psychoactive drug use. It played an 
>important role in shaping my thinking on the subject, and is widely 
>regarded as a classic in the field. As for Chocolate to Morphine, which 
>Andy co-authored with Winifred Rosen, there is simply no better drug 
>education book -- both for young people and adults.
>
>Dr. Weil will be online to address your questions on a range of topics. 
>Please email <mailto:questions@drugpolicy.org>questions@drugpolicy.org to 
>submit questions, and don't forget to bookmark the chat address!

>When: Thursday, April 28, 2005, 3 PM PST / 6 PM EST

><http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=90529>http://www.drugpolicy.org/news/041205weilchat.cfm

>
>About Andrew Weil:
>
>Recognized as one of the world's most influential people by Time magazine, 
>Andrew Weil, M.D., is a world-renowned leader and pioneer in the field of 
>integrative medicine. He is also a clinical professor of medicine and the 
>founder and director of the Program in Integrative Medicine at the 
>University of Arizona in Tucson. He is an expert in the traditional use of 
>mind altering substances and the different effects of various legal and 
>illegal drugs.
>
>Dr. Weil is a best-selling author whose books include Spontaneous Healing; 
>8 Weeks to Optimum Health; Eating Well for Optimum Health; The Healthy 
>Kitchen; The Natural Mind; The Marriage of the Sun and Moon; Health and 
>Healing; Natural Health, Natural Medicine; and From Chocolate to Morphine: 
>Everything You Need to Know About Mind-Altering Drugs. His new book, 
>Healthy Aging: Your Lifelong Guide to Physical and Spiritual Well-Being, 
>will be available in October 2005. Andrew Weil, M.D., also authors the 
>popular Self Healing newsletter, a monthly column for Prevention magazine, 
>and is the editorial director of DrWeil.com, the leading online resource 
>for healthy living based on an integrative medicine philosophy.
>
>I am the founder and executive director of the Drug Policy Alliance, the 
>leading organization in the United States promoting alternatives to the 
>"war on drugs." I've spent many wonderful hours with Andy over the years. 
>It will be a real pleasure to have you join our conversation.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: THRUST w/ Lee Coombs - Set Times for Tomorrow!

ok, so it turns out i'm going on at the same time as Mr. Lee Coombs.=20
that means that there will be practically nobody in the room when i'm
playing.  as such, i've decided to fill my box with miami bass and old
school booty jams.  i'm breaking out the 2 live crew, jj fad, mc
luscious, afrorican, mc shy d, and egyptian lover.  because egypt is
the place to be.  egypt.  egypt.

let's get stupid.

MAIN ROOM
10 Fred Funk
11 Smoove
12 Lee Coombs
330  Adam Ohana

SIDE ROOM
1030 Goldilox
1200  Bam
130  Samira
300 Aaron Jae

UNIMOG (subj to change)

10 Kapt Kirk
1045 Mancub
1130 Brad Robinson
1215 Cotter
100 rrrus
145  Miranda
230  Polarbear


 A new residency for Lee Coombs at MIGHTY with Space Cowboy DJs on the Unim=
og
& Visuals by James Green of pixnstones.com

Space Cowboys are proud to welcome back good friend and rockstar Lee
Coombs. Lee is settling down for a chunky extended 4 hour set at
Mighty while the cowboys rock the Unimog out front.

THRUST Recordings is Lee's new label, and San Francisco's newest
party. Being one of his favorite cities in the world to DJ, he can't
wait. The full line-up includes members from crews that are helping to
make San Francisco one of the great breaks communities in the world:

Fred Funk, Goldilox (Brass Tax)
Samira (Seismic, SisterSF)
Aaron Jae & Bam (Evil Breaks)
Adam Ohana (Get Freaky)

The guest list page is up and running on Lee's website, so get on it!

Friday, April 29, 2005
Mighty
119 Utah St. @ 15th, SF
21+ / 10pm-6am
$15 at the door, OR get on that $10 ALL-NIGHT guest list!
www.leecoombs.co.uk/thrustGuestList.php
--=20

And here the great mystery unravels. Let's face the facts:
 
1) Someone apparently called P.O. (like that? sounds like B.O.) a "Homo"
 
2) Word got back to P.O., who makes over 6 figures an hour and has more money than God. 
 
3) P.O., being the insecure homophobe he is (this happens with Mamma's boys sometimes), decided to find out who's talking shit on a global scale. 
 
4) P.O. Hires these assholes to spam everyone and their mom that might even know what a dj is to give the culprit a chance to fess up & make a public apology before he flies over here and kick's some Yankee ass. 
 
5) Bring it on, P.O., but first, please, brush your teeth & take a shower. 
 
so there
 
Chuck

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  'Generation Rx' Label Dazzles Media

--=====================_23995613==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit



'Generation Rx' Label Dazzles Media




By Maia Szalavitz, STATS
Posted on April 26, 2005, Printed on April 28, 2005
http://www.alternet.org/story/21876/

The Partnership for a Drug Free America released its latest survey on teen 
drug use last week, prompting the usual almost-verbatim press-release 
reporting and expressions of being "shocked, shocked" about "kids today" 
from the media.

Almost all of the coverage picked up the Partnership's label "Generation 
Rx," so named because nearly one in five of this group of adolescents 
reported having used the opioid Vicodin without a prescription. In the 
third paragraph of its story, the AP included a quote from the 
Partnership's chairman which said, "For the first time, our national study 
finds that today's teens are more likely to have abused a prescription 
painkiller to get high than they are to have experimented with a variety of 
illegal drugs."

But this is only the second time prescription drug use has been included in 
the survey -- and it was at the same level when they measured it for the 
first time, last year. The AP story (which was picked up by CNN, among many 
others) buried this information in its last two paragraphs, along with the 
fact that far more kids used marijuana than prescription drugs.

So, it's not only not the first time that prescription drug use has been 
this high, it's also not true that kids use more prescription drugs than 
marijuana. Where's the news, and where's the truth in the quote? If this is 
only the second year that prescription drug use has been measured, the fact 
that the level is higher than for cocaine and ecstasy doesn't provide much 
information about whether this is a new or ongoing phenomenon.

That's the news here -- but reporters seem to be dazed to see it.


© 2005 Independent Media Institute. All rights reserved.

while you are alive!  What you call "salvation" belongs to the time before 
death.  If you don't break your ropes while you are alive, do you think 
ghosts will do it after?"
-Kabir

dance. Tarot and other readings offered before and after ritual.
Please bring flowers, musical instruments, and food or non-alcohol drinks

short blocks into park, enter parking lot on right, look for Pagans and/or

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: 30th Anniversary of the Fall of Saigon

Article by my friend's unble in Philly.  Tomorrow is the 30th
anniversary of the fall of Saigon.


--
It was 'our last hope'

Thirty years ago today, Inquirer director of photography Hai Do was
among hundreds of thousands of people frantically trying to flee South
Vietnam as the North Vietnamese entered Saigon. Many died on boats or
drowned. Many were caught and sent to "reeducation camps." His story
follows.

All I could see were the thousands of hollow eyes looking in despair
as the cargo vessel slowly pulled away from its berth along the Saigon
River. This moment, so calm and so quiet, was punctured nightly when I
woke up, breaking out in a sweat, after seeing that a pair of those
hollow eyes were my own.

For years after the fall of Saigon on April 30, 1975, the scene played
out every night in my sleep as a reminder of how close I came to being
left behind as communist forces entered the city.

I was 17 at the time. The Vietnam War had existed for my entire life.
It had also existed for my parents' entire lives. Born and raised in
North Vietnam, they moved to the South as the Geneva Convention in
1954 divided the country. The division ended up splitting family
members who took up arms fighting for communism in the North and
nationalism in the South.

My father, Hoe, joined the South Vietnamese army and rose to the rank
of major in artillery. The only times we ever saw him were at army
hospitals nursing his wounds or at special family occasions. One time,
he arrived at a cousin's wedding in battle fatigues, carrying the
smell of gunpowder and the red dirt of Pleiku. Everyone paused as he
entered the room.

Life went on in and around Saigon while soldiers like my father fought
battles in An Loc, Ban Me Thuot and Tay Ninh. My older sister, Thuy; a
younger brother, Vu; and I would head off to school six days a week as
our mother struggled daily to bring home food.

But the war took a turn in 1968.

Vietnamese believe that whatever you do for Tet, the New Year's Day of
the lunar calendar, will shape your fortune for the year. My father
would come home as both sides of the conflict stopped fighting. There
would be new clothes to wear, more food to eat, and lucky money to
spend. We would celebrate with firecrackers to scare off the ghosts of
the past and the evils of the future.

On the morning of Tet in 1968, the sound of firecrackers turned out to
be the sound of gunfire. Communist forces broke the traditional
cease-fire and staged surprise attacks in every community in the
South.

Hiding in the alley in front of our house on the edge of Saigon,
communist soldiers attacked the headquarters of the South Vietnamese
armed forces with batteries of machine guns.

As a fire started to spread, we had to leave our hiding place, our own
home. I was about 11, but I could never forget that moment of having
to walk through the gauntlet of communist soldiers to flee the coming
fire.

I held on to my mother's arm, looked straight ahead, and kept
reminding myself, "If I make myself so small, they're not going to see
me and they're not going to shoot me."

A few years later, on my way to school, I said hello as usual to the
uniform cleaner by the railroad tracks, waved to the owner of the
motorcycle repair shop, and passed the old man who was always sleeping
on the sidewalk in front of the cinema. As I continued on my way, a
time bomb detonated, collapsing the theater's facade onto the
sidewalk. Somewhere underneath was the old man I had seen only moments
earlier.

By the spring of 1975, the North Vietnamese army was advancing at a
breakneck pace.

The Vietnamese broadcast from the BBC described the scene of South
Vietnamese soldiers taking off their uniforms to flee from the
highland. My father was one of the soldiers who escaped and came home.

As communist forces closed in on Saigon, planeloads of well-connected
Vietnamese took off hourly from the Tan Son Nhut air base near our
home.

President Nguyen Van Thieu broadcast his farewell address blaming the
Americans for losses, and took off. Gen. Nguyen Cao Ky crisscrossed
the city calling for troops to defend the motherland, then flew away
in his own plane.

On the morning of April 29, we were awakened by loud explosions as
shells landed at the air base.

My dad held Diem, my 2-year-old sister, in one hand and grabbed one of
my three brothers in the other. Mom clutched the two others while my
sister Thuy and I took our 72-year-old grandmother, and we departed
our home.

With every burst of gunfire echoing, my father hollered at us to pick
up the pace. My grandmother mumbled about how fruitless it was to even
bother running. I could see rows of helicopters flying overhead. And I
could hear the noise of rotary blades shaking everything in sight.

But I was not prepared for what I saw ahead in downtown Saigon. There
were men with eyes bulging and weapons waving. There were women
sobbing and children crying for anyone to latch on to.

A sea of humanity was pushing, shoving, punching and screaming toward
the U.S. Embassy, at least five blocks away. For the first time in my
life, I was terrified. I snatched glances from the corner of my eyes,
afraid that the men would empty their weapons if I dared to look them
in the eyes.

My father changed our course to Bach Dang naval base on the other side
of the city, hoping that we could get on board a naval vessel. The
crowd in front of the base was small enough to afford a view of the
gate. We quickly found out why as bursts of gunfire overhead sent
everyone cowering on the pavement. Our own soldiers were firing at us
to protect their way out!

Our last hope was fading as we started heading south ahead of the
communist forces marching in from the north. Low-flying jets fixing on
targets around the city drowned out the noise of helicopter blades.
Then, the loudest explosion imaginable shook the earth below my feet.

An orange ball of fire shot up in the sky ahead, followed by another.
The oil reserve tanks in Nha Be exploded, sending up columns of fire
and smoke.

And right there in front of us, a black cargo vessel was boarding.

A single man with arms outstretched on the ramp was pushing against a
tidal wave of humans desperate to board. With my dad in front, we
pushed and pulled and shoved and clutched one another until all of us
were aboard. We forced our way to the hold of the cargo vessel and
joined the exodus of boat people fleeing Vietnam.

The Truong Xuan was a 60-foot vessel designed to navigate the Mekong
River. As the tide turned against South Vietnam, its owner and a group
of paid passengers had organized the maiden voyage to the high seas to
escape. They were not prepared for the waves of refugees forcing their
way aboard.

The first two days on board without food and water, I still had enough
energy to roam about and found two bags of flour tucked away in a
corner. With a tin can attached to a string, I fetched seawater and
mixed it together with the flour. How hard could it be to make some
bread? I persuaded the boat owner to bake it in the oven. The result
was a clump of white powder burnt on the outside. I did not get
through even the first bite.

A lasting image was of my father walking around the boat with the limp
body of my sister Diem. She was dehydrated after two days at sea. He
begged and begged until someone gave her some water and food. My
father dipped his finger in the cup of water, and put it in her mouth.
He repeated it over and over and then shared what was left with our
family. Then, he would pick Diem up again and go to a different family
to beg some more.

Overcome by hunger, I faded into my corner of the world, a door frame
leading to the deck below, where every step had been claimed by a
fellow refugee. The boat was so crowded, no one had room to lie down.

After seven days, the Truong Xuan was found. American warships were
stationed off the coast of South Vietnam to pick up refugees escaping
by anything that floated.

I was barely conscious when my father and a sailor propped my head up
to pour some liquid into my mouth. It tasted like milk. I hated, still
hate, milk. I proceeded to drink the whole container and asked for
more. I revived. My little sister survived as well.

The warships escorted our vessel to the Philippines. We arrived at the
harbor at Subic Bay after midnight on the ninth day with only the
twinkle of lights visible.

With his arm around me, my father talked about our lives, our hopes,
and our future. Then he pulled out a pistol that he had carried on the
battlefields, on the run, and on the boat, and dropped it into the
sea.

Vietnamese Refugees in U.S.

Vietnamese who fled to the U.S. in 1975: 135,000

Amerasians (children of U.S. servicemen) and their families who later came

to the U.S.: 89,700

Vietnamese political prisoners and relatives released to the U.S.
after 1988 agreement: 167,000

Vietnamese living in the U.S. in 2000: 1,122,528

   in Pennsylvania: 30,037

   in New Jersey: 15,180

SOURCES: Census Bureau,

State Department.

About Hai Do

In the last 25 years, Hai Do has worked as a news photographer with
the Troy (N.Y.) Record, the Albany (N.Y.) Times Union, United Press
International and Agence France-Presse, and as photo editor with the
Journal News in White Plains, N.Y. Last month, he joined The Inquirer
as director of photography.

--=20

Lee Coombs!  Space Cowboys!  @ Mighty!!!!=20


A new residency for Lee Coombs at MIGHTY with Space Cowboy DJs on the
Unimog & Visuals by James Green of pixnstones.com

Space Cowboys are proud to welcome back good friend and rockstar Lee
Coombs. Lee is settling down for a chunky extended 4 hour set at
Mighty while the cowboys rock the Unimog out front.

THRUST Recordings is Lee's new label, and San Francisco's newest
party. Being one of his favorite cities in the world to DJ, he can't
wait. The full line-up includes members from crews that are helping to
make San Francisco one of the great breaks communities in the world:

Fred Funk, Goldilox (Brass Tax)
Samira (Seismic, SisterSF)
Aaron Jae & Bam (Evil Breaks)
Adam Ohana (Get Freaky)

The guest list page is up and running on Lee's website, so get on it!

Friday, April 29, 2005
Mighty
119 Utah St. @ 15th, SF
21+ / 10pm-6am
$15 at the door, OR get on that $10 ALL-NIGHT guest list!
www.leecoombs.co.uk/thrustGuestList.php

Subject: [sfraves] >> Depth Charge 6/4 <<

OtherWorld, Coil, and Radiant Atmospheres present... 

++++ DEPTH CHARGE ++++
Saturday, June 4, 2005
more info 510 287 5917

UNLEASH YOUR INNER KRAKEN

When they've had enough rum, the old-timers tell 
the tale of the last voyage of the Jiggletech, 
a noble submarine. Weighing anchor, she drifted from 
port and set out in search of the Other World, an 
undersea grotto of kinky pyramids and giant pearls.

  Sutekh (Force Inc. / Mille Plateux / Context) 
  http://www.context.fm/sutekh.html

  Dragn'fly vs. Amber
  (lovetribe / sister sf / iamthedj.com)
  http://www.djdragnfly.com
  http://www.iamthedj.com/music.html

  Ethan vs. Surprise Guest Contestant (FnF)
  
  Reid Oda (Aranji / Looq Records)
  http://www.orangeage.com

  Dom (FnF)

Fearing the pleasures this might unleash, a squadron
of black helicopters intercepted the vessel on the
horizon's edge. The good ship dove for the ocean floor
as depth charges rained down from the sky! Relentless 
sonic pressures pounded her hull with each detonation,
discharging waves of unending acoustical force. 
Her hatches battened, her bulkheads sealed, 
the Jiggletech drifted deeper.

  Azeem
  (Future Primitive / Oaklyn Records / Wide Hive) 
  http://www.widehive.com/azeem.html
  http://www.futureprimitivesound.com/home.php

  Marc Stretch (Foreign Legion / Look Records)  
  http://www.lookrecords.com/marcstretch 

  Brown Baggin (Oakland deep funk for your booty)
  http://www.brownbaggin.com

  Barefoot (Aranji)
  http://www.orangeage.com

  Mozaic (13moontribe / djmozaic.net)
  http://www.djmozaic.net

Beyond the reach of sunlight, the Jiggletech
found herself embraced by the coiling tentacles
of a radiant squid. Gently, this leviathan
deposited its catch on the sandy sea bottom. 

  Origami vs. Cubik (newstylesound / Moksha Tribe)
  http://newstylesound.com

  Tom Thump (Throwdown / Milk / Kinkysweet Records)
  http://www.tomthump.com

  Joe Rice (Justice League / FnF) 
  http://www.justiceleague.com/agents/joe.html

  Monty (Justice League / FnF) 
  http://www.justiceleague.com/tsm/blog 

  Redstickman (Ambient Mafia / Moksha Tribe) 
  http://redstickman.homestead.com/redstickman.html

  The Band (live)

Having jaws but no gills, the submarine's divers
ventured curiously out through the hatch, snorkles 
in hand, masks and tanks at the ready. What they 
found was no inky abyss; all around them were
Nereids, Neptunes and shape-shifting sea-nymphs -- 
a deep water garden of coral and bubbles, 
beautifully lit by the phosphorescence of the 
benevolent squid.

  BRAIN-BENDING SUPER-COLOSSAL LIGHTING 
  by Coil & Radiant Atmospheres

  PRECISION PRESSURES
  by Know:Audio & Gateway Systems

Scuttling her butt in this clamshell of love,
the Jiggletech never returned.

  DEPTH CHARGE 06.04.05
  more info 510 287 5917
  http://www.redolent.org
  
Protect your right to party. Do not post this
invitation on other lists.

From: Other World [mailto:otherworld_sfr@yahoo.com]

Subject: [sfraves] >> Depth Charge 6/4 <<

OtherWorld, Coil, and Radiant Atmospheres present... 

++++ DEPTH CHARGE ++++
Saturday, June 4, 2005
more info 510 287 5917

UNLEASH YOUR INNER KRAKEN

When they've had enough rum, the old-timers tell 
the tale of the last voyage of the Jiggletech, 
a noble submarine. Weighing anchor, she drifted from 
port and set out in search of the Other World, an 
undersea grotto of kinky pyramids and giant pearls.

  Sutekh (Force Inc. / Mille Plateux / Context) 
  http://www.context.fm/sutekh.html

  Dragn'fly vs. Amber
  (lovetribe / sister sf / iamthedj.com)
  http://www.djdragnfly.com
  http://www.iamthedj.com/music.html

  Ethan vs. Surprise Guest Contestant (FnF)
  
  Reid Oda (Aranji / Looq Records)
  http://www.orangeage.com

  Dom (FnF)

Fearing the pleasures this might unleash, a squadron
of black helicopters intercepted the vessel on the
horizon's edge. The good ship dove for the ocean floor
as depth charges rained down from the sky! Relentless 
sonic pressures pounded her hull with each detonation,
discharging waves of unending acoustical force. 
Her hatches battened, her bulkheads sealed, 
the Jiggletech drifted deeper.

  Azeem
  (Future Primitive / Oaklyn Records / Wide Hive) 
  http://www.widehive.com/azeem.html
  http://www.futureprimitivesound.com/home.php

  Marc Stretch (Foreign Legion / Look Records)  
  http://www.lookrecords.com/marcstretch 

  Brown Baggin (Oakland deep funk for your booty)
  http://www.brownbaggin.com

  Barefoot (Aranji)
  http://www.orangeage.com

  Mozaic (13moontribe / djmozaic.net)
  http://www.djmozaic.net

Beyond the reach of sunlight, the Jiggletech
found herself embraced by the coiling tentacles
of a radiant squid. Gently, this leviathan
deposited its catch on the sandy sea bottom. 

  Origami vs. Cubik (newstylesound / Moksha Tribe)
  http://newstylesound.com

  Tom Thump (Throwdown / Milk / Kinkysweet Records)
  http://www.tomthump.com

  Joe Rice (Justice League / FnF) 
  http://www.justiceleague.com/agents/joe.html

  Monty (Justice League / FnF) 
  http://www.justiceleague.com/tsm/blog 

  Redstickman (Ambient Mafia / Moksha Tribe) 
  http://redstickman.homestead.com/redstickman.html

  The Band (live)

Having jaws but no gills, the submarine's divers
ventured curiously out through the hatch, snorkles 
in hand, masks and tanks at the ready. What they 
found was no inky abyss; all around them were
Nereids, Neptunes and shape-shifting sea-nymphs -- 
a deep water garden of coral and bubbles, 
beautifully lit by the phosphorescence of the 
benevolent squid.

  BRAIN-BENDING SUPER-COLOSSAL LIGHTING 
  by Coil & Radiant Atmospheres

  PRECISION PRESSURES
  by Know:Audio & Gateway Systems

Scuttling her butt in this clamshell of love,
the Jiggletech never returned.

  DEPTH CHARGE 06.04.05
  more info 510 287 5917
  http://www.redolent.org
  
Protect your right to party. Do not post this
invitation on other lists.

> > publisher didn't like the expansion.  then in the late 70's, he found another
> > publisher to agree to publish the book with the expansion.  the only problem
> > was he couldn't find 4 pages of the original book so he rewrote the beginning
> > and ending to make it all fit together.  then he died in 1982, and the person
> > managing his writings found the 4 pages and published the book, with the
> > expansion, under the new name "lies, inc."  that dick intended.
> > 
> > the book without the expansion is very much like a twilight zone episode.  the
> > expansion is very abstract and psychedelic.  i can see why the publisher would
> > have thought it too weird but it does add to the story.
> > 
> > and finally, after about 6 different people told me i should, i'm reading snow
> > crash.  very funny and outlandish adventure book.  what are you reading?  let
> > me or us know!
> > 
> > --
> > 
> > After another moment's silence, she mumbled that I was peculiar, that that was
> > probably why she loved me but that one day I might disgust her for the very
> > same reason.
> > 
> > ? Albert Camus, L'Etranger

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Phillip K. Dick

I saw discussion of this on barbelith a couple weeks ago ... if any of
you haven't read it, a scanner darkly is an /awesome/ book. It's about
drug culture in the realest sense: paranoia and insanity followed by
betrayal and more insanity. Everyone's nuts and everyone's scared and
nobody can be trusted. A parody of the schizophrenic state of a narc
... I can't do it justice with words. I am not Phillip K Dick.

Really. Read this book. See this movie.

(and hope they don't do to it what they did to hitchiker's guide. christ. :=
( )

think and THEN let's have some discussion of it here!

Date: Sat, 30 Apr 2005 10:40:59 -0700

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;

X-Priority: 3 (Normal)

X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook, Build 10.0.2616
In-Reply-To: <9746744ea82676f4e54c022b0e6c7b18@cruzio.com>
Importance: Normal
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1409
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] [Was Re: [sfraves] Phillip K. Dick] "Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy"

Saw it, loved it.  Since every incarnation of the guide is different,
the movie stuck closer to the book than I thought it was.  Loved the
imagery, the vogons were great, marvin was awesome, Ford, Arthur, Zaphod
and Slarti all met up to my expectations and all the cameo's from the
old TV series were good too.  The only character that suffered from
Disney producing the movie in my opinion was Trillian.  Personally I
think DA would've been proud of the movie.  They didn't change much from
his original screenplay either.  Of course I've also been waiting for
this since 1986 when I first read the books at 8 years old.  I only have
3 gripes with the movie, the new symbol for the guide when the green guy
has been the staple icon forever, superficial details about the
portrayal of Zaphod (physical not character traits.. Although, the fact
they made him talk and act like george bush was a nice touch) and a yet
to be talked about storyline since the movie just came out and I don't
want to spoil it. As a movie I'd give it a 7 - 7.5 out of 10.  Since
most sci-fi isin't 10 quality with a rare exception, I'd give it a 9.5
in meeting my expectations as to how this movie should've been done.

-Rayn

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [Was Re: [sfraves] Phillip K. Dick] "Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy"

just a thing, real quick. "true to the book" doesn't mean shit. when
the books came out people were complaining that the books weren't true
to the radio show.

the "Hitchhiker's" books were based on "Hitchhiker's" the radio show.
in England radio shows are a drama format as established as movies,
television, and books. the radio show came first, and believe me, it
is better than the books, better by orders of magnitude, and although
I'm sure this movie is good, it'd have to be good as a motherfucker to
be even half as good as the radio show.

plus, the radio show is the best source of quality samples in the
history of human endeavor, outclassing even The Muppet Show.

(and I have Muppet chickens singing "Babyface" on vinyl.)

long story short, if you like "Hitchhiker's" at all, on any level, in
any way shape or form, get the fucking radio show on CD as soon as you
can.

you will be glad you did.


Giles Soundwave

nerding out and working freelance at a dot-com boom hourly rate (yeah
you heard me), so:

watch the white label bin at your local record store. ;-p










boyakasha.
